To that end, the company is using some sales techniques akin to those of GM's Saturn division. It recently started offering free one-hour at-home test drives in some American cities, featuring delivery of a car by a Saab technician who will answer questions but will not make a sale.

In Geneva, it is testing a new dealership design whose stark white walls warmed by cherry wood accents and tile floors evoke an Italian boutique. After viewing the cars, buyers are ushered behind a ``confidentiality screen'' to discuss a purchase. Salespeople are called hosts, and the nearby service center is undergoing a metamorphosis intended to make the repair experience more personal.

Saab dealerships are getting more than a face lift, however. In the United States, which accounted for more than a quarter of Saab's sales last year, the company lacks strong dealers in five of the 11 markets that account for 85 percent of the nation's sales of imported luxury cars, a fact that infuriates Butler-Wheelhouse. ``We're weak in Los Angeles, which is car country,'' he said. ``If we had the same penetration there that we have in the Northeast, we'd be well on our way to achieving our sales goals.''

The effort to reach out to the heights of the market runs counter to the prevailing trends in auto manufacturing. Mercedes and BMW have both focused their sights lower, increasing their offerings of smaller, less expensive models in a bid to pump up sales.
But industry experts say Saab may have no choice other than to aim high, since the small-car market is overwhelmed now with bigger European and Asian competitors.

``Right now, they're caught in the middle,'' said Robert Spano, who follows the industry for Ludvigsen Associates in London. ``On the one side, there's Mercedes and BMW, and on the other, GM, Ford, Volkswagen and the rest. They need to decide which camp they're going to be in and get out of the middle.''

Saab has clearly elected to take the high road of Mercedes and BMW. But that creates a conundrum because the market for premium-priced cars is minuscule, the very opposite of what is needed by a company in search of a 50 percent sales increase.

But Butler-Wheelhouse reckons on more opportunity there than elsewhere. People do not want to drive just any car, he says. ``You don't want your newspaperman delivering your paper in the same brand of car you drive,'' he said. ``I don't like to criticize my competitors, but I think BMW is starting to have that problem by reaching too far down to get volume.''

As confident as he is in Saab's strategy, Butler-Wheelhouse is well aware of how high the hurdle is for Saab. Last year, it missed its sales goal of 100,000 cars. Spano, the analyst, says European car makers will be lucky to increase their sales by 2 percent to 3 percent this year.

If Saab falters, it may face the unpleasant prospect of being taken off the GM life-support system. ``There may be a window when we start thinking about the next new car, when they will pause to reconsider what they're doing with this company,'' Butler-Wheelhouse said. ``We have to make sure they don't have a reason for doing so.''

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-AZ-LOSTRING-AZR LONG-LOST RING RAISES WORLD WAR II GHOST (For use by N.Y. Times News Service clients) By LINDA HELSER c.1996 The Arizona Republic

TEXT.p: When a blackened sterling-silver ring popped up like a ghost from the vintage debris, Bob Lasher was stunned.
Poking around with a stick on his hands and knees, Lasher wasn't expecting to uncover much more than a charred piece of radio in the burned-out remains of a B-17.
Forty-nine years earlier, the warplane had carried four young U.S. Army Air Force airmen to their deaths on the slopes of the San Francisco Peaks near Flagstaff.
When Lasher, an avid hiker and aviation history buff, spotted the ring, he could scarcely believe his eyes.

``Mostly what I felt was, well, it was a very humbling moment,'' Lasher said. ``I was a kid during World War II, and I was in awe of the guys who flew these planes and this ring belonged to one of those young airman who was alive one minute and dead the next.''
Now, Lasher, 60, a retired reproduction publishing manager for AlliedSignal Engines, wants to track down any family or friends of the ring's rightful owner.
It's not as if Lasher doesn't know who the owner was.
Through records provided by the Civil Air Patrol in Phoenix, Lasher knew there had been a crash of a military aircraft at the Flagstaff site in 1944.
In fact, with all the World War II training facilities in and around the Phoenix area, wreckage is reasonably common in the mountains of Arizona.

``They catalog crashes as far back as 1940,'' Lasher said, ``giving brief descriptions of the aircraft, the location where it crashed and when it happened. And in those days, the military didn't go in and clean up the sites like they do today.''
Starting seven years ago, Lasher began searching for the wreckage. After three attempts over several years, he finally found it.
``I knew a B-17 had crashed Sept. 17, 1944, near Bear Jaw Canyon but it's so overgrown that you could walk right past an engine and not even see it,'' he said.
He also knew that the B-17, assigned to the Kingman Army Air Field nearly 150 miles away, was on a night training flight. First it was to visit Winslow, then Tucson and back to Kingman.

On board was Lt. Richard V. Howell, 24, the pilot, from Chicago; Lt. Richard A. Davis, 22, of Lincoln, Neb.; Flight Warrant Officer Lafayette R. Brown, 21, of New London, Conn.; and Tech. Sgt. Edmund M. Sikora, 26, also of Chicago.
It was just at timberline where the bomber hit.
``Kind of a glancing blow,'' Lasher said. ``Another 100 feet higher and they would have cleared the mountain. They came that close.''
After the plane hit, it broke apart, scattering debris over a wide area.
``Three of the engines are still there on the ground,'' Lasher said, ``and the fourth is three or four feet off the ground, embedded in a tree.''
Lasher said he returned to the crash site three or four times after locating it and on his second visit, in August 1993, he found the ring.
With the help of a friend, Robert Kropp of Mesa, Lasher obtained not only an Air Force report of the accident but a newspaper story briefly recounting the crash:

``After passing over Flagstaff,'' the report said, ``the aircraft made a 360 turn around the mountains located north of Flagstaff. Shortly after, two fires broke out in the aircraft and a minute later, another fire broke out at the rear of the aircraft. The B-17 glided towards the earth. It hit the tops of trees at the top of the peak, separating the tail assembly from the main part of the airplane. The wreckage was completely burned. There were no survivors.''

On Sept. 23, 1944, The Arizona Republic reported: ``The bodies of four airmen removed from a B-17 bomber, which crashed Monday near the top of 12,000 foot San Francisco peaks, were brought out of the wilderness to Kingman Army Airfield today.... A military party reached the ship's burned wreckage last night.''

Once Lasher unearthed the ring and wiped the years of soot and dirt from it, the Cottonwood man found the USAAF's ``wings and propeller'' insignia along with an eagle perched over sergeant's chevrons.

``When I found out that this was an enlisted man's ring, I knew who it belonged to,'' Lasher said. ``It had to be Edmund Sikora's, the flight engineer or crew chief for that aircraft because he was the only enlisted man aboard.''
Checking further, Lasher discovered that young Sikora was unmarried and had listed his mother, Josephine Sikora of Chicago as his next of kin.
Searching a phone book, Lasher has found nearly 30 listings with the Sikora surname.
And now with more time on his hands, because of his recent retirement, he intends to contact them.
``If I can find a relative of his that's still living, and they have an interest,'' Lasher said, ``I'd like to present the ring to them.''
For the moment, the silver ring rests in Lasher's jewelry box, while a piece of the bomber's tail section sits in his yard.
And if he fails to locate a suitable recipient in the next few months, he'll loan the ring and the tailpiece to a new museum in Kingman.
``At least that way,'' he said, ``a part of Edmund Sikora will finally get back to where he was trying to go.''

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-AEROFLOT-FAMILIES-SUE-SCMP FAMILIES SUE OVER AREOFLOT CRASH DEATHS By PATRICIA YOUNG c.1996 South China Morning Post

TEXT.p: The Russian airline Aeroflot has been hit with a writ for loss and damages, filed in Hong Kong by the families of seven passengers killed in an air crash.
All 75 people on board the Aeroflot Airbus died when it ploughed into a Siberian mountain in March 1994.
Aeroflot general manager for Hong Kong Vassili Tkatchenko said on Tuesday he was unaware the writ had been filed.
The writ is for ``damages, interest and costs'' of seven passengers who died when the Moscow Airbus A310 flight bound for Hong Kong crashed at Novokuznetsk, Siberia.
It claims the deaths were ``caused by negligence, breach of statutory duty and breach of contract on the part of the defendant [Aeroflot].''

Air industry investigators say the 15-year-old son of Captain Yaroslav Kudrinsky was flying the Hong Kong-bound aircraft after it left Moscow. Black box transcripts show Eldar and Yana, his 13-year-old sister, were in the cockpit prior to the crash.
Airline passengers are protected under a section of the Warsaw Convention relating to air travel which was signed on October 12, 1929.
The liability of the carrier for death or personal injury to passengers has an upper limit of US$75,000. But larger amounts have been awarded through the courts or through out-of-court settlements.
Aviation consultant Steve Miller, the managing director of Trinity Aviation, said he was unaware of any aviation court settlements in Hong Kong.
``Taking it to the courts is very unusual for Hong Kong,'' Mr Miller said.
Six of the claims in the writs were filed by family members who live outside Hong Kong.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-PLANE-CRASH-BOS 4 KILLED AS PLANE HITS CAR IN MASS. (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By MATT BAI AND DAVID ARMSTRONG c.1996 The Boston Globe

TEXT.p: WAREHAM, Mass. A;N;D;MD; Four people, including a 4-year-old girl and her mother, were killed Saturday when a single-engine airplane trying to make an emergency landing touched down onto Interstate 495 and collided head-on with a station wagon, officials said.

The two people in the plane, who were not identified, and the two passengers in the car A;N;D;MD; Karen Wilkinson, 22, of Framingham and her daughter, Brittany Karp A;N;D;MD; died in the fiery crash, officials said. Wilkinson was taken by ambulance to Tobey Hospital in Wareham, where she died a short time later, said Cynthia Outhouse, a hospital spokeswoman.
Her daughter apparently died at the scene of the accident, which occurred at about 12:45 p.m.

The driver of the car, 31-year-old Anthony Lobello of Wayland, suffered head injuries and was evaluated at the hospital before being airlifted to Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston late Saturday afternoon. He was in stable condition.
State Police said Saturday that they were still trying to identify the pilot and passenger in the Piper Arrow plane, who apparently died instantly when the aircraft exploded on impact.

Lobello and Wilkinson were driving Brittany back to the Mashpee home of her father, Edwin (Rusty) Karp, after spending the week with her, Karp said Saturday. Brittany lived with her father, who dated Wilkinson for three years, he said.
``This is the hardest day of my life,'' Karp said. ``Brittany was the best little thing in the world. She was my life. I'm just trying now to survive.''
Of Wilkinson, a pharmacy technician at a CVS in Framingham, Karp said, ``She loved Brittany very much. She had a great sense of humor.''

At about 12:45 p.m. the plane, apparently with the engine not working, slashed a tree next to the highway, bounced on the northbound lane and swerved across the median, officials said. The plane hit the white Chevrolet station wagon as it traveled south.
``It was unbelievable A;N;D;MD; there were just flames and smoke everywhere,'' said Eddie Caprarella, who was driving by.

Joseph Monteiro, who lives near the crash site just over the Middleborough town line, said he was washing his car when he heard the falling plane hit the highway and saw it lurch left, right and left again. Then there were two loud crashes and an explosion that sent flames shooting as high as 80 feet into the air, he said.
Monteiro said that Lobello got out of the car in a daze and was pleading with other drivers to help Wilkinson, crying out: ``She's choking! She's choking!''
``Definitely there was panic,'' Monteiro said. ``People on the highway were just shocked.''

Police and aviation authorities had not determined Saturday the plane's point of origin or its intended destination. But a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration at T.F. Green State Airport in Warwick, R.I., said that the tower there had received an emergency distress call from the plane saying that it was having engine trouble.

Controllers there tried to guide the plane to the nearest airport, in New Bedford, but the pilot apparently attempted an emergency landing either on the highway or in a bog next to it, officials said.

The plane was a 1973 model, said Merrill Cross, an investigator on the scene from the Federal Aviation Administration. An investigator from the National Transportation Safety Board was en route from Washington Saturday, a spokesman from the FAA said.
About a dozen grieving relatives of the victims arrived at Tobey Hospital Saturday in shock.
When Wilkinson's mother was told of the deaths of her daughter and granddaughter by relatives outside the emergency room, she collapsed instantly, wailing in agony.
An aunt of Brittany's said, ``She was like a little flower that was still blooming.''

At the crash scene Saturday, where rescue crews continued the grisly job of exploring the wreckage while traffic throughout the region came to a halt, the twisted, burnt-out frame of the plane lay stretched across Interstate 495. Only its wings, burnt to the core, were recognizable.

The station wagon, which had taken the most impact, was some 30 yards away, an empty baby seat in the front passenger side. A child's bicycle appeared to have fallen out of the car and leaned up against one side.

State Trooper William Serpa, the first trooper to arrive on the scene, said the carnage left rescue crews shaken. ``It was a very traumatic experience,'' Serpa said. ``It wasn't something I'd want to see every day.''
Given the way in which the plane descended and swerved across a major highway, it was amazing that more people were not hurt or killed in the crash, State Police Lt. Ahmed Mustafa said.
``Maybe everyone was already down at the Cape,'' he said, alluding to the light afternoon traffic on one of spring's first balmy days. ``Or maybe it was just a fluke.''
(Richard Chacon of the Globe staff contributed to this story.)

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-CRASH-BROTHERS-BOS WORKERS REMEMBER OWNERS KILLED IN PLANE (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By MICHAEL GRUNWALD AND KATE ZERNIKE c.1996 The Boston Globe

TEXT.p: BOSTON A;N;D;MD; In era of corporate downsizing and labor-management wars, Sam and Jim Snyder were the kind of bosses workers dream of.

At the brothers' plastics firm in Rockland, Mass., all 85 employees worked full time, for full benefits, and a pay scale they helped set themselves. Every worker A;N;D;MD; janitor or engineer, machinist or manager A;N;D;MD; got business cards emblazoned with the Polymer Design slogan: Together We Guarantee Success. And business has boomed, through recessions and recoveries, up to $8 million in annual sales.
The Snyders' efforts in corporate responsibility came to a disastrous end Saturday, when a single-engine plane they were flying crash-landed into a station wagon on Route 495 in Wareham, Mass.
Samuel Snyder, 50, and James Snyder, 49, were killed, along with a 4-year-old girl, Brittany Wilkinson-Karp, and her 23-year-old mother, Karen Wilkinson.

Investigators who examined the wreckage Sunday said they were focusing on mechanical failure as the cause of the crash. They also said it appears that Jim Snyder acted appropriately in trying to emergency-land the plane, which was having engine trouble. A preliminary report may be available from the National Transportation Safety Board within several days, but a final report is expected to take much longer.
Meanwhile, families, friends and employees are left to take stock in the wake of the sudden loss of four lives.

The Snyders had worked together since 1979, when a coin toss made Sam president and Jim vice president of their new firm. They had grown up together, and socialized together. But though both loved to fly, Saturday's ill-fated outing in a rented Piper Arrow was the first time the brothers had flown together.

``They were a great team,'' said Jeffrey Esterman, a machinist at Polymer Design for five years. ``They were always walking around the factory, telling us how important we were to the company. Everyone should have bosses like that.''

Investigators believe Jim Snyder, of Newton, Mass., flew from Norwood Memorial Airport to Plymouth Airport Saturday morning to pick up Sam, a Hingham resident. The brothers then took off again, headed to Block Island, off Rhode Island, investigators said.

An air traffic control tower in Warwick, R.I., received the Snyders' emergency distress call reporting engine trouble shortly before 12:45 p.m. The tower tried to guide the aircraft, a 1973 model owned by ADS Flight Center, to the New Bedford airport.

Minutes later, the plane bounced onto Route 495, swerved across the median and crashed into a white Chevrolet Celebrity station wagon heading south, about a mile south of Exit 2. The Snyders were trying to make an emergency landing, either on the road or in a nearby cranberry bog.

The plane exploded on impact, killing the Snyders and little Brittany instantly, officials said. Wilkinson, who worked at a CVS in Framingham, died on the way to the hospital. Brittany was supposed to attend a birthday party that afternoon.
Officials at ADS Flight Center declined to comment Sunday.

The only survivor of the crash was Anthony Lobello, the driver of the station wagon. Lobello, 31, of Wayland, an unemployed auto mechanic who had dated Wilkinson for several years, was in stable condition Sunday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston.
``He has no broken bones, only a broken heart,'' said his mother, Marie Lobello. ``He feels like he should be dead, too. He keeps saying, `They're dead, I should be dead.' ''

Lobello told his family the plane swooped into his path out of nowhere, giving him no chance to swerve out of the way. Witnesses said the plane's engine appeared to be stalled and that its propeller had stopped spinning.

``It was too quick, too fast A;N;D;MD; there was nothing he could do,'' Marie Lobello said. ``He heard people screaming that they were on fire, but he couldn't do anything. It was all in flames, it was just too quick.''

Friends and neighbors of the Snyders, who both were married with children, said the brothers were avid and reliable pilots. They said that Sam had considered a career in aviation, and that Jim also knew what he was doing.
``He loved flying, and he was very good at it,'' said Andrew Melton, Jim Snyder's neighbor in Newton.

For the Snyders, the fiery explosion ended a remarkable entrepreneurial success story. Both were trained as engineers A;N;D;MD; Sam at the US Naval Academy and Columbia, Jim at Northeastern University A;N;D;MD; but found their calling in the business world, parlaying their technical knowledge about liquid resins into an international moneymaker.

Over 17 years, Polymer Design Corp. carved a niche as a reliable source for small but complex orders of custom-made plastic parts. It supplies medical firms with arthro-scopes, heart pumps and high-tech devices for spinal surgery. It makes protective suits for helicopter crews and bomb disposal squads. It once replicated a 1950s Cadillac tail fin for a customer.

With Sam Snyder overseeing the engineers and Jim Snyder in charge of sales and administration, the firm has earned a reputation as a pioneer in its field. It has grown almost every year, and added 13,000 square feet of factory space at the start of this decade.

But the Pleasant Street company is also known as a solid corporate citizen. In 1994, the Snyders donated a used machine-shop lathe to the Rockland High School shop department, saving the cash-strapped school an estimated $30,000.

``They were really unique,'' said David Salto, an engineer at Polymer Design. ``I'll tell you, they always listened to what we had to say, even if we disagreed with them. They always treated all of us with respect. I just can't say enough about them.''

Polymer Design is a private firm, but the Snyders regularly opened their books to their employees. They also invited workers to suggest pay structures that would reward teamwork and customer service. And they often footed the bill for company outings, trying to foster a sense of camaraderie and pride.
There is no union at Polymer Design, but every employee works full-time, with health insurance and a 401K plan. Workers say it is no accident that most of them have stayed with the company for years.
``People just don't leave,'' Esterman said. ``Jim and Sam were tough businessmen, but they made sure we were all happy.''
Sam Snyder leaves his wife, a Marshfield, Mass., schoolteacher, and three children. Jim Snyder leaves his wife and two children.

Meanwhile, Rusty Karp was preparing Sunday to bury his daughter Brittany next to her mother. The girl spent last week at Wilkinson's home in Framingham, and was to have returned home Friday night to Karp's home on the Cape, where she has lived for the past three years. But Brittany had been ill, so Karp agreed to let Wilkinson bring her back Saturday, as long as she returned in time for a friend's birthday party.
``His whole life is dwindling,'' said Karp's sister, Mary Jane Dyer. ``She was the center of his life, she was his everything.''
A funeral will be held for Karen Wilkinson and Brittany Wilkinson-Karp on Wednesday. James Snyder's funeral will be held Tuesday. Funeral arrangements for Samuel Snyder were incomplete.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-CRASH-PLANE-NYT TWO PRIOR CRASHES OF 737S STILL UNSOLVED (With CRASH-BROWN-NYT) (HLW) By MATTHEW L. WALD c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: WASHINGTON A;N;D;MD; The Air Force plane that crashed in Croatia on Wednesday was a modified version of the Boeing 737, a widely used aircraft with one of the best safety records in the air. But two unexplained crashes in the last five years, in Pittsburgh and Colorado Springs, have raised questions about the 737's performance.

Like the plane that crashed on Wednesday, those aircraft crashed while approaching airports for landing. But it is not known if there are any similarities between the crashes in the United States and the crash in Croatia.

The investigators in the crash on Wednesday may be lacking one basic tool available to those probing the civilian crashes. The Air Force public affairs office at the Pentagon said that the plane, like many of its aircraft, did not carry a cockpit voice recorder or a flight data recorder, which are commonly known as black boxes. However, a spokesman for the U.S. European Command, in Stuttgart, Germany, contradicted that, saying such equipment was aboard.

The Pittsburgh crash, of a USAir flight from Chicago that crashed on an airport approach in 1994, is the most intensively studied crash in the history of American civil aviation, but safety experts still do not know what caused it. The Colorado Springs crash, in 1991, is also unexplained; transportation officials hope the investigation of the Pittsburgh crash will help explain it.

The 737 is the single most popular commercial jet, and it makes up about a quarter of the American airline jet fleet. Boeing has sold over 1,100 of the 737-200s, the model that crashed on Wednesday, and over 2,800 of all types of 737s, with 500 more on order.

The Air Force bought 19, including the one that crashed on Wednesday, for $5.4 million each, and they were delivered in 1973 and 1974. Most are used for training navigators. Until Wednesday, the Air Force had never had a crash involving the planes, or indeed any incident that resulted in a death or permanent disability.

The plane that crashed had recorded 12,000 landings and 17,000 hours of flight, which made it a relatively young aircraft, said Maj. Laura J. Feldman, a spokesman for the Air Force. The plane was flying from Tuzla to Dubrovnik, a 45-minute trip.
Among the characteristics that make the 737 desirable for the Air Force is its ability to operate from short, rough airfields.

The plane that crashed, called a T-43 by the Air Force, was set up to carry about 60 passengers. It had fewer windows than the airline model and some extra electronic equipment protruding from its stubby, 100-foot-long body.

The plane had been used in Bosnia in recent weeks to ferry American and NATO dignitaries to and from airports where many runways have been scarred by civil war. Air Force officials say that Secretary of State Warren Christopher flew aboard the plane during a visit to the Balkans earlier this year.

The plane had been used earlier this week to ferry Defense Secretary William Perry on trips within the Balkans A;N;D;MD; from Zagreb, the Croatian capital, to Tuzla and Sarajevo in Bosnia, and then to Tirana, Albania, and from Albania to Cairo on Tuesday. Military officials said that the plane then returned to Zagreb to pick up Commerce Secretary Ron Brown and his delegation.
For security, the crew minimized time at low altitudes, to limit the possibility of the plane being hit by gunfire or shells fired by rebel forces, according to officials.

The plane, clearly marked with a U.S. flag on its tail and the bold lettering ``United States of America'' on its side, was based at Ramstein Air Base, in Germany, as was its crew. The civilian version has a crew of three; the Air Force said that the plane that crashed had six crewmen on board.

Investigators working on the Pittsburgh crash say they believe that the aircraft's trajectory on Wednesday can be explained only by a sudden, full swing of the rudder on its tail, but the parts that survived the wreckage do not provide any physical evidence that this actually occurred, and the flight data recorder was not sophisticated enough to record the information.
The National Transportation Safety Board, the independent federal agency in charge of investigating civilian aircraft accidents, hopes to finish the investigation and reach a conclusion this year.
Apart from Colorado Springs and Pittsburgh, the agency has only three unsolved crashes in its 29-year history.
The Safety Board is sending several investigators with the military team to look into the crash.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-BROWN-PLANE-SPI PLANE'S CRASH AGAIN RAISES QUESTIONS ABOUT ITS CIVILIAN COUSIN, THE 737 (For use by New York Times News Service clients.) (With BROWN-CRASH) By T.M. SELL c.1996 Seattle Post-Intelligencer

TEXT.p: The jet that crashed Wednesday with U.S. Commerce Secretary Ron Brown and 32 others aboard was a military derivative of the Boeing 737 A;N;D;MD; similar in many ways to the civilian model but different in that it had no in-flight voice or data recorders.
Boeing sold 19 of the T-43 models to the U.S. government in 1973-74 for use as trainers. A couple, like the one that crashed Wednesday, were later refitted to carry passengers.

The T-43 is basically a 737-200 model with a reinforced floor to support training equipment and with fewer windows. Most of the fleet is involved in training flight navigators for other U.S. military aircraft, stationed at Air Force bases around the United States. The plane that crashed was stationed at Ramstein Air Force Base in Germany as part of the 76th Airlift Squadron.

The tragedy again raises questions about the 737, if only because the well-traveled jetliner has been involved in a pair of unsolved crashes in recent years. A March 3, 1991, crash of a United Airlines 737 near Colorado Springs killed 25 people. The Sept. 8, 1994, crash of a USAir 737 near Alequippa, Pa., in which 132 people died, remains under investigation.

In both accidents, the aircraft rolled sharply and crashed. Federal investigations into the crashes have centered on unexplained movements of the rudder. About a dozen such incidents, not involving crashes, have been recorded on 737 flights.

U.S. Air Force and Boeing representatives said they have no immediate explanations for Wednesday's crash in the coastal mountains of Croatia. The 22-year-old aircraft had modern safety equipment and was certified for instrument flying in the type of stormy weather reported in the area at the time of the crash.
Boeing spokesman Russ Young said the company will send experts to support the Air Force's investigation of the crash.

That investigation will be hampered by the T-43's lack of the ``black box'' recorders that are standard equipment on commercial jets. Air Force Maj. Felicity Tavares said the T-43 was equipped only with a ground-proximity warning system and standard commercial navigational aids.

The airplane had logged about 17,000 hours of flying time and had 12,000 take-off and landing cycles. Boeing officials say that's not much by normal commercial standards, and especially not for a 737, which is designed for frequent, short-haul service.
Aerospace industry officials say the crash underscores the challenge facing modern aviation, to reduce the number of crashes even as the number of flights increases.

The challenge is particularly acute for the 737. With more than 2,600 jets in service and more than 3,300 ordered, the 737 is the world's best-selling jetliner. Boeing executives and many observers argue that, considering its tremendous number of flights in all conditions, the 737 is as safe as any aircraft.

Tim Neale of the Air Transport Association, which represents U.S. airlines, said that the incidence of accidents has fallen by half over the past 15 years. But the rising number of flights makes it sometimes appear that the chance of a crash is increasing.
From 1979 to 1994, the number of fatal accidents was 1 per 1.8 million flights, Neale said, vs. 1 per 814,000 flights from 1963 to 1978.
Bob Robeson, vice president of civil aviation for the Aerospace Industries Association, a manufacturers' group, said the improvements have flowed from advancements in technology as well as training.
``Controlled flight into terrain'' was a leading cause of crashes until the advent of the ground-proximity warning system, which tells pilots when they're too close to the ground, Robeson said.
``Human factors'' A;N;D;MD; such as improved training, improved flight-deck design and improved maintenance A;N;D;MD; also have played a large role in improving safety, he said.

Still, the severity of air crashes, no matter how rare, makes the safety issue one of constant concern. Industry officials acknowledge that if the public doesn't think it's safe to fly, they'll be out of business.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-BROWN-CRASH-BOS TRADE MISSION TURNS TRAGIC (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By PAUL QUINN-JUDGE c.1996 The Boston Globe

TEXT.p: WASHINGTON A;N;D;MD; Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown and 32 others are missing and believed dead after a US Air Force jetliner carrying them from the Bosnian city of Tuzla to the Croatian port of Dubrovnik crashed in bad weather Wednesday.

The plane hit a hillside 1.8 miles from Dubrovnik airport as it prepared to land in poor visibility, Lt. Gen. Howell M. Estes of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said Wednesday. Croatian special police had made their way up to the remote, cloud-covered site, Estes said, and US troops were on the way.

Unconfirmed reports from Dubrovnik included accounts of rescue teams finding several bodies and one person, a woman, alive. The woman was later reported to have died of her injuries on the way to a local hospital. ``We have no confirmed reports of either fatalities or survivors,'' Estes said, although officials said they were pessimistic.
Brown would be the first serving Cabinet officer to die in the line of duty in more than 150 years. The plane was also carrying a delegation of senior American business executives.
Officials in Washington appeared inclined to blame the weather for the crash. They said there was no indication of hostile fire or a suspicious explosion.

Brown was ``one of the best advisers and ablest people I ever knew,'' President Clinton told staff at the Commerce Department Wednesday afternoon when it became clear that little hope remained of finding any survivors.
A consummate Washington insider and former staff director for Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, Brown had been chairman of the Democratic Party before becoming Commerce secretary in 1993.

He was traveling in the Balkans with senior executives from US corporations in an effort to involve US business in the Balkans, and particularly in the postwar reconstruction of Bosnia. Earlier in the day, he had spent time with US troops in Tuzla, regaling them with Big Macs and tapes of the NCAA basketball finals.

Other passengers on the plane are thought to include members of Brown's staff, senior officials of the Commerce and Energy departments, and Nathaniel Nash, a correspondent from the New York Times. Six of the missing are believed to have been the Air Force crew members of the T-43 aircraft, the military version of a Boeing 737.

Wednesday afternoon, President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton visited Brown's wife, Alma, and son Michael, for 50 minutes at the Browns' Washington townhouse. Brown's daughter, Tracey, was flying in from California.
After the visit, the Clintons and members of the Cabinet went to the Commerce Department. Clinton addressed staff members, many of whom wept.
``We do not know for sure what happened there,'' Clinton said, referring to the crash. But he paid tribute to Brown, describing him as ``a magnificent life force.''

``He was one of the best advisers and ablest people I ever knew. And he was very, very good at everything he ever did. Whether he was commerce secretary or a civil rights leader or something else, he was always out there just giving it his all,'' he said.

``This is a man whose multiple talents will not be easily replaced,'' said Eleanor Holmes Norton, the District of Columbia's delegate to Congress. ``For the African-American community, the loss is into infinity.''

After visiting the Brown home Wednesday afternoon, Kennedy issued a statement saying, ``At a time of increasing polarization and heightened voices and more intense rhetoric, Ron cut to the core of an issue and was able to reconcile different viewpoints in a way that established common ground. We need those talents much more as a country.''

Fears for the plane began to surface in Washington late Wednesday morning. Well over three hours after the plane had been due to land, the White House put out a terse statement saying that it was missing. By then, night was beginning to fall in Croatia.

For a number of hours, the fact that the plane was missing was the only confirmed piece of information. Confusion reigned, with US and Croatian officials offering differing locations for the crash site.

US officials spoke of wreckage being seen in the Adriatic Sea off Dubrovnik, while Croatian officials, including President Franjo Tudjman, said the plane had crashed into a mountainside near the Dubrovnik airport.

Planes and helicopters searched the Adriatic for signs of a crash. But the Croatians, whose troops were scouring the mountains around the airport, proved to be right. Later in the day, Estes of the Joint Chiefs of Staff pieced together the chronology of the tragedy at a press briefing in the Pentagon.

Brown's plane had left Tuzla, the northern Bosnian city that is the headquarters of US military operations in the country, around 2 p.m. local time (7 a.m. EST). The flight should have taken about 45 minutes.

Because of bad weather around Dubrovnik, the pilots used an instrument approach, a standard procedure in poor weather, Estes said. The plane was in contact with the control tower in Dubrovnik when communications were suddenly lost at 2:52 p.m. Croatian time.
The plane crashed into the top of St John's Hill, a 2,300-foot hill about 1.8 miles northwest of the airport, he said. Officials noted that the crash site put the plane well off course.

The T-43, based in Ramstein, Germany, had been used to transport a number of VIPs around the region, officials said, including Defense Secretary Willian Perry and Hillary Clinton and the Clintons' daughter, Chelsea. It had undergone a ``total'' maintenance and inspection in June 1995 and run up a total of about 17,000 flying hours, a relatively modest amount, he said.

Bad weather had not hindered other planes landing at Dubrovnik airport Wednesday: Tudjman told CNN that three aircraft A;N;D;MD; two Croatian and one Swiss A;N;D;MD; had landed there ``half an hour'' before Brown's plane was due to arrive.
A;N;D;UR; el.5l A;N;D;LR;
But conditions remained so bad that a US military helicopter was unable to land near the crash site and had to return to the airport.

The US Air Force appointed Brig. Gen. Charles Coolidge to lead an inquiry into the crash. Coolidge was to leave for Dubrovnik last night, and will be assisted by members of the National Transportation Safety Board.
Officials said the plane lacked a flight recorder, which might have helped determine the cause of the crash.

Investigators will almost certainly be able to use less conventional sources of information. These could include AWACS, or airborne warning and control systems, aircraft and the National Security Agency, the secretive communications intelligence organization that is reported to be very active in monitoring the Balkans peace process.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-BROWN-TRAGEDY-BOS BODY OF BROWN AMONG 33 RECOVERED (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By PAUL QUINN-JUDGE c.1996 The Boston Globe

TEXT.p: WASHINGTON A;N;D;MD; Working in foul weather and hampered by the hazard of mines, search parties on Saint John's Hill just outside Dubrovnik, Croatia, recovered the remains of 33 people Thursday from the wreckage of a US Air Force jet. Among them was the body of Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown.

Brown and his colleagues died on Wednesday when their plane, flying in heavy rain and near-zero visibility, apparently went off course and crashed into the hillside, nearly 2 miles northwest of Dubrovnik airport. Brown was flying to the Croatian port city for talks with government ministers after visiting US troops in the northern Bosnian city of Tuzla.

As investigators arrived to search for the causes of the accident and military mortuary teams started work, confusion remained on a number of key issues. Why was the plane off course? Were there 33 people on board or 35, as a manifest released by the State Department indicated? Did the plane have a voice recorder and so-called black box and if not, why not?

Two things were clear, US Ambassador to Croatia Peter Galbraith said Thursday in Dubrovnik after he visited the crash site. One was that the weather was terrible: ``In fact, people in Dubrovnik said this is the worst storm in a decade.''
The other was that the plane ``was not where is should have been.'' Instead of approaching the airport from the sea, it was flying up a valley ``one ridge over'' from the airport, he said.
Officials do, however, seem to be increasingly confident that the plane was not attacked by renegade soldiers from any of the armies operating in the region.

While the area had once been on the front lines in the war between Croat and Serb armies, Defense Secretary William Perry said Thursday that potentially hostile forces were no longer in the area. And, he added, ``you cannot direct ground fire against an airplane if you can't see it.'' Visibility in the area was so bad at the time of the crash, he said, that ``directing small arms fire or directing a shoulder-fired rocket at the airplane would have been almost impossible.''

But, Perry added, it would take ``some days'' for investigators to determine exactly what happened. Officials have declined to speculate about the causes of the crash. But a Defense Department official said Thursday, ``The most likely hypotheses are serious pilot error or serious equipment malfunction.''

In Washington, meanwhile, President Clinton ordered all flags on official buildings to be flown at half-staff until April 10. After a private memorial service at St John's Church in Washington, a short distance from the White House, Clinton once again paid tribute to Brown, his government colleagues, the business executives and others who died with him.
Clinton's spokesman, Michael McCurry, described the president as ``in a very somber mood.''
No date has yet been announced either for a funeral or for the return of the bodies. Brown's family was to gather Thursday to discuss the funeral arrangements, McCurry said.

Earlier Thursday morning, the White House said, Clinton broke the news to Alma Brown that her husband's body had been identified by Brig. Gen. Andrew Canavan, the senior US military officer on the scene.

Perry, reflecting on the death of Brown and of Deputy Assistant Defense Secretary Joseph Kruzel A;N;D;MD; killed in an accident outside Sarajevo, Bosnia-Herzegovina, in August A;N;D;MD; said the tragedies illustrated the risks involved in operations such as the one in Bosnia.
But, he told journalists, ``I believe our security interests are worth risks.'' Perry noted that he had in fact flown to Egypt in the same plane the day before it returned to Europe to collect Brown.
By late Thursday, remains of 14 people had been removed from the crash site and taken to Dubrovnik, the Defense Department said.

An internal government memo described the scene at the crash site. The memo said that the aircraft, a Boeing-made T-43, was lying in pieces, with fragments spread over a radius of 400 meters. The plane showed some signs of fire, but there were no indications that it had been struck by a projectile. The bodies were thrown clear of the plane.

Heavy rain, high winds, fog and wind chills in the low 30s continued to make the retrieval work difficult. The bad weather, in fact, seems to have played a role in diverting investigators flying from the United States to Vicenza in Italy. A US mortuary team has arrived at the scene, and additional staff is on its way from Fort Lee in Virginia.
Croatian officials at the site continued to insist that black boxes A;N;D;MD; voice and data recorders built to withstand a crash and help explain its causes A;N;D;MD; had been found at the site.

Estes disputed this. ``The information we have is that this aircraft was not equipped with what you would consider black boxes,'' he said. Searchers may have recovered instruments in black boxes, he said. But real black boxes are in fact colored bright orange, to facilitate their retrieval.
The T-43 is the military equivalent of the Boeing 737. Most of the 19 purchased by the Air Force have been used to train aviators in navigation.
Estes attributed the lack of a black box to the fact that the plane had been acquired originally as a training aircraft.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-AIRLINE-LIABILITY-575A;N;D;AMP;ADD-NYT NEW PRESSURES ON AIRLINE CRASH-LIABILITY ACCORD (lh) By MATTHEW L. WALD c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: WASHINGTON A;N;D;MD; The Warsaw Convention governing the liability of an airline when passengers die in a plane crash is crumbling as airlines try to raise the accord's $75,000 limit on damages.

But prospects for a new agreement are uncertain, because the U.S. Department of Transportation is demanding that the accord provide that damage suits involving Americans be heard in the United States. Some foreign airlines reject that demand.

This is the third effort to raise the $75,000 limit, which was set in 1966 and which all parties agree is now far too low. Efforts in 1977 and 1988 would have raised the limit several-fold and were eagerly supported by U.S. officials, but the United States did not approve them. Trial lawyers said the higher limits were still too low, and aircraft manufacturers feared high limits would encourage suits against them.

``The amount of time it's taking to do something rational is simply astonishing,'' said Jeffrey N. Shane, an aviation lawyer who was assistant secretary of transportation for policy and international affairs from 1989 to 1993.

The Warsaw Convention, initiated in 1929 among 29 countries and joined by the United States in 1934, also governs who may sue and where, and details cargo rules. All nations with commercial airlines have signed on, but the airlines agree that the document needs to be updated.

Because of the low liability limit, many airlines are voluntarily paying more, either to spare themselves a lengthy trial at which families will try to show negligence A;N;D;MD; which allows higher damages A;N;D;MD; or for general good will, or because they do not think the limits will hold up in court.

American Airlines, for example, has told families of the people who died when one of its planes crashed in Colombia in December that it would negotiate as if the limit did not exist; it is doing the same for the 16 passengers on international trips who were on the American Eagle commuter flight that crashed in Roselawn, Ind., in October 1994.

``The message American is sending is, `We'll do what's fair, because we know a jury will do what's fairer,''' said Barry Lambert Harris, who was an acting administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration in the Bush administration.

But the airlines would like a realistic limit and uniform system. Representatives of airlines from around the world met this week in Montreal to try to work out the details of a system with no limits. U.S. airlines have received an antitrust exemption to negotiate an agreement, which would be subject to government approval.

The airlines and U.S. officials envision fairly simple negotiations with families over ``economic damages,'' the amount that the victim was likely to have earned over the remaining years of his or her life, given normal life expectancy. The sticking point now is which court would resolve disputes if negotiations failed.

Under the current agreement, survivors can bring suit in the country the plane was flying to, the home country of the airline, a country where the airline has its major operation or the country where the contract for transportation was written.

The United States wants a ``fifth jurisdiction'' for Americans: the United States. Since domestic carriers are based here, they can already be sued here; adding the ``fifth jurisdiction'' would generally affect overseas carriers.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-CRASH-BROWN-NYT SOMBER FAREWELL IN CROATIA FOR U.S. VICTIMS (th) By CHRIS HEDGES c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: DUBROVNIK, Croatia A;N;D;MD; The coffins carrying the remains of Commerce Secretary Ron Brown and 32 other Americans killed in a plane crash Wednesday were loaded onto two C-17 transport planes that took off for Dover Air Force Base in Delaware after a somber farewell ceremony in Dubrovnik on Saturday morning.

Croatian and American officials, flanked by 19 American and 19 Croatian honor guards, stood as the last four coffins, two covered with the American flag and two with the Croatian flag, were laid on the tarmac. Two of those who died in the crash were Croatian citizens.
President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia, who spoke at the ceremony, said his nation was ``shaken by pain and sorrow.''

``Today when we take our leave from Ron Brown and all other senior U.S. officials, on behalf of the whole of Croatia and myself, I express my deepest sympathy to the families of those who have perished,'' Tudjman said. ``You will remain forever in our memory.''
He posthumously awarded Brown a high Croatian decoration.
In a brief euology, the American ambassador to Croatia, Peter W. Galbraith, reminded those present that Saturday was Easter eve.

``As Jesus said in the Sermon on the Mount,'' the ambassador said, ``blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called the children of God. Blessed indeed are our friends and colleagues who perished on a mission of peace.''
The Air Force T-43 plane slammed into a rocky hill named after St. John the Baptist on Wednesday in heavy rain and fog. The 35 passengers on board were killed, most instantly.
The two Croatians and Brown are the only victims whose bodies have been identified. The remaining bodies, many badly burned or mutilated, will be identified by forensic experts in the United States.
Galbraith said the most fitting memorial would be to make peace ``a reality on the ground'' and to offer ``a vastly better future to people who in the last five years have suffered so much.''
He called on Americans, Croats and Bosnians to build the ``decent, honorable and wonderfully ordinary lives that we Americans too often take for granted.''

The Roman Catholic archbishop of Dubrovnik, Zelimir Puljic, said a prayer and blessed the remains. A bugler played taps before the planes taxied to the runway and lifted off in a clear sky for the 11-hour journey.

American investigators continued to search the crash site Saturday and had cordoned off a debris-covered area with orange tape and also marked several pieces of wreckage with tape. The investigating team that will try to determine the causes of the accident arrived in Dubrovnik on Saturday.

The white tail section of the plane, with the Stars and Stripes visible, and a few rows of attached passenger seats are the only large pieces left. A long black burn mark outlined where the body of the aircraft probably had been. Down the steep, rocky hillside lay part of the engine and a chunk of the fuselage.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-HK-AIRCRASH-CHINA-SCMP TWO DIE IN HELO CRASH OFF CHINA c.1996 South China Morning Post By JONATHAN HILL and ADAM LEE in Macau Two Chinese crew members were killed Tuesday when their helicopter crashed near Macau.

TEXT.p: The China Southern Helicopter Company aircraft was on its way to Zhuhai, apparently returning from an oil rig, when it crashed, said a spokesman for Hong Kong's Civil Aviation Department.
Other reports said the helicopter, which went down 10 to 15 nautical miles southeast of the Portuguese enclave, was gathering weather information.
The incident fell within Hong Kong airspace, triggering a search by Civil Aviation Department rescuers.
Two Government Flying Service helicopters joined Macau Marine Police in the search for the Sikorsky 76.
Mainland authorities later told the department's Aeronautical Rescue Co-ordination Centre the wreckage had been recovered from the Chinese island of Daiwaishan.
``Someone on the island heard a noise and called Zhuhai airport authorities,'' said a Macau aviation source. ``China sent a helicopter and confirmed the crash on the island.''
Macau authorities, who lost radar contact at 10 am, said the pilots had been found at the site ``and appeared dead''.
Zhuhai officials confirmed the crew had been killed.
Sources suggested that poor weather was the likely cause of the crash.
The Royal Observatory reported strong winds in the area at the time. Rescuers also reported poor visibility.
China, as the country of registration, would investigate the incident, the Civil Aviation Department said.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-PLANE-CRASH-HNS GIRL, FATHER, INSTRUCTOR KILLED IN PLANE CRASH (For use by New York Times News Service clients.) By LARRY D. HATFIELD and ERIN McCORMICK c.1996 San Francisco Examiner

TEXT.p: SAN FRANCISCO A;N;D;MD; A 7-year-old Pescadero, Calif., girl's dream of making history by flying coast-to-coast in both directions ended in tragedy Thursday morning when her light plane crashed in a Cheyenne, Wyo., rain, hail and snowstorm, killing her, her father and her flight instructor.

Jessica Dubroff, her father, Lloyd Dubroff, 57, a San Mateo, Calif., corporate consultant, and her flight instructor and co-pilot, Joe Reid, 52, all perished when the four-seat Cessna Skyhawk went down in a residential neighborhood seconds after it's 7:24 PDT takeoff in heavy rain, mixed with light hail and snow.
``We don't have any details except we are not expecting any patients,'' said Ginger Humphrey, a spokeswoman for United Medical Center.

Witness Tom Johnson, a pilot, said it appeared the pilot was trying to return to the airport in the face of the rapidly developing storm when ``it stalled over my building, winged over and went straight into the ground like a dart.''

``I kept thinking, `Please, please get some altitude,''' Johnson said, saying the plane never got more than 400 feet off the ground. ``It just went right into the ground. I knew no one survived. It would have been impossible.''

It was not immediately known who was at the controls, said Cheyenne police spokesman Dick Royce. But the ground rules for the record attempt were that Reid was to touch the controls only in an emergency and Dubroff was to ride in the back seat.
Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Mitch Barker in Seattle said the small plane crashed about a mile north of the airport after taking off to the west.
``It went in nose first,'' said Dawn Salyards, a resident of the area. ``From the looks of it you could tell, pretty much right away, that there would be no survivors.''

It barely missed one house, landing at the end of the driveway, witnesses said. Debris was scattered throughout the neighborhood in this quiet prairie city of about 50,000. The FAA and police said fuel spilled but there was no fire.
Within 20 minutes of the crash, a tarp had been placed over the plane. The only sections visible were the tail and wings, which were crumpled.
Mike Benson, spokesman for the National Transportation Safety Board, which investigates 2,000 plane crashes a year, said a team was enroute from Seattle to probe the crash.
``We will be looking at all aspects of the accident, from the human factors to the mechanical,'' he said.
Certain to be a focus of the investigation was the stunt itself, the type of flight A;N;D;MD; and pilot A;N;D;MD; many air safety experts say should be discouraged.
``The Guinness Book of Records'' had ceased recognizing the ``youngest pilot'' category for fear of encouraging unsafe flights.

The FAA's Barker, would not comment on the potential danger of such record-breaking attempts. ``The FAA was aware that there was a record attempt being made by the 7-year-old,'' he said. ``This is not the first time something like this has been attempted by minors.
``The FAA's position is that the flight instructor is in control. The 7-year-old was considered a passenger (and) was not considered to be in control of the plane.''
The minimum age for a pilot's license is 16.
Before the flight, Jessica's father said the girl ``dragged her mother and me into this'' and was not pushed by parental ambition.

``If she can do this, she can do anything,'' he said. ``And it will expand her horizons. She's going see the country slide by under her wing at 150 knots ... and she's going to be able to say, `I did that.'''
A man who answered the Reid home telephone in Half Moon Bay, Calif., shortly after the crash, said, ``I'm sorry, we're not making any comments right now.''
The Dubroff home telephone was not answered.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-CRASH-YOUNGPILOT-BOS 7-YEAR-OLD TRYING FOR PILOTING RECORD DIES IN CRASH (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By ADAM PERTMAN AND JANE MEREDITH ADAMS c.1996 The Boston Globe A 7-year-old girl, pursuing her dream of becoming the youngest pilot to crisscross America, died Thursday when her plane plummeted at the start of her journey's second leg.

TEXT.p: Jessica Dubroff's body was found in the wreckage near the municipal airport in Cheyenne, Wyo. Her father, Lloyd, and her flight instructor, Joe Reid, also died in the crash.
The three left an airfield outside Pescadero, Calif. Wednesday, spent the night in Cheyenne and planned to conclude their trip by meeting the young girl's mother in Falmouth, Mass.

The National Transportation Safety Board sent investigators to the scene of the crash, and the Federal Aviation Administration said it would review its rules governing who may operate an aircraft. The minimum age for taking a plane's controls alone is 16, but there's no restriction on anyone doing so alongside a willing licensed pilot.

``I fly for joy. I'm going to fly till I fly solo. I'm going to fly until I die,'' Jessica said before leaving here Wednesday. As she climbed into her Cessna 177B in Wyoming Thursday, she expressed just one fear: ``crashing.'' But she went on to say she did not worry about it.

At 4-foot-2, Jessica was too short to reach the plane's pedals, so they were equipped with extenders for her. The craft had two sets of controls, so Reid could take over A;N;D;MD; as he did over the Rocky Mountains on the way to Wyoming A;N;D;MD; whenever he deemed it necessary.

Authorities said they were unsure who was guiding the plane when it went down in driving rain and snow Thursday morning, minutes after attaining a height of only a few hundred feet. A witness, Tom Johnson, said he saw the Cessna stall over the building where he worked and then nose-dive ``like a dart'' before smashing into the ground near a driveway and scores of houses and cars.

Why Reid allowed the flight to take place Thursday is a mystery. Asked about his pending trip before leaving Pescadero, he replied: ``Basically the only ground rule is good weather. ... If there's any weather ahead of us that doesn't look good, we're either going to wait it out or go around it.''

The girl's parents, who did not live together, sought to give her an untraditional upbringing. Her mother, Lisa Blair Hathaway, taught Jessica and her two other young children at home. Lloyd Dubroff tried to provide what he described as a ``real world'' education A;N;D;MD; for example, encouraging Jessica to try and break the record for youngest cross-country pilot.

Hathaway told reporters in Falmouth Thursday that she had no second thoughts about how she was rearing her children and suggested that Jessica's death should not lead other parents to impose undue restrictions on their own.
``I beg people to let children fly if they want to fly,'' Hathaway said, crying. ``Clearly I would want all my children to die in a state of joy, but not at age 7 ... I know Jess did her best.''
At Logan International Airport in Boston, where Hathaway left for Wyoming, she added that she just wanted to get to Cheyenne to ``hold my child, dead or alive.''

Joan Hathaway of Ashburnham, Mass., who accompanied her sister to Logan, defended Jessica's mother. ``She was just very supportive; she wanted her children to experience different things, so she supported them in doing those kinds of things,'' Joan Hathaway said.

Jessica lived with her mother, 9-year-old brother Joshua, and 3-year-old sister Jasmine in Pescadero, a farming and fishing community 50 miles south of San Francisco. Her father lived in the nearby city of San Mateo.

Both parents thought their children should be educated through unconventional means like flying A;N;D;MD; to learn weather-forecasting, geography and physics A;N;D;MD; riding horses and building furniture. ``I'm the culprit,'' Lloyd Dubroff said earlier this week, when he told reporters he first suggested Jessica try flying coast-to-coast.

``They're getting a tremendous education from having their lives be in the real world,'' Hathaway, 41, told the San Francisco Examiner before Jessica embarked on her attempt to set a record. Had she succeeded, it wouldn't have been official because the Guinness Book of World Records eliminated its ``youngest pilot'' category several years ago out of concern it might encourage unsafe flying.

Jessica, who would have turned 8 next month, had less than a month to set the unofficial record. It was set in 1991 by Daniel Shanklin, who was one day shy of 8 when he flew from San Diego to Kill Devil Hills, N.C.
Jessica, along with her two siblings also took music lessons, including piano and trumpet. All were encouraged to excel and take risks, friends and neighbors said Thursday.
The Pescadero community flag was lowered to half-staff in her memory and a local florist hung out a sign that read, ``Jessica, you inspired all of us. Keep soaring.''
For the $50-an-hour flying lessons, paid for by Lloyd Dubroff, 57, a corporate consultant in nearby San Mateo, Jessica's mother would drive a white minivan to the hangar at Half Moon Bay Airport.

Michael Benson, a spokesman for the NTSB, said, ``We will be looking at everything related to this accident.'' He said crashes involving child aviators are rare. ``Our initial search of NTSB records does not turn anything up.'' He said the safety board will ``look at any regulations or requirements that could have played a factor in this.''

(Adams, a Globe correspondent, reported from Pescadero, Calif., Pertman from Los Angeles. Contributing were Patti Nealon, Martin F. Nolan and Matthew Brelis of the Globe staff, along with wire service material)

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-REID-FLIGHT-INSTRUCTOR-HNS OTHER PILOTS REMEMBER JOE REID, JESSICA'S FLIGHT INSTRUCTOR (For use by New York Times News Service clients.) By GEORGE RAINE c.1996 San Francisco Examiner

TEXT.p: HALF MOON BAY, Calif. A;N;D;MD; Joe Reid, who died Thursday when the airplane he was flying with 7-year-old Jessica Dubroff and her father crashed in Cheyenne, Wyo., took up flying the same way he did anything else: with passion and attention to detail.

``I respected his leadership, his thoroughness,'' said Gary Petersen, manager of Half Moon Bay Airport. ``He was always capable and competent, a real by-the-book guy A;N;D;MD; very thorough, very detailed.''
Reid, 52, who for nearly 27 years was a broker at the Dean Witter Reynolds office in Palo Alto, was president of the Half Moon Bay Pilots Association.

George Auld, a longtime friend who co-owned the aircraft that crashed, said he had first taken Reid up in a small plane in 1970. He said Reid, a Vietnam veteran, got his pilot's license in the late 1970s and was certified to be an instructor about four years ago.
They bought the plane, a 1975 single-engine Cessna 177B Cardinal, about nine years ago.
``He loved flying and helping other people learn the excitement of flying,'' Auld said. ``Joe's not the type to do anything half way.''
Reid began giving lessons to Jessica about five months ago and was supportive of her effort to become the youngest person ever to make a round-trip, cross-country flight in the United States.
``I'm teaching her just like I would anybody else,'' he said. ``Mentally, she grasps the concepts as well as an adult.''
Forrest Storz, who also gives flying lessons at the airport, called Reid ``an exceptional, competent pilot.''

Reid, who grew up in Kansas City, Mo., and was graduated from Saint Mary of the Plains College in Dodge City, Kan., was active in the Half Moon Bay community and serving a fourth term on the Coastside County Water District board. He also was a member of the San Mateo County Airport Land Use Committee and was chairman of the annual Half Moon Bay Fly-In and Air Show.
He and his wife, Ana, were active parishioners at Our Lady of the Pillar Catholic Church. They had two sons, Christopher, 27, of Occidental, and Matthew, 23, of Half Moon Bay.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-NAVY-PILOT-CRASH-NYT (ATTN: Tenn., Calif. ) NAVY BLAMES SHOWING OFF FOR JET CRASH (ll) By TIM WEINER c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: WASHINGTON A;N;D;MD; The Navy said Friday that a pilot was probably showing off for his parents when he crashed an F-14A jet fighter in Nashville in January, killing himself, a fellow officer and three people on the ground.

The pilot, Lt. Comdr. John Stacy Bates, had been grounded for a month in April 1995 after he lost control of another F-14A after taking off from the aircraft carrier USS Lincoln. The plane crashed after the pilot and his crew ejected. The crew members were rescued.

Rear Adm. Bernard Smith, who investigated the Nashville crash, said Bates' judgment was influenced by his parents' presence at the field'' and his desire to show them risky takeoff and flight maneuvers.
The admiral said that in taking off from the Nashville airport on Jan. 29, Bates ascended at an angle steeper than 50 degrees, violating Navy rules.

After the near-perpendicular takeoff, in the clouds, Smith said, the pilot became disoriented, and in all likelihood did not realize that he was heading earthward until his jet pierced the clouds at 2,300 feet.
By then, the admiral said, it was too late to prevent the plane from smashing into the house of Elmer and Ada Newsom.
In addition to Bates, 33, and his radar intercept officer, Lt. Graham Alden Higgins, 28, those killed were the Newsoms and Ewing Wair, who was visiting them.
The crash would never have happened had the pilot made a normal take-off or taken the cloudy weather into account, Smith said after an 11-week review of the incident.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-CHILD-PILOTS-NYT REACTIONS TO DEATH OF ONE CHILD PILOT MAY GROUND OTHERS (bl) By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: PLAINVILLE, Conn. A;N;D;MD; The boys, ages 12 to 14, peered intensely at their instructor, their red textbooks open to Lesson 23: ``Emergency Procedures, Wind Shear, Turbulence.'' The instructor, John Calla, began. ``What are some types of emergencies?,'' he asked. ``Engine failure,'' one student said. ``Electrical fire,'' said another. ``Ice,'' someone else piped in.
The boys are students in Cloud Chasers, a six-year-old nonprofit program that seeks to build motivation and raise self-esteem by teaching young people how to fly airplanes.
Every Saturday morning they practice on the ground and in the sky with instructors from Robertson Airport, a tiny airstrip in this tiny town just west of Hartford.
The Cloud Chasers fly in planes with dual controls and with an instructor in the next seat. They labor over pre-flight safety checks. For practice, they simulate stalls in flight.

They do not fly to break records. And they are all older than 7-year-old Jessica Dubroff, who died, with her father and flight instructor, in a crash this month as she tried to become the youngest person to fly across the country.
But the reaction to Jessica's crash may ground these young pilots sooner than any emergency for which they rehearse.

Federal law requires student pilots to be at least 16 years old before they are allowed to fly solo. Younger children can fly as long as there is a licensed pilot sitting next to them at the controls and acting as pilot in command.
But since Jessica's crash, three Republican state senators from Connecticut are seeking to ban children under the age of 16 from flying.

Sens. Kevin F. Rennie from Rocky Hill, Mark Nielsen from Danbury and John A. Kissel from Enfield proposed the ban, and on Wednesday the Senate voted to add it to a bill dealing with child restraints in automobiles. The amendment states: ``No person under the age of 16 shall engage in the operation of aircraft. No person shall aid a person under the age of 16 in the operation of aircraft.'' The bill itself must now go before the Senate for ratification.

Rennie said that he and his supporters considered the ban a safety precaution that would close an inadvertent gap in the federal law. He said the ban came at a time when the legislature was also banning newly licensed drivers from the roads between midnight and 5 a.m.

``We're putting restrictions on driving a car for six months after you get your license,'' Rennie said. ``At the same time we will be debating whether or not someone younger than that can be flying an airplane, and it strikes me as one of those Kafka moments in the legislature.
But Calla, the Cloud Chasers instructor, sees the ban as misguided.
Federal safety investigators who looked into the crash said they believed Jessica's instructor was in control of the airplane when it went down just after takeoff.

Calla and others involved with Cloud Chasers noted that the responsibility for the flight A;N;D;MD; and, they say, for any pilot error that would have contributed to the crash A;N;D;MD; lay with the pilot in command, not with the 7-year-old.

The ban, they say, would end one of the only programs in the country dedicated specifically to teaching young people to fly responsibly, and even worse, they say, would be the lost opportunity to teach lessons about life through aviation.

``I am the adult,'' Calla said. ``I am in control of the aircraft. I am the sole person responsible for keeping us out of harm's way. It really aggravates me that they want to throw it all away when we could be educating the world in the correct procedures in handling the safe operation of aircraft, making students more knowledgeable about the world around them, opening up their eyes to new horizons, all in an environment that has a safety net: the flight instructor.''

Joe Tortorici, a public school art teacher who volunteers as the director of Cloud Chasers, said that students in the program would have known better than to take off in a storm like the one in Wyoming this month.

``This school is designed to raise self-esteem, to foster decision-making, including the kind of decision that would have kept that plane on the ground,'' he said.``We're not training pilots. We are training mature adults.''
Indeed, learning how to fly also involves learning more than a smattering of physics, mathematics and meteorology, and the Cloud Chasers students portray a seriousness beyond their years.

Neil Brewer, 14, said he would not fly in bad weather. ``It's a safe way to play it,'' he said. ``I think that a good portion of things we learn here are how to make judgments. We learn the more technical aspects of flying. We learn why stalls happen. We practice stalls and go and actually do the maneuvers in the plane.''

Nathan Sheely, 14, said he had been fascinated by planes since birth. The hardest thing about learning to fly, he said, was learning ``to always be a step ahead of the aircraft, to know what's going to happen before it happens and to know what to do.''

State Sen. Rennie said he had not heard of the Cloud Chasers program until his office received a call from Calla on Wednesday. But he said he remained firm in his belief that youngsters should not fly.

``With Cloud Chasers you may have found the best example, with Jessica Dubroff you may have the worst, most egregious example,'' he said. ``Most of the examples probably fall in between. We make public policy with a broader brush and so we have to make some decisions that apply equally to both extremes.

Rennie also said he had received a call from a constituent who lets his 9-year-old fly the family plane and who invited the Senator to come up for a ride. Rennie begged off. ``I don't like flying in big planes,'' the senator said, ``let alone in small planes.''

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TEXTRON-PROVIDENT-TALKS-BLOOM TEXTRON DISCUSSING SALE OF PAUL REVERE UNIT TO PROVIDENT COS. (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By Stephen Walsh c.1996 Bloomberg Business News

TEXT.p: Providence, Rhode Island, April 24 (Bloomberg) -- Textron Inc. is discussing the sale of its Paul Revere Corp. disability insurance unit to Provident Cos. Inc. for about $1 billion, a person familiar with the talks said.

The talks are part of Providence, Rhode Island-based Textron's efforts to shed financial services units and focus on core manufacturing businesses, which include making Cessna aircraft, Bell helicopters and E-Z-GO golf carts.

For Chattanooga, Tennessee-based Provident, an acquisition would be the latest step in the company's effort to reorganize and expand through insuring policyholders against loss of income if they suffer a debilitating accident or illness.

Textron Chief Financial Officer Stephen Key declined to comment on the likelihood of selling Paul Revere. His company ``has been saying all along'' that it plans to reduce its presence in financial services, he said, declining to elaborate.
Provident wouldn't comment on any potential acquisitions. Provident Vice President Thomas White said, ``We have said it is our strategy to grow Provident.''
News of the talks was reported in today's Wall Street Journal. Provident stock fell 1/8 to 30 7/8 in early trading. Textron shares rose 3/4 to 88 7/8.
Officials at Paul Revere weren't available for comment. Its shares rose 3/4 to 25.

Worcester, Massachusetts-based Paul Revere, 83 percent owned by Textron, has been a laggard among Textron's six operating units, and especially among its finance-oriented businesses. In 1995, revenue at Paul Revere rose 14 percent to $1.52 billion while operating income dropped 6 percent to $123 million. Revenue also rose as income declined in 1994.

While Paul Revere has had trouble with rising benefit costs, results are just the opposite at Textron's Avco Financial Services unit, a consumer finance company, and Textron Financial Corp., a commercial finance company.
Revenue in Avco and Textron Financial rose 19 percent last year on a combined basis to $1.99 billion, with operating income increasing 10 percent to $365 million.

Given the performance at Paul Revere, Salomon Brothers analyst George Shapiro said Textron has been looking ``to extricate'' itself from the insurance company in favor of acquiring more manufacturing businesses.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-EMERGENCY-LANDING-LADN (Las Vegas ATTN) SOUTHWEST JET BOUND FOR BURBANK MAKES EMERGENCY LANDING (For use by NYTimes News Service clients) By MARY SCHUBERT c.1996 Los Angeles Daily News

TEXT.p: LOS ANGELES A;N;D;MD; A Southwest Airlines jetliner en route from Las Vegas to Burbank made an emergency landing at Ontario International Airport after the landing gear failed to fully lower, but none of the 132 people aboard was hurt.
The left landing gear of the Boeing 737-300 failed to lower all the way Tuesday, so the Burbank tower diverted Flight 1767 to Ontario, which has longer runways.
After several failed efforts to shake the stuck gear loose, the pilot landed the plane in a lopsided position, with just the nose wheel and right landing gear down.

``Everybody was really amazingly calm. I don't know whether it was shock, but there didn't seem to be any sense of panic,'' said Larry Spears, 49, of North Hollywood, who said he was on the flight. ``I have been on much rougher landings with both sets of landing gears. It was amazingly smooth.''
Spears said he was returning home from an overnight getaway to Las Vegas.
The nearly full flight, with 127 passengers and five crew members aboard, had left Las Vegas at 1 p.m. and was due in Burbank at 2 p.m.

The pilot, an eight-year Southwest veteran, landed the jetliner safely at 2:40 p.m. on the north runway, said Melanie Jones, a spokeswoman for the Dallas-based Southwest. She refused to identify the pilot, citing company policy.
``No passengers or crew were injured,'' said Maria Tesoro, a spokeswoman for Ontario Airport. ``All the passengers are safe, and the cause of the difficulty with the landing gear is unknown.''
Spears said passengers became aware of the problem when the jet began its descent toward Burbank.
``As he was lowering the landing gear, there was a real loud thump, much louder than normal. About 45 seconds later, there was another loud thump,'' Spears recounted.

The pilot announced that a light on the instrument panel indicated the landing gear hadn't engaged, and he would circle the jet past the Burbank Airport tower to see if the controllers could spot a malfunction, Spears said.
That strategy failed because the plane couldn't fly low enough for the tower to see the wheel, so the flight was rerouted to Ontario, located 35 miles east of downtown Los Angeles.
The pilot did a low fly-by past the Ontario control tower, and at that point airport officials verified the landing gear was stuck, Spears said.

The flight crew twice tried a maneuver to knock the landing gear free: sharply climbing and accelerating, and then abruptly cutting back the power. ``He called it a `maximum G-force maneuver,' and it was basically (intended) to try to jolt it down by force of gravity,'' Spears said.
``It really was like a roller coaster. Our stomachs went up past our throats and into our noses,'' he joked.
When that technique didn't work, the pilot announced he would try a hard touch-and-go landing on the one free wheel, in hopes the hard impact would jolt the other wheel down, Spears said.
``He told everybody: `There's no need to be alarmed. We do this thing all the time A;N;D;MD; in simulators,' and everybody groaned.''

Again, the attempt failed. The pilot announced the only option left was an emergency landing. Flight attendants began demonstrating crash precautions as the plane circled to burn off and dump excess fuel, Spears said.
The crew asked younger, stronger passengers to sit near the exits and help with evacuations, Spears said.
Passengers were directed to take off their glasses and high-heeled shoes. ``We started a really slow descent into the airport,'' Spears said.
``The captain came on and said we would only be going about 60 mph. They would try to set it down on the one wheel, and they would try to ease it down really slowly,'' he said.
As the jet landed, Spears said he could see ``the fire trucks racing down the runway beside us.'' Firefighters sprayed fire-retardant foam on the plane as a precaution.
``The captain said: `Stay in your seats. We're on the ground safely,''' Spears said. ``At that point, everybody cheered.''

Jones said the jetliner had just undergone a ``major maintenance inspection'' April 16, but she wasn't sure whether the landing gear was checked at that time. Such periodic inspections are required by the Federal Aviation Administration, she noted.

``We know that the landing gear wouldn't come down, (but) we don't know the cause of the malfunction,'' Jones said. Southwest and Boeing sent aircraft mechanics out to Ontario to inspect the plane, she said.
``We took it new from Boeing eight years ago. That's very new for an aircraft,'' Jones said.

``We have a perfect safety record for 25 years,'' Jones said. ``Occasionally, we have things go wrong, as with any piece of equipment with mechanical parts. But we think our crew did a wonderful job of landing the airplane.''
Southwest offered the stranded passengers an option: a ride to Burbank Airport or a motel room near the Ontario Airport, Jones said.

``The (north) runway was closed five minutes prior to the landing of the airplane,'' Tesoro noted, but she didn't know how many landings and takeoffs were delayed or diverted while the north runway was out of commission.
The 737-300 was taken out of service to be repaired by Southwest crews at Ontario, Tesoro added.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-IND-AIRCRASH-REPORT-NYT REPORT RELEASED ON INDIANA CRASH THAT KILLED 68 (bl) By ADAM BRYANT c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: Eighteen months after an American Eagle turboprop plane crashed in Roselawn, Ind., killing all 68 people aboard, the Federal Aviation Administration issued its answers this week to one series of questions raised by the accident. And Monday, the agency begins addressing new questions raised by the very same crash.
