Since the Roselawn crash, the agency has worked to gain a better understanding of the effects of flying in icy weather, in particular a rare condition in which tiny droplets of water are suspended in the atmosphere below freezing temperature.

When those liquid droplets strike a surface like an airplane wing, they freeze on contact. Investigators believe a ridge of ice formed on the wing of the American Eagle turboprop A;N;D;MD; an ATR-72 A;N;D;MD; causing it to tilt uncontrollably and crash.

Thursday, the FAA issued a series of so-called airworthiness directives affecting 29 types of turboprop aircraft A;N;D;MD; the kind typically used by regional commuter airlines A;N;D;MD; that have a long rubber bladder along the leading edge of their wings to crack and shed ice.
The regulations instruct pilots to look for signs of ice accumulating on windows, wings or propeller hubs. If they see it, they are supposed to change altitude or direction quickly.
To reach that relatively simple ruling, however, required an enormous amount of testing of these aircraft by the aviation agency and their manufacturers.

Those tests included measuring the tilting forces created while taxiing at high-speeds with wooden shapes attached to the wings. In addition, some aircraft were flown behind a tanker plane, which sprayed them with water to see how they would perform in such conditions.
The aviation agency has determined that the French-made ATR aircraft were the only turboprop commuter planes now flying in the United States that required a design modification.

The manufacturer, Avions de Transport Regional, with the agency's approval, agreed to enlarge the rubber bladder along the leading edge so that it covered more of the top of the wing. An ATR spokeswoman said the company had modified the wings of all its aircraft worldwide that flew in conditions where such icy weather might occur.

Anthony J. Broderick, the agency's associate administrator for regulation and certification, said that because the tests were so rigorous, he was confident that a crash like the one in Roselawn would not occur again.
``We have closed the door on the safety issues,'' he said. He added that since Roselawn, no airlines or pilots had filed reports on planes upset in icy weather.

Even so, questions about icy weather remain, and many of them will be discussed starting Monday during a three-day conference on in-flight icing at Springfield, Va. About 400 aviation experts from the United States and many foreign countries are expected to attend.
Those and other discussions may lead, in months or even years, to new standards that manufacturers must meet before the aviation agency certifies their aircraft.

The current standards have been in place since the 1940s, and were not changed after a review in the 1960s. In broad terms, those standards take into account most weather conditions that occur most of the time.
But as more turboprops fly more frequently, the chances of encountering the rare but hazardous condition known as ``super-cooled drizzle drops'' rises.

Broderick said his agency's goals included developing better ways to forecast these conditions and possibly develop equipment to alert pilots that they are flying in such conditions. Generally, these conditions occur in relatively narrow bands in the sky, and experts say that changing altitude by 2,000 or 3,000 feet is often enough to escape the situation.

The aviation agency is currently spending about $400,000 a year on research into the problem. Broderick said the agency also planned to start testing some smaller aircraft that are not used by commercial airlines but that do use the rubber de-icing system.
The National Transportation Safety Board, which investigates accidents, is expected to issue its conclusions about what caused the Roselawn crash within two months.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-HELICOPTER-CRASH-NYT 4 DIE IN CRASH OF MILITARY HELICOPTER (sw) By GEORGE JUDSON c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: STRATFORD, Conn. A;N;D;MD; A helicopter making a test flight before it was to be delivered to the Marine Corps to provide cargo service for the White House appeared to lose its rotors on Thursday and crashed onto the flight field of the Sikorsky Aircraft Corp., killing all four crew members.

Hovering at the height of the nearby Sikorsky Bridge, where the Merritt Parkway crosses the Housatonic River, the CH53E helicopter A;N;D;MD; also known as the Super Stallion for its size and power A;N;D;MD; appeared to be in distress, witnesses said, with smoke issuing from it before its 40-foot rotors broke off.

``The helicopter was up in the air; it's normal for us to see them,'' said John Nasufi, who spotted it as he was loading pizzas from his restaurant above the river for a lunchtime delivery to the Sikorsky workers. ``The helicopter had smoke coming out, and all of a sudden it lost its blades, and that was it. It came straight down.''

The explosion shook nearby buildings and stopped traffic on the bridge, from which the crushed fuselage could be seen burning on the tarmac less than half a mile away, about 50 feet from the river. The craft's distress had lasted long enough for one driver to call a Bridgeport radio station to report that a helicopter was in trouble.
Sikorsky officials said all four peole on board were employees. Their names were withheld until relatives could be notified.

A spokeswoman for Sikorsky, Gina McAllister, said the heavy-lift helicopter, which can carry a payload of 31 tons, was to be assigned to the Marine base at Quantico, Va. The helicopter would have been used to ferry limousines and other advance equipment for the White House. She said it would not have carried the president.

The crash occurred at 11:08 a.m. Witnesses differed as to whether the craft had burst into flames before it dropped onto the flight field, or upon impact. But many said that before the craft fell, its three rotor blades shot off. One landed across the Housatonic River, which borders the Sikorsky property, one flew toward the Sikorsky Bridge, and the third fell toward the assembly plant.

Ms. McAllister said the cause of the crash was not known. With the approval of the Federal Aviation Administration and the National Transportation Safety Board, she said, Sikorsky Aircraft would conduct the safety investigation with the participation of the Navy Safety Center.

The Marine Corps and the Navy have purchased 150 of the heavy-lift helicopters, which can be used for amphibious assaults, carrying cargo and recovering aircraft, according to Jane's All the World's Aircraft. CH53E's were used to rescue Air Force Capt. Scott O'Grady when he was shot down over Bosnia, and to evacuate the U.S. embassy in Somalia, Ms. McAllister said.
``This helicopter has a very proud tradition, and the Sikorsky family is devastated by this mishap,'' she said.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-MARINE-CRASH-600A;N;D;AMP;ADD-2NDLD-NYT (Mo., Mass., N.J. ATTN) HELICOPTER CRASH KILLS 14 MARINES (inserts new material after 3rd graf to give some of victims' names) By RONALD SMOTHERS c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C. A;N;D;MD; Fourteen marines were killed and two were injured before dawn Friday when two helicopters collided and plunged into a densely forested marsh in an isolated part of this Marine Corps base in eastern North Carolina.
The cause of the crash, which happened at 2 a.m. during a huge U.S.-British amphibious-assault exercise, is still under investigation, officials said.

Of the injured, one was listed in critical condition at Pitt County Memorial Hospital in Greenville, N.C., and the other was listed in serious condition at the base hospital. No British troops were involved in the crash.

The Associated Press reported that officials at the base identified three of the dead as First Lt. Arthur J. Schneider of Livingston, N.J.,; Maj. Michael D. Kuszewski of Fort Devens, Mass. and Capt. Scott T. Rice of Springfield, Mo.

By midafternoon 11 bodies of the crash victims had been recovered from the scene. But it took until about 4:30 p.m. for the final three bodies to be recovered from the muddy and wooded area where rescuers toiled for more than 16 hours. It was an indication, a marine spokesman said, of the conditions in the forest.

The search was hampered as tractors sank up to their tread tops in the muck and rescuers resorted to cutting pathways with chainsaws and fashioning walkways over the shifting ground with slabs of plywood.

``It is very thick pine forest and swamp,'' said Maj. Steve Little, a spokesman. ``It has been difficult, especially difficult before dawn as we began the recovery. It has been made easier with more light.''

Little said the marines were part of a joint exercise including 38,200 U.S. troops and 15,600 British troops. The helicopters involved were an AH-1W Super Cobra attack helicopter with a two-person crew and a CH-46E Sea Knight, an assault and transport helicopter that can carry as many as 22 people in addition to its crew of four.

The helicopters had taken off earlier that night from ships massed off the North Carolina coast and headed inland to where the accident occurred near the Courthouse Bay boat basin at the 150,000-acre military base.
Flight operations in the British-U.S. exercises were suspended, although surface operations would continue, Little said.

Friday's accident was deadliest for the Marine Corps since 1989, when 14 people were killed in the crash of another Sea Knight off Okinawa. More than twice as many marines have died in aviation accidents in the last eight months as were killed in such accidents in the previous two years. The total killed so far this year in aviation accidents, counting Friday's deaths, is 19. In 1995 there were six aviation deaths and in 1994 there were only three such deaths.

It was a Harrier jet crash here in 1993 that prompted the Marine Corps to order a rare 48-hour suspension of all fixed-wing and helicopter flights to conduct emergency safety checks. In that year, 12 people were killed in aircraft accidents. As recently as March the Marine Corps called another two-day halt to all aircraft flights for emergency checks.

Col. Joe C. Yannessa, commander of the rescue operation, said the collision had occurred in midair over the densely pine-forested marshland and rained debris over a 150 yard area. Yannessa said rescue crews on foot and carrying nothing more than their packs and hand-held fire extinguishers got to the section of swamp 600 yards from the nearest road within 30 minutes of the crash. There were several smoldering, but not intense, fires scattered throughout the area, he said.
``The aircraft frankly is in such a state of destruction that there are no identifying marks that we could see on the aircraft,'' Yannessa said. ``They were sunk 3 to 4 to 5 feet into the muck.''

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-VALUJET-CRASH-545(2TAKES)-NYT (ATTN: Fla., Ga.) 109 FEARED DEAD AS JETLINER CRASHES IN EVERGLADES (Eds: This is a late addition to The New York Times front page.) (ll) By ROBERT D. McFADDEN c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: A Valujet DC-9 jetliner with 109 people aboard crashed in the Florida Everglades shortly after takeoff from Miami International Airport on Saturday afternoon. Aviation and rescue officials found widely scattered debris and said there were apparently no survivors.

Bound for Atlanta, the twin-engine aircraft was about 30 miles northwest of Miami airport when the pilot reported smoke in the cockpit, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration said. The plane was believed to be turning back to the airport when radar contact was lost shortly after 2 p.m.
``We believe that the aircraft is down somewhere in the vicinity of the Florida Everglades,'' the FAA spokesman, Anthony Willett, said.
The cause of the crash was unclear. Valujet Airlines Inc., which is based in Atlanta and serves 26 cities in 17 states, began operations in 1993 with an old fleet that has grown to about 50 planes.
It has experienced a number of problems, including several aircraft that have run off runways and one that caught fire, but never a crash.

Television pictures from helicopters flying over the Everglades at midafternoon showed no shattered fuselage, tail assembly or other large sections of the plane, only what appeared to be widely scattered pieces of whitish debris that flecked the high grasses and desolate swamps. It was unclear how deep the water was.
The FAA said the crash site was 15 miles west of Opa Locka, or about 20 miles northwest of Miami. But it was unclear by late Saturday afternoon whether the precise crash site had been located.

One aerial picture showed a depression and what appeared to be scorched earth, but rescue pilots found no clear signs of wreckage or survivors from Valujet's Flight 592, a daily two-hour flight from Miami to Atlanta.

The crash site appeared to be inaccessible by road. The Coast Guard dispatched rescue helicopters and aircraft to the site, and airboats were being mustered to carry rescue and other emergency personnel to the area.
Valujet said in a statement that the plane was carrying 104 passengers and a crew of five. Earlier reports had said that as many as 112 and as few as 90 were on board.

Valujet's fleet, said to be the oldest in the industry, has run into a series of problems in the last two and a half years, the most serious being a fire on June 8 last year that destroyed a DC-9 on a runway in Atlanta.
A flight attendant was burned and six other injuries were reported as 57 passengers and 5 crew members were evacuated.

An FAA investigation in the wake of the fire found ``a significant decrease in the experience level of new pilots being hired by Valujet as well as other positions, such as mechanics and dispatchers.''

The inquiry said Valujet's rapid expansion from two to 48 planes had been accompanied by accidents and incidents involving inexperienced pilots, inadequate maintenance and insufficiently trained flight attendants.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-VALUJET-CRASH-2NDTAKE-NYT UNDATED: flight attendants.

TEXT.p: Valujet, which had proclaimed itself the fastest-growing airline in history, said last month that it would buy fewer airplanes than it planned this year and would ``concentrate on its product integrity'' in anticipation of the summer Olympic Games in Atlanta.
Last Jan. 12, a Valujet DC-9 with 30 people aboard slid into a snowbank after landing at Dulles International Airport outside Washington, closing the airport for three hours.
On Jan. 26, another a Valujet DC-9 got stuck in the mud at Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport and 101 passengers had to be bused back to the terminal.

On Feb. 28, another Valujet plane ran off a runway in Savannah, Ga. And on Mar. 19, an emergency chute inflated inside the cabin of a Valujet plane in Tampa, Fla., slightly injuring a flight attendant; the pilot had to crawl out a window, climb into the plane through the tailcone and cut the chute with a knife to free the attendant.

Because of the inaccessibility of Saturday's crash site, few details were available in the hours immediately after the plane went down. In its statement, Valujet said that Flight 592 had left Miami at about 2:15 p.m., more than 70 minutes after its regularly scheduled departure time.
It said the DC-9-32, a McDonnell-Douglas plane configured with seats for 113 passengers, radioed at 2:25 p.m. that it was returning to Miami.
The Valujet statement did not mention smoke in the cabin, but other reports said the pilot had spoken to air-traffic controllers of smoke in the cabin.
The airline quoted preliminary reports as saying the plane went down about 20 miles northwest of Miami ``in a dense area of the Florida Everglades, making accessibility difficult.''

Three hours after the crash, the FAA reported that the jet had been about 100 miles northwest of Miami when the pilot reported smoke in the cockpit, and that after turning around had gone about 80 miles before crashing.
The FAA report said the plane had apparently gone into a steep dive and exploded on impact.

A student pilot, Rick DeLisle, who was flying a small plane in the area with an instructor, bound for Naples, Fla, told CNN of witnessing the crash. After hearing his instructor yelling, DeLisle said, ``I turned and saw an explosion.''
``There was nothing in the sense of fire,'' he said. ``It was almost like what I would call a mushroom cloud. It went up 100 feet.''
DeLisle said he and his instructor flew closer and examined the ground with binoculars. ``We got down to about 200 feet or so, and with the binocs it looked like a large trash bag worth of debris.''
As word of the crash was flashed over news reports, relatives of people who had been on board went to Miami International Airport, seeking information on what had happened.

Hernando Vergera, an airport spokesman, said the Office of Dade County Aviation was bringing counselors to meet with family members, about 50 of whom were at the airport. They were being taken to an undisclosed location for privacy, Vergera said.
Valujet personnel at the airport declined to comment, and had minimal contact with the families of the victims, Vergera said. Valujet did not immediately return telephone messages.

The Coast Guard told The Associated Press that rescue aircraft were helping to look for wreckage and survivors. But all that rescue pilots could detect was scorched earth, Petty Officer Angela Weeks said.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-CRASH-MAIN-COX 109 FEARED DEAD IN EVERGLADES CRASH By GEORGE BENNETT c.1996 Cox News Service

TEXT.p: MIAMI A;N;D;MD; A ValuJet DC-9 jetliner headed for Atlanta with 109 people on board crashed in the marshy Everglades about 20 miles northwest of Miami International Airport Saturday.
Flight 592 plunged into a swampy expanse of sawgrass more about 10 miles from the nearest road in an area accessible only by helicopter or airboat.
The Federal Aviation Administration said Flight 592 was about 100 miles west of Miami when its pilot reported smoke in the cockpit and turned to go back to Miami shortly after 2 p.m.
An eyewitness said the plane dived nose down at a 75-degree angle.
``Nothing could have survived that,'' said Daniel Muelhaupt, who told CNN he was piloting a private plane with a student and was about two miles from the DC-9.
Muelhaupt said he first thought the plane was a smaller craft practicing maneuvers. He saw no smoke or fire coming from the plane, Muelhaupt said.
His flying student, Rick DeLisle, told CNN the impact of the plane created a mushroom cloud about 100 feet high.
``It just looked like a large trash bag was blown open,'' DeLisle said.
The plane crashed into at least four feet of water and debris sank into several feet of muck below, fire-rescue officials said.
All that was visible from the air was flotsam spread over a 50-yard area.

The crash site is about 20 miles northwest of the airport in an area inhabited primarily by snakes, alligators and mosquitos. Rescue workers put out a call for anti-venin as a precaution against possible snake bites.
``Accessibility is extremely difficult,'' said Metro-Dade Lt. Luis Fernandez.
``You cannot see the total fuselage,'' said R.D. Paulison, director of Metro-Dade Fire Rescue. ``There were no tail pieces to see. There were no wing pieces to see. There was nothing at all.''
A sheen of highly flammable aviation fuel on the water hampered initial rescue efforts and attempts to recover the plane's flight recorder, or ``black box.''
A National Transportation Safety Board investigator said the recorder aboard Flight 592 was an older model that would not provide as many clues to the crash as newer, more sophisticated models.

A plane crash in a swamp is one of the worst-case scenarios in the rescue business, said John Wright, a special operations chief for Palm Beach County Fire Rescue, which practiced such a rescue last month.
Between the waist-deep watery mud, sawgrass so sharp it can slice rescue worker's gear and the alligators and snakes, access is a nightmare, Wright said.

Along the Tamiami Trail about 10 miles south of the crash site, dozens of private airboat owners lined the road volunteering their services to rescue workers. By nightfall, though, authorities had sent them home, and police were turning away visitors.
Rescue and recovery workers were setting up camp Saturday night near the site along the levee of the L-67 Canal, hanging mosquito netting and lights from their boats as they settled in for the night.

At Miami International Airport, about 50 or 60 family members of Flight 592 passengers arrived in the first 2{ hours after the crash and were shepherded to a private area where counselors and clergy were on hand.

It was the first crash of a commercial flight arriving or departing at Miami International since December 1972, when an Eastern Airlines L-1011 crashed in the Everglades approaching the airport and 101 of 176 aboard were killed.
It was the first fatal accident involving ValuJet since the bargain airline began operations in October 1993.
But ValuJet has had several safety problems over the last year.
In June, an engine fire spread through the fuselage of a ValuJet plane on the runway at Hartsfield International Airport in Atlanta, burning a flight attendant and destroying the plane.
Since January, three ValuJet planes have run off runways in bad weather, and two planes have been knocked out of service after hard landings. There were no injuries in any of those incidents.

The Atlanta-based carrier began with two used planes in 1993 and has expanded to about 50. But it announced last month it would take a break from its rapid growth ``to concentrate on its product integrity prior to the commencement of the Olympic Games,'' the airline said.

``This decision has been made, in part, in response to increased (FAA) scrutiny and requirements relating to the company that resulted from recent incidents involving the company's aircraft,'' the airline said at the time.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-COLORADO-STOCKS-BLOOM COLORADO STOCKS: UAL RISES 2.8% TO LEAD INDEX TO RECORD HIGH (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By Jeanie Stokes c.1996 Bloomberg Business News

TEXT.p: Denver, May 13 (Bloomberg) -- Colorado stocks climbed to a record high as UAL Corp., parent of United Airlines, rose in the wake of the crash of a ValuJet Inc. DC-9 this weekend.

The Bloomberg Colorado Stock Index rose 0.86, or 0.61 percent, to 141.07. Advancers outnumbered decliners 48 to 35 in the price-weighted index that tracks shares of companies with operations in the state.
In the broader U.S. stock market, the Standard A;N;D;AMP; Poor's 500 Index rose 9.42, or 1.44 percent, to 661.51. The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 64.46, or 1.17 percent, to 5582.60.

UAL rose 6, or 2.8 percent, to 214, as the stocks of major U.S. airlines registered their biggest one-day advance in almost a month. The SA;N;D;AMP;P airline index rose 12.37 to 344.53, with investors favoring established carriers over recent start-ups.
UAL is included in Colorado's index because of its dominant position in the state's economy.

Investors said Saturday's crash of a ValuJet DC-9 in the Florida Everglades cast a pall over the ability of fledgling airlines to raise sufficient capital to replace older jets. The crash killed 109 people. ``People have been able to get financing fairly readily,'' said Joseph Ray of Gerald L. Ray A;N;D;AMP; Associates, a Dallas money management firm that oversees $500 million in assets. ``It will be interesting to see what the capital markets say about all this.''

Among those carriers that Ray is watching is Colorado Springs-based Western Pacific Airlines Inc., which fell 3/4 to 15 3/4 to lead the state's declining issues. Western Pacific hopes to add eight aircraft to its 14-plane fleet by the end of 1996.

Denver-based Frontier Airlines Inc., which fell 3/4 to 7 5/8, is also growing. The airline, which marks its second anniversary in July, is putting its eighth and ninth aircraft into service this summer, and hopes to add at least a couple more Boeing 737s this year.
The state's other airline, cargo carrier Atlas Air Inc., fell 7/16 to 53 13/16.

Other advancing stocks included Lockheed Martin Corp., up 2 n1/8 at 83 1/4; Amrion Inc., up 1 1/2 at 18 5/8; Exabyte Corp., up 5/8 at 20 5/8; and Newmont Mining Corp., up 5/8 at 59 1/8. Other declining issues included Boston Chicken Inc., off 5/8 at 35 7/8, even though it reported first-quarter profit doubled.
Adolph Coors Co. fell 7/16 to 17 13/16, while FirstMiss Gold Corp., dropped 3/8 to 37 5/8.
The Colorado index has gained 18.62 percent since the first of the year, compared with the SA;N;D;AMP;P 500's 7.40 percent advance.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-CRASH-MAIN-COX EDs: Will update with 8 p.m. news conference. CRASH INVESTIGATORS BRAVE ENVIRONMENT RECOVER `BLACK BOX,' BODY PARTS; SEARCH CONTINUES FOR SECOND RECORDER, CAUSE EDs: With CRASH-PILOT, CRASH-ID, CRASH-FAA. By GARY KANE and JOHN FERNANDEZ c.1996 Cox News Service

TEXT.p: MIAMI A;N;D;MD; Undaunted by a hostile environment, crash scene investigators extracted a flight data recorder and dozens of body parts Monday from the marshy grave of ValuJet Flight 592.
The discovery marked the first real victory for recovery crews since the aircraft nosedived into a desolate expanse of the Florida Everglades two days ago.
National Transportation Safety Board investigators said the ``black box,'' which was in the powder-blue tail of the DC-9 aircraft, was located during a plotted-grid search of the crash site.

The flight data recorder measures altitude, speed and acceleration of the aircraft at the time of an accident. The device will be taken to an NTSB laboratory in Washington where it will be analyzed for clues to the cause of Saturday's crash.
Search crews are still looking for a second recorder which is designed to capture the conversations in the cockpit.

The Atlanta-bound plane crashed roughly nine minutes after takeoff from Miami's airport with 104 passengers and five crew members. The flight crew reported smoke in the cockpit and cabin before the tower lost contact.

While a marksman atop an airboat scanned for alligators and poisonous water moccasins, five teams of Metro-Dade police divers took turns wading through the waist-deep soup of water and muck. The walked gingerly, groping with their hands and feet for chucks of debris or remains of victims.

The six members of each crew were linked to each other with rope A;N;D;MD; muck beneath the surface water is soft enough in spots to swallow trespassers. Gooey and black, the muck is full of decaying plant material. South Florida Water Management District specialists at the site measured muck at 3-5 feet deep with 12-18 inches of water atop.
Like archaeologists working a dig, the investigators marked the search area in square plots.
The site, sandwiched between two canals, is just east of the Miccosukee Indian Reservation and nine miles from Route 41. It is roughly 16 miles northwest of the Miami airport runway.

Helicopters shuttle searchers to the site, where they work in shifts of about 20 minutes. They wear hazardous-material gear and masks and tightly tape pant legs and shirt sleeves for added protection against irritating jet fuel and bacteria in the water. At the end of each shift, the teams remove their dive suits and drop them in barrels of disinfectants.
Investigators said they have little hope of finding any intact bodies. The aircraft reportedly plunged into the marshland at a 75-degree angle at an estimated speed of 500 mph.

About 40 body parts were recovered Sunday A;N;D;MD; nothing larger than a knee. By noon Monday, seven body bags of remains were loaded onto an airboat normally used for everglades tours and taken to a levee where emergency vehicles and vans from the medical examiners office assemble.
As the grim search progressed, federal transportation officials in Washington provided new details about the stepped-up scrutiny of ValuJet.

The Federal Aviation Administration had been reviewing ValuJet's operations since February because of a series of problem flights. Saturday's crash prompted FAA officials to begin a month of intensive inspections of Valujet's maintenance plants and cockpit procedures.

Inspectors are visiting Valujet's 29 field maintenance facilities where mechanics handle minor repairs and make sure planes are ready for their next flight. The FAA also wants to check work at six contractor maintenance facilities used by the airline. Among them: Aero Thrust in Miami, where engine repairs are made, Aero Corp. in Lake City, which handles airframe work, and Sabre Tech in Miami.

The crash has sparked questions about the age of Valujet's fleet. The DC-9 that crashed Saturday was 27 years old. But FAA officials suggested Monday that older aircraft can be perfectly safe because any plane 15 years or older is required to have frequent inspections.
CBS News reported that the FAA was to be investigated as part of an overall probe being conducted in the wake of the crash by the Department of Transportation.
CBS said the Department of Transportation was looking into the possibility the FAA knew Valujet was headed for trouble before the crash. The network said the FAA declined to comment on the probe.

ValuJet Airlines stock dropped sharply Monday, the first day of trading since the crash and also the first day of intensified federal scrutiny of the Atlanta-based carrier. It closed on the Nasdaq Stock Market down $4.18} a share at $13.68}. This story was supplemented by wire service material.
(Story Filed By The Palm Beach Post, West Palm Beach, Fla.)

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-CRASH-SCENE-BOS IT'S INVESTIGATORS VERSUS NATURE AT EVERGLADES CRASH SCENE (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By MICHAEL REZENDES c.1996 The Boston Globe

TEXT.p: THE EVERGLADES, Fla. A;N;D;MD; With a government sniper patrolling for alligators and snakes, 30 divers Monday combed the mud and inky waters of this vast swamp in a gruesome search that yielded one of the two flight recorders from doomed Flight 592.

Federal investigators are hoping the flight-data recorder, also known as a ``black box,'' will offer clues about the cause of the crash that took 109 lives Saturday afternoon, when a ValuJet DC-9 nose-dived into a desolate stretch of saw grass, water and ooze about 15 miles northwest of Miami.
``We're encouraged that we found it and hope we can find the second one which recorded conversations in the cockpit,'' said Mike Benson, a spokesman for the National Transportation Safety Board.
Rescuers also continued the grim search for bodies. By midday seven body bags of remains had been removed.
``I don't hold any hope we'll find any recoverable large parts of people,'' said retired Dade County Medical Examiner Joseph Davis, who is taking part in the investigation.

The flight-data recorder found Monday by divers measures altitude, speed and acceleration of the aircraft at the time of an accident. But some investigators believe more significant information will be contained in the box that recorded the crew's conversations.
Meanwhile, CBS News reported that the Federal Aviation Administration was to be investigated as part of an overall probe being conducted in the wake of the crash by the Department of Transportation.
CBS said the Transportation Department was looking into the possibility the FAA knew ValuJet was headed for trouble before the crash. The network said the FAA declined to comment on the probe.
The FAA Monday began an intensive review of ValuJet, in which FAA inspectors were to ride in the cockpits and review the company's maintenance facilities for the next month.

President Clinton said he directed Transportation Secretary Federico Pena to report this week on the additional measures the Transportation Department and the FAA plan to take to ensure US airlines ``continue to operate at the highest level of safety.''
``I'm determined to do everything I can to make sure American aviation is the safest in the world,'' Clinton said.

Although officials were buoyed by retrieving the flight-data recorder, officials from a widening array of civilian and military agencies remained stymied about how to retrieve pieces of the airliner from what one investigator called the most difficult scene ever encountered for recovering a large passenger plane.
``We're going to have to be prepared for the fact that this may take us some time,'' said Robert Francis, vice chairman of the NTSB.
Francis would not say whether investigators might ultimately have to leave victims and large portions of the plane entombed in the swamp, which sucked the entire airliner into its murky depths.
But the problems associated with retrieving the submerged craft from a site more than 300 yards from the nearest road mounted even as new plans for recovery were considered.
``At any accident site you end up leaving something, you never recover every single part,'' Francis said.

Francis said investigators and salvage crews haven't ruled out any option for retreiving the wreckage. Nevertheless, an early plan to build a new road to the scene of the crash has been frowned upon because of environmental considerations.

Although the federally protected Everglades National Park A;N;D;MD; home to rare animals, birds and plants A;N;D;MD; is posing unprecedented hurdles to government salvage crews, it is considered environmentally fragile due in part to pollution from nearby sugar cane farms.

A plan to build an artificial dam around the crash site, so that water can be drained from the area around the wreckage, has also met with skeptisim. Local geologists say the rock underlying the swamp is so porous that water would inevitably seep back into the site.
Other potential recovery plans include construction of a floating staging area near the wreckage and the erection of temporay bridging from the nearest roadways.

Monday, US Navy salvage experts arrived began searching for the flight-data recorder with an underwater listening device called a hydrophone to try picking up radio signals emitted from the data recorder.
The box has a ``pinger'' that transmits a signal for 30 days. But the signal would be activated only if the data recorder rests in water and may be impossible to pick up if the box is covered in mud.

``The equipment is designed for ocean operations, not for swamp operations,'' said Greg Geisen, a Navy spokesman at the Pentagon. He added that Navy personnel on the scene ``don't know the terrain. They're still trying to assess if they can even possibly assist.''
The Navy salvage experts include the head of diving and salvage operations at the Navy Sea Systems Command and a civilian expert from the firm of Oceaneering Technologies in Maryland.

Federal officials Monday also continued to paint a harrowing picture of the aircraft's passengers and crew, which encountered smoke in both the cockpit and cabin before the plane plunged into the Everglades at an estimated speed of more than 500 m.p.h.

The crew, speaking with great urgency just minutes after leaving Miami International Airport, made its last transmission at 2:13 p.m., asking air traffic controllers for the location of the airport A;N;D;MD; then failed to respond when the information was given.
NTSB investigator Greg Feith said it was impossible to say whether the crew was conscious.
Meanwhile, the recovery of human remains continued with urgency, due to rapid decomposition caused by subtropical weather, swamp bacteria and spilled fuel.

Dr. Roger Mittelman, the Dade County medical examiner, said the largest remain recovered so far was a knee. He said his office would rely on heart pacemakers, teeth, fingerprints, tatooed skin and DNA tests to identify the bodies. He said officials also would test for the presence of carbon dioxide in the remains, which could indicate whether the cabin was on fire when the plane went down.

Many high level officials were giving much credit to the divers who, because of the jet fuel and other contaminants in the water, taped themselves into airtight protective body wrap before donning rubber suits to work 20-minute shifts in water with near-zero visibility.
For the most part, officials said, divers searched blindly for bodies and wreckage using their hands, feet and long poles.
``It's not the most efficient of operations,'' Francis said. ``It's tough going.''
(To read previous Globe coverage and related information on the ValuJet crash, go to the Globe Online at http://www.boston.com. Use the keyword: ValuJet.)
(Matthew Brelis of the Globe staff in Boston contributed to this report. Material from wire services also was included.)

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-AIRCRASH-PILOT-TEX PILOTS REMEMBERED AS `VERY SAFETY CONSCIOUS' (For use by NYTimes News Service clients) By G. CHAMBERS WILLIAMS III c.1996 Fort Worth Star-Telegram

TEXT.p: Candalyn ``Candi'' Chamberlin Kubeck was apparently the first female captain killed in a commercial airline crash, and one of only a few female commercial pilots killed in a crash, other pilots said Monday.

Pilots, friends and family praised Kubeck and her co-pilot, First Officer Richard Sherrill Hazen, as experienced and ``very safety conscious,'' with excellent flying records. They were among the 109 killed Saturday when ValuJet Airlines Flight 592 plummeted into the Florida Everglades.

One of the only other female pilots killed on duty in a commercial crash was the co-pilot of a United Airlines 737 that crashed in 1991 in Colorado Springs, Colo., said Beverly Bass, an American Airlines captain and founder of the International Society of Women Airline Pilots.
Kubeck had been involved in two previous aircraft incidents as pilot, neither of them serious, Federal Aviation Administration records show.

In November 1991, Kubeck was flying a Fairchild Metro 3 twin-engine turboprop for Grand Airways Inc., a now-defunct sightseeing and commuter airline that operated between Las Vegas and the Grand Canyon Airport in Arizona.
Upon landing at the Grand Canyon Airport, the propeller of the aircraft's left engine struck a deer on the runway. There were no injuries and no significant damage to the aircraft, FAA records show.
On Sept. 2, 1994, Kubeck was piloting another McDonnell Douglas DC-9 for ValuJet when the plane skidded sideways on a wet runway during a landing in Chicago, records show.
There were no injuries, but the jet had to be towed to the gate, records show.

FAA records show that Kubeck passed a checkride in a simulator after the incident, scoring a ``high grade.'' No FAA enforcement action was taken against her for her performance during the skid, although the incident report indicated that she had failed to maintain directional control of the aircraft.
Each of the earlier events involving Kubeck was classified by the FAA as an ``air carrier incident,'' rather than the more serious ``accident.''

Kubeck, a 35-year-old San Diego native, lived with her airline-captain husband in Phoenix and maintained an apartment in Bedford, Texas, where she was based at Dallas/Fort Worth Airport. She was first licensed as a pilot in 1978 at age 17 in Encinitas, Calif., a San Diego suburb.

In February 1983, in the wake of President Reagan's firing of striking air traffic controllers, Kubeck became a controller in the El Paso Airport control tower, the FAA said. She left that job in 1984 to pursue a career as a professional pilot.

She had FAA licenses as an air-transport pilot, certificated flight instructor (airplane and instrument) and control-tower operator, and had ratings to fly single- and multiengine airplanes. She was qualified to fly the Boeing 737, Beech 1900, DC-9 and Fairchild Metro 3 aircraft.

Kubeck had 8,805 flight hours, including 5,388 hours as a captain or pilot in command, ValuJet officials reported. Since joining ValuJet in late 1993, she had accumulated 2,073 flight hours with the airline, including 1,697 as a captain in the DC-9.
She last passed the required annual first-class pilot's medical exam April 12, records show.
As a pilot, she was ``very experienced, very well-trained, very competent,'' ValuJet President Lewis Jordan said.
Hazen, 52, was also assigned to ValuJet's D/FW base, from which the airline operates as many as five daily round trips to its main hub, Atlanta's Hartsfield Airport.
Hazen, a retired Air Force pilot, had 6,146 flight hours. He lived in Mineola, a small city northeast of Tyler in East Texas, and had been flying for ValuJet since November, a family spokesman said.
He previously worked for Federal Express and for an airline taking tourists to Mexico, said his stepdaughter, Kimberly Reedy of Irving.

FAA records show that Hazen had an air-transport pilot's license, as well as a flight engineer's certificate. His ratings included single- and multiengine aircraft, and he passed the first-class medical exam in September 1995.
As a pilot, Hazen was ``very safety conscious,'' son-in-law Marc Reedy said. ``He was proud of his safety record and proud to be a pilot.''
Kimberly Reedy said the tragedy is ``hard to believe.'' Hazen used to take her for rides in his two-seat plane and ``just fly around for fun.''
``He loved to fly,'' she said. ``That was what he always wanted to do.''
(Staff writers Andrew Backover and Dan Reed contributed to this report.)

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-CRASH-PILOT-LADN FATHER SAYS VALUJET PILOT HAD LIFELONG LOVE OF PLANES (For use by NYTimes News Service clients) By STEVE GETZUG c.1996 Los Angeles Daily News

TEXT.p: LOS ANGELES A;N;D;MD; Hugh Chamberlin never had any worries about his daughter's well-being while she piloted commercial jets.
Candalyn ``Candi'' Kubeck, her father said Monday, was an experienced aviator who turned a childhood love for airplanes into a career that won her family's admiration.

``She was such a careful pilot, which is why I think it was the equipment on Flight 592,'' said Chamberlin, a resident of the Encino section of Los Angeles. ``I think that something electrical probably flooded the cockpit with toxic fumes ... Nothing could be done.''

Kubeck, believed to be the first woman commercial jetliner captain to die in a U.S. crash, was among 104 passengers and five crew members killed Saturday when her ValuJet plane crashed into the Florida Everglades.
The Atlanta-bound DC-9 crashed shortly after takeoff from Miami. The crew radioed urgently about smoke in the cockpit and cabin before the tower lost contact.
The crash and Kubeck's death has left her family devastated.

Kubeck, who first entered a major airline cockpit in 1989, turned 35 Friday. Chamberlin said he and his wife, Joan, had planned to take their daughter to see ``Beauty and the Beast'' in Los Angeles on Wednesday to celebrate.
``We were overwhelmed by this event, this tragedy,'' Chamberlin said. ``She loved to fly. She expressed so much intelligence and so much love. Those are the things that will be with us.''
Kubeck's husband, Roger Kubeck, is a pilot with American West Airlines.

Family members say Candi Kubeck was captivated by the military aircraft she saw in the skies while growing up in Southern California. She hoped to fly, just like her grandfather who flew biplanes during World War I.
Kubeck studied at the Berkeley Hall School in Bel-Air and Palomar College near San Marcos.
She graduated from Metropolitan State College in Denver, where she studied aviation and competed in a flight team that challenged teams from the Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs.

She began her career as a pilot instructor at small airfields and working at various commuter and freight airlines. Her career breakthrough came in 1989, when she crossed the picket lines at Eastern Airlines.

Chamberlin, a management consultant, said the airlines' training facilities were among the best in the industry, and his daughter learned to fly some of the nation's largest and most modern jets, including Eastern's biggest plane, the Airbus 300.
She was hired in 1993 at ValuJet.
Chamberlin said his daughter never expressed safety concerns at ValuJet, but recalled Kubeck noting that some of the fleet had reached a ``pretty senior age.''
He said she was excited about the company's recent orders for new planes from the McDonnell Douglas Corp.
The ValuJet DC-9 that crashed Saturday was 27 years old.
Patrice King, who is setting up a scholarship fund in her stepsister's memory, said flying was Kubeck's ``lifelong passion.''
``We feel that the scholarship fund is something that Candi would like to have done, to help others live out her dream,'' King said.
The Kubecks were married for eight years and have no children.

Her family has established the Candi Chamberlin Kubeck Scholarship Fund for Aspiring Young Pilots. Contributions may be sent to King at Home Savings of America, 17107 Ventura Blvd., Encino, Calif. 91316.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-CRASH-FAA-BOS (Eds.: AvAtlantic is cq) FAA SAFETY CHECK WEAKNESSES REPORTED BY PROBERS BEFORE CRASH (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By AARON ZITNER c.1996 The Boston Globe

TEXT.p: WASHINGTON A;N;D;MD; Two weeks before ValuJet Flight 592 carried its 109 passengers to their deaths in the Everglades, federal auditors reported that the Federal Aviation Administration's airplane safety checks lacked some of the basic elements of a common automobile inspection.

Tuesday, as the FAA responded to the ValuJet crash with a plan to hire more inspectors quickly, those same examiners cautioned again that the agency should also change its inspection and training procedures to make the skies safer. Congressional critics echoed their remarks.

During an aircraft check before a flight, FAA inspectors are not required to check vital equipment, such as the landing gear and engine, said Raymond J. DeCarli, an assistant inspector general for the US Department of Transportation. ``Can you imagine taking your car in for an inspection and having the brakes and tires checked 50 percent of the time?'' he asked. ``There's no checklist of what they have to inspect.'' An inspector ``can do virtually nothing and it's considered an inspection.''

DeCarli's spoke as some congressional lawmakers called for more scrutiny of FAA inspection procedures and questioned whether the agency is too cozy with the industry it is assigned to watch. The inspector general's office also said it would investigate reports, first aired by ABC News, that the FAA encouraged inspectors to ``go soft'' on ValuJet.

Lawmakers said the various investigations of ValuJet and the FAA would bring new urgency to a debate over the FAA's structure and funding. Some critics want to strip the FAA of its mission of promoting the US air travel industry, saying it cannot nurture young airlines or aircraft manufacturers and ensure safety at the same time.
DeCarli's comments, made in a phone interview, echoed his testimony before a Senate subcommittee April 30, in which he said that training, personnel-testing and other FAA procedures were inadequate.

For example, DeCarli said the FAA failed to crack down on the use of unapproved parts in airplane repair. Moreover, a study by his office showed that FAA workers checked landing gear in only 48 percent of their preflight plane inspections. They checked the engines 52 percent of the time and engine controls a third of the time.

DeCarli's report was one basis for a Newsweek magazine essay by Mary Fackler Schiavo, inspector general for Transportation, in which she said she has skipped conferences rather than fly on ``marginal airlines.'' She said she avoids flying on ValuJet because of a history of ``mishaps.''
Those comments alarmed lawmakers Tuesday.

Sen. Ron Wyden, a Democrat from Oregon, called it ``troubling'' and ``bizarre situation when the inspector general says they don't feel comfortable flying an airline that is out flying planes and offering its services to the American public.''

At a Senate hearing on the FAA, scheduled long before the ValuJet crash, other lawmakers said they were hesitant to comment on FAA procedures without knowing the cause of the accident. Sen. Ted Stevens, a Republican from Alaska, criticized Schiavo for ``destroying confidence'' in air safety. ``I suggest the president has the right to remove an inspector general for dereliction of duty,'' Stevens said.
White House spokesman Mike McCurry said there was no talk of removing Schiavo from her job.
At the Senate Transportation Committee hearing, top FAA officials said they would take three steps to improve safety:

A;N;D;MD; Speed the hiring of 91 inspectors by the end of June who were due to be hired by October. The agency has already hired 140 inspectors this year and has asked Congress for 150 more in its next budget. It has about 2,500 inspectors.
A;N;D;MD; Speeding up introduction of a system that tracks inspection data and flags dangerous conditions.
A;N;D;MD; Reviewing the work that inspectors do to make sure they focus on top priorities.

Separately, the FAA issued an emergency order Monday suspending flight operations of HCL Aviation Inc.'s AvAtlantic because of ``discrepancies in the training, testing and qualifications of flight attendants.'' AvAtlantic, based in Savannah, Ga., leases planes to the presidential campaign of Sen. Bob Dole, which said it expects no interruption in Dole's travel schedule.
Even before the ValuJet crash, lawmakers had been wrestling with how to improve the FAA. Plans to change the FAA's dual mission could generate the biggest debate in the next few months.

As part of the Clinton administration's efforts to boost US exports, Transportation Secretary Federico Pena and FAA administrator David Hinson have traveled overseas to help sell US-made airplanes. But the FAA is also charged with making sure those planes are safe.
``There is an inherent conflict in those two missions,'' said Sen. William S. Cohen, a Maine Republican.

Hinson, the FAA administrator, said Tuesday that the air system is safe and improving. If the United States had the same accident rate today as in 1960, he said, a fatal air crash would occur every 10 days. ``When we say an airline is safe to fly, it is safe to fly,'' he said. ''There is no gray area.''

At the same time, though, the FAA budget of $8.6 billion is down $600 million from 1993, and the FAA has lost 5,100 workers, a cut of about 10 percent. Anthony J. Broderick, associate administrator of the FAA, said Tuesday that the level of worker training has decreased significantly, ``and quite frankly, I think it's too deep a decrease.'' The agency has requested a 6 percent increase in its training budget for next year.

Complicating matters, the agency has lost $550 million in monthly revenue because Congress, amid the impasse over the federal budget, has not renewed a 20-year-old tax on airplane tickets and cargo. Plans to revive the tax are tangled in a debate over the FAA's structure and a controversial plan to replace the tax with user fees to be paid by airlines. Several big airlines favor user fees, but low-fare carriers say it would force them to raise prices.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-CRASH-CONSUME-COX NERVOUS FLYERS HAS MANY PLACES TO FIND OUT INFORMATION ON AIRLINE FLIGHTS, PLANES EDs: With CRASH-CONTACTBOX; CRASH-MAIN. By MITCH McKENNEY c.1996 Cox News Service

TEXT.p: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. A;N;D;MD; ``I'm traveling next week on a Delta flight with an extemely fearful flier,'' begins the note posted Saturday night in a computer forum on aviation safety.
``The ticket agent told me it was an MD-88 and I was hoping someone here could provide us with a little info about exactly what kind of aircraft that is and what its track record has been.''
Relax, about two dozen people have since told the writer: the planes have an outstanding safety record.
``Tell your friend to expect Delta to provide her with a safe and on-time journey,'' one wrote.

Places like CompuServe's Aviation Safety Interest Group, a longtime gathering point for pilots and aviation buffs A;N;D;MD; and several sites on the Internet A;N;D;MD; can arm you with a lot of information about airplane models, crash records and other data.

But can you find out if the plane you're catching tomorrow has had a lot of maintenance problems? Or whether it's one of the models for which the government, eager to prevent smoky fires, has started requiring new cockpit wiring?
A phone call to the airline can get you the model scheduled for your flight and perhaps the age of the plane, but not much else.

Even if you can extract the plane's tail number from a customer service agent, searching aviation databases ``is not for someone who doesn't have a lot of patience,'' said Mike Overly (CQ) , research director for the Aviation Safety Institute in Columbus, Ohio.
And once you had the records and are reassured your plane's in fine shape, you could find the airline had to make a substitution.
A USAir spokesman said a daily flight from West Palm Beach to Charlotte, for example, could get any of the airline's 34 757s, depending on weather delays, scheduled maintenance and other factors.

``The airline usually will fly the same type of plane,'' said Steve Loucks, spokesman for the American Society of Travel Agents. ``But there's no real way to pinpoint which piece of aircraft you'll be traveling on.''
If you're seeking information on the model, as the woman curious about the MD-88 was, several sites on the World Wide Web can help.

The Federal Aviation Administration is a good starting point, with the FAA's weekly summary of airport and airline incidents, known as service difficulty reports, and equipment notices called airworthiness directives.

And Internet news groups and aviation forums such as CompuServe's can offer useful advice, such as thinking of turbulence ``like the wake from a boat'' and comparing changes in engine pitch with the sounds a Greyhound bus moter makes while climbing and descending hills.
(Story Filed By The Palm Beach Post, West Palm Beach, Fla.)

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-FLA-AIRCRASH-NYT INVESTIGATORS BEGIN EXAMINING DATA FROM VALUJET'S `BLACK BOX' (With FLA-AIRCRASH-SAFETY, FLA-AIRCRASH-SEARCH) (sw) By MATTHEW L. WALD c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: MIAMI A;N;D;MD; Crash investigators on Tuesday began analyzing technical information from the single ``black box'' recovered so far from the Valujet DC-9 that crashed near here on Saturday and began reassembling parts of the plane in a hangar at a small airport nearby.

Investigators are still searching for the second black box. In addition, they are trying to figure out how to pull the wreckage from the main crater the plane made in the mud under the shallow water of the Everglades. They met here on Tuesday to work on that problem with the Army Corps of Engineers, the U.S. Navy, Florida officials and private engineering companies. The crater is about 130 feet long and 40 to 50 feet wide; no one knows its depth.

In Washington the secretary of transportation, Federico Pena, reported to President Clinton on steps the Federal Aviation Administration would take ``to insure that the nation's civil aviation system remains the safest in the world.''

He said the FAA would accelerate an existing plan to hire more inspectors and would work harder to track the status of problems its inspectors uncover. For years the agency has been criticized by auditors from the Transportation Department and Congress for what they call sloppy record keeping that makes it harder to spot dangerous trends and for the agency's inspection procedures.

But whether the steps Pena discussed would have prevented the crash is unclear because no one yet knows why the cockpit and cabin filled with smoke and the plane crashed, killing all 109 people aboard.

At the crash scene, about 12 miles west of the Miami metropolitan area, the searchers have been working shoulder-to-shoulder in a carefully organized grid. Dressed in special protective suits and slogging through several feet of water and subsurface muck, they have been able to work only 20 to 30 minutes at a time in the 90-degree weather before coming out to rest, cool off and be decontaminated from the jet fuel and possible pathogens in the human remains in the water.

Robert Francis, the vice chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, said at a mid-day briefing that most of the plane parts found had originally been in the tail of the jet, but, like the human remains, had been discovered south of the main crater, farther along the route of flight. The tail is where both of the black boxes were situated.

The box that has been found was the flight-data recorder, which collects information on altitude, heading, speed, horizontal and vertical acceleration and engine function. Francis said that the box was dented but that its magnetic tapes had recorded ``good data.''

But the box will not provide information on many individual parts of the plane, and reading its information will be a little like watching an opera in a foreign language, providing only a gross approximation of what happened.

On the other hand, the other box, the cockpit voice recorder, could contain ``a magic bullet,'' a statement by the captain or first officer that would make clear what happened, said one safety board official. People at the safety board said they could not remember a case in which one box had been recovered but the other had not.

Francis also spoke about the reassembly of the plane in a hangar nearby. In crash investigations, engineers often lay out on the floor of a hangar the mechanical pieces of the plane they recover. This helps them keep track of what has been found, what is missing and how the plane has been damaged. In this inquiry, not enough parts have yet been found to draw conclusions, Francis said.
Of the aircraft parts found so far, none shows obvious signs of fire or smoke, searchers said. The co-pilot of the plane reported smoke in the cockpit and cabin shortly before the crash.

Searchers have not found the air-conditioning packs, which are devices powered by the jet engines that pressurize air for the cabin and are one possible source of smoke. But there are many other potential sources of smoke, experts say, including electrical wiring. Francis said some wiring had been found and would be closely scrutinized.

Wiring in old planes like this one, built in 1969, has long been a concern, and in Washington, the FAA said on Tuesday that a new rule would take effect on Wednesday to require that DC-9's and other planes made by the McDonnell Douglas Corp. be inspected for chafed wiring in the cockpit. On some planes, but not DC-9's, that condition has caused smoke.

As salvage operations proceed, investigators will also be looking for circuit breakers for the fuel pumps. A malfunction in these circuit breakers caused a lengthy delay in Atlanta, before the plane took off for Miami in its last successful flight. There is no immediate indication that this problem had any relationship to the crash when it took off for the return trip to Atlanta.

The FAA on Tuesday continued to defer questions on the crash to the safety board, an independent agency that takes charge of plane accident investigations. The crash is a blow for the aviation administration, which early this year identified Valujet as requiring additional attention and blitzed the young airline with hundreds of inspections in a one-week period in February. FAA officials say they found no violations significant enough to require enforcement action, but they did make numerous suggestions, to which, they said, the airline voluntarily responded.

Mary Schiavo, the inspector general of the Department of Transportation, which is the parent agency of the FAA, said today that she would look into whether the investigators had been too easy on the airline.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-VALUJET-FAA-BLOOM U.S. AIRLINE REGULATOR ANNOUNCES `INTENSIVE' REVIEW OF VALUJET (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By Jeff Vinson c.1996 Bloomberg Business News

TEXT.p: Washington, May 15 (Bloomberg) -- The Federal Aviation Administration said it is launching an ``intensive 30-day review'' of ValuJet Airlines operations following the crash of the discount airline's Flight 592 Saturday in the Everglades, which killed 109 people.
FAA administrator David Hinson, who announced the review at a news conference this morning, said the agency still considers ValuJet ``safe to fly.''
``The additional inspections we are doing are additional safety margins and should be viewed as such.''
Tony Broderick, the FAA's associate administrator for regulation and certification, said the review would involve ``five specific steps'' in which the agency would:
-- Review all reports of mechanical problems filed within the past 12 months to insure they have been corrected.
-- Inspect all aircraft the morning after they have undergone overnight repairs.

-- Put FAA inspectors on every ValuJet plane for weekly in-flight inspections. ValuJet has ``at least 350 flights weekly and we'd like them on as many as possible,'' Broderick said of the FAA inspectors.
-- Reinspect all of ValuJet's maintenance stations at operations centers away from the airline's main repair facilities.
-- Conduct ``top to bottom inspections'' of every ValuJet plane that has undergone heavy maintenance.
ValuJet Flight 592 crashed as the pilot and first officer were attempting an emergency landing of the 27-year-old, McDonnell Douglas-built DC-9 jetliner back to Mi
QIreporting smoke in the cockpit and passenger cabin.

Last night, the National Transportation Safety Board, which is directing the accident investigation, said an explosion could have torn through the jetliner, triggering a sudden loss of speed and altitude.
A flight recorder recovered by police divers Monday indicated the DC-9 had a flight ``anomaly'' 3 1/2 minutes before the crash, Robert Francis, NTSB vice chairman, said in Miami.
Additionally, two parts of the plane were discovered, marked with ``apparent soot,'' and that suggested ``there could have been an explosion,'' Francis said.

While no cause has been pinpointed, accident investigators were studying the possibility that the blast may have been related to 50-60 surplus aircraft oxygen generators shipped in the aircraft's cargo hold.
The generators, which had exceeded their shelf life, were being shipped to ValuJet's headquarters in Atlanta.
It wasn't immediately clear last night whether shipping the generators was contrary to government regulations.
Hinson declined to answer a question on that point, although he did say that ``some hazardous material is allowed on airplanes under proper circumstances.''
In trading today, ValuJet shares were at 14 5/8, down 3/8. Shares had fallen as much as 27 percent on Monday, the first trading session after the crash, to 11 3/4.

Following the crash, the FAA expanded a 120-day investigation of ValuJet's flight operations, training and maintenance procedures. The inquiry was prompted by several mishaps, including a fire last year that destroyed a ValuJet DC-9 on a runway in Atlanta and injured several people.

The airline has one of the oldest jet fleets in the sky, and has drawn criticism from the inspector general of the Transportation Department, Mary Schiavo. However, ValuJet President Lewis Jordan has defended the airline's safety standards, saying: ``We cannot put too much emphasis on safety --ever.''

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-CRASH-CHICAG-COX 1986 COMMERCIAL FLIGHT EXPERIENCED SIMILAR FIRE, EXPLOSION TO VALUJET PLANE EDs: With CRASH-MAIN. By SIOBHAN MORRISSEY c.1996 Cox News Service

TEXT.p: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. A;N;D;MD; Half an hour after a mechanic jostled an oxygen-generating canister aboard a grounded McDonnell Douglas DC-10, the airplane began smoldering and then erupted into flames.

Although no one was injured, flames destroyed the American Trans Air jetliner shortly after it arrived from Honolulu on Aug. 10, 1986. A decade later, National Transportation Safety Board investigators are exploring whether a similar fire could have caused ValuJet 592 to crash into the Everglades, killing all 110 (CQ) people on board.

ValuJet's cargo manifest listed five crates containing 50 to 60 of the stainless steel canisters that produce oxygen for emergency masks. The devices were stowed near three inflated aircraft spare tires.
Robert Francis, the board's vice chairman, said the oxygen generators may have exploded in the forward cargo hold.

Such an explosion could account for why the air speed and altimeter registered information that conflicted with radar reports of how fast and how high the plane was traveling, chief investigator Gregory Feith said.

Similarly, the aircraft tires pose a potential problem for in-air explosion. Former safety board chairman Jim Burnett described the aircraft tires as ``very dangerous to be around because they are under very high pressure A;N;D;MD; if you are around one when it blows it can kill you.''

Sometimes tires that are part of the landing gear explode while in flight but they do not damage the aircraft because a special shield in the wheel well protects the aircraft, Burnett said. However, the cargo hold lacks such shielding, he said.
``I've heard of tires exploding in the wheel well, but never ran across the issue of them being transported in the cargo,'' he said. ``I rather suspect that's because they don't do it.''
Other safety board officials registered concern about proper use of oxygen generating systems as early as 1976.
``The potential for serious injuries and fatalities is great,'' an NTSB report said then, noting recurring problems with the systems that chemically generate oxygen on DC-10s and Lockheed 1011s.
The Department of Transportation classifies the oxygen generators as hazardous materials when carried as company material in cargo compartments. They should be packaged and stowed securely.

Just as in the ValuJet case, oxygen generators were stowed in the forward cargo compartment of the American Trans Air plane what was demolished in the Chicago fire 10 years ago. An American Trans Air mechanic apparently set off the fire that destroyed the DC-10 while attempting to fix an oxygen compartment door that would not close.

``He found a loose oxygen canister and handled it improperly by its oxygen hose,'' according to a safety board account of the fire. That released the firing pin, which in turn fired the percussion cap and triggered a chemical reaction that generated oxygen.

Improper handling of the oxygen generating canisters -- such as inadvertently releasing the firing pin -- can trigger a chemical reaction and generate oxygen, which generates heat up to 430 degrees outside the canister. That's hot enough to explode hydrogen and automatically inflate air bags in vehicle fires. Volcanic eruptions that throw off ash and steam reach just over 400 degrees.

The fire aboard American Trans Air began shortly after the aircraft completed a flight from Honolulu. The passengers and crew had deplaned the cleaning crew entered, noting the cabin was initially cold and grew ``uncomfortably hot'' within minutes. Within the next 30 minutes gray smoke began billowing in the passenger cabin, forcing the cleaning crew to evacuate.
``The smoke grew darker and rapidly intensified,'' according to a safety board account of the fire.
The cabin then burst into fire, destroying the entire aircraft. The fire ignited seat covers, burned through the cabin floor and spread throughout the entire cabin.

After the fire investigators tested a similar oxygen canister to determine whether it could generate enough heat to cause the fire. They wrapped the canister in a paper laboratory coat and pulled the canister's pin. The coat ignited and burned.
(Story Filed By The Palm Beach Post, West Palm Beach, Fla.)

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-FLA-AIRCRASH-ART-NYT CLERK'S MISTAKE MAY HAVE PUT VOLATILE CHEMICALS ON VALUJET PLANE (ART ADV.: a graphic for use with this story is being sent to NYT graphics clients. Non-subscribers may make individual purchase by calling 212 556-4204.) (HLW) By MATTHEW L. WALD c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: MIAMI A;N;D;MD; Valujet Flight 592, which crashed here on Saturday apparently after an explosion and fire on board, may have been carrying highly reactive chemicals because an inexperienced shipping clerk did not recognize them as hazardous materials, according to people involved in the investigation.

The chemicals were in canisters called oxygen generators, which are used to supply emergency masks with oxygen. A maintenance contractor had removed the canisters from another Valujet plane at the airline's request and delivered them back to Valujet. An employee of the contractor packed the canisters in boxes and labeled the boxes ``empty,'' a notation that ordinarily would refer to the canisters, not the boxes.

Investigators now believe that the canisters may have been full and consider them a leading suspect in the crash. Even if the canisters were empty, they still might have required more secure packaging, according to aviation experts.

Kenneth P. Quinn, a spokesman for the maintenance contractor, SabreTech, said: ``It is unclear whether the employee knew that the substance in the canisters constituted a hazardous material, and if so, whether the material had been discharged.''

Quinn said that the cannisters, 50 to 60 in all, in five cardboard boxes, ``were returned to Valujet for appropriate disposal.'' He said a shipping tag on the boxes had two notations: ``empty'' and ``customer furnished material returned per customer instructions.'' Quinn said his company was now investigating whether the canisters were still full.
It is standard practice in the industry for such canisters, when carried as cargo, to be emptied and packed in strong, airtight boxes.

The chief accident investigator, Gregory Feith, said at a mid-day briefing near the scene of the accident: ``We don't know what experience the people that were handling these canisters had.'' He added: ``If you pick up a one pound canister and somebody says they're off an airplane, they're old, that may have been interpreted by some to mean something else.''
He said: ``There's a terminology problem here that we need to clarify.''
Feith added: ``We're going to try to identify who actually handled it, what they saw, what they used to make the evaluation as to whether they are actually full or not full.''

The canisters are not used on DC-9s, the kind of the plane that crashed. They are used on MD-80s, which Valujet also flies, to make oxygen for passenger emergency masks. They make oxygen with a chemical reaction that generates tremendous heat but is safe when the canisters are installed in a seatback or overhead compartment.

The National Transportation Safety Board has found strong evidence of fire and explosion on the plane, and has found paperwork on the ground indicating that the oxygen generators were on board. It has not suggested a mechanism by which a generator or generators became activated, though, and it is still looking at wiring and other possible sources of explosion or fire.

SabreTech said in a statement on Thursday: ``We agree with Lewis Jordan, president of Valujet, that it is premature and irresponsible to engage in speculation over the probable cause of this tragic accident. We are cooperating fully with the FAA and NTSB.''

Thus far, none of the generators has been recovered. The safety board hopes to find some in the muck of the Everglades where the plane crashed and check their serial numbers against maintenance records to determine definitively if they were still potent when shipped.

Also on Thursday, Feith contradicted the Federal Aviation Administration and said that Valujet could legally have carried the generators even though it has chosen not to carry hazardous materials for others and has not developed the procedures and trained the personnel as required by the FAA for such work.

On Wednesday, senior officials of the FAA, who refused to be publicly named, said that if the airline was not authorized to handle hazardous materials, then it could not carry the oxygen generators even if they were what the industry calls ``company materials.''

Feith said: ``There are provisions that allow Valujet to ship hazardous material that is necessary for company business.'' He said: ``This discussion needs to be expanded to find out if in fact this was being done for company business, and then what regulations and requirements does Valujet have to follow when shipping hazardous materials for their own benefit.''

Investigators have recovered the flight data recorder, one of the plane's ``black boxes,'' and found signs on it consistent with an explosion on board. They have also found soot-covered wreckage. In addition, before the plane crashed, the co-pilot reported to the ground that the cockpit and cabin were filling with smoke. A possible source of that smoke, according to investigators, was three aircraft tires from an MD-80, carried with the generators in the forward cargo compartment.

On Thursday, searchers used a heavy-duty helicopter to lift major pieces of the wreckage out of the Everglades, including two tires, two major landing gear pieces, some pieces of wing and fuselage, and ``a piece that looks like it's from the rear cargo bay,'' said Robert Francis, vice chairman of the safety board. Investigators are not sure whether the tires were cargo or in use on the plane. Searchers have also recovered both engines, Francis said.

Illustrating the difficulty of recovery, he said that the helicopter pulled at one engine with a force of 4,000 pounds before freeing it from the muck; once airborne, it weighed less than 3,000, he said.

For the last two days, Francis has been wearing a small green ribbon marked ``Valujet Flight 592, May 11, 1996.'' The ribbons were given to dozens of relatives of the victims who have arrived here to await recovery of body parts.
Searchers have not found the cockpit voice recorder, which investigators badly want.

Support organizations, including the Salvation Army and the Fire Department, plan now to be at the scene at least three to four more weeks; the Salvation Army said it was serving about 1,800 meals a day.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-VALUJET-CRASH-ART-NYT (Fla., Ga. ATTN) MORE EVIDENCE POINTS TO OXYGEN DEVICES (With VALUJET-SAFETY) (ART ADV: Graphic on airline accident rates has been sent to NYT graphic clients. Non-subscribers can make individual purchase by calling 212-556-4204 or -1927.) (th) By MATTHEW L. WALD c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: WASHINGTON A;N;D;MD; Federal crash investigators said Sunday that they had found a partly burned aircraft tire that was carried as cargo by the Valujet DC-9 that crashed near Miami on May 11, a likely source of the smoke that the co-pilot urgently reported just before the crash. Embedded in the tire, the investigators said, were parts from at least one oxygen generator, a device that can generate tremendous heat.
The discovery adds substantial weight to a leading theory in the crash, that one or more generators, which were being carried as cargo on the flight, somehow activated and ignited the tire.

But the National Transportation Safety Board, following its standard practice, will take months before it formally establishes what caused the crash, which killed all 110 people aboard when it slammed into the Everglades a few minutes after takeoff from Miami International Airport, bound for Atlanta.

The investigator in charge, Gregory Feith, said at a briefing near the crash site that the safety board's staff had determined through interviews of ground personnel that there were 119 of the generators on board, double what had previously been suspected, and that some were stacked on top of one of three tires in the forward cargo hold.

He said the generators, which are each a little bigger than a coffee thermos, were in cardboard boxes. When carried as cargo they are supposed to be in air-tight containers, and standard airline practice is to transport them only after they have been activated and allowed to run through their chemical reaction, thus eliminating the possibility that they will produce heat, which can start fires, and oxygen, which feeds fires, while in a cargo hold.

But there is strong suspicion that at least some of the generators were still potent. They had been removed three months earlier from three other Valujet aircraft, MD-80s being refurbished for Valujet, and were being returned to the airline by a maintenance contractor.
On MD-80s the generators are used to provide oxygen to passenger emergency masks, but because the chemicals they use can deteriorate, each is given an expiration date, and these had expired.

Feith said Sunday that Valujet personnel put them aboard the DC-9 for shipment to Atlanta, where the airline has its headquarters. The distinction may be important because Sabertech, the maintenance contractor, contends that whether or not the generators were hazardous cargo, the airline is responsible for figuring out what it is loading on its planes.
Valujet officials assert that before the airline put the boxes aboard the flight, 592, its personnel saw that the labels on the boxes described the generators as empty.

Valujet and Sabertech have already begun pointing fingers at each other, and may eventually do so in court. While the safety board does not fix blame for accidents, Feith has repeatedly used a legal term in describing one of the chief areas of inquiry: what the board wants to know about the oxygen generators, he said, is the ``chain of custody.''

The investigators have a lot of other work to do. Many soot-covered parts have been discovered, and laboratory technicians will examine the soot to see if it is from rubber or from electrical wiring, which is another suspect in the crash.

Feith said that the oxygen generators and the tires were ``a main focus'' of the investigation, but that it was still too soon to draw conclusions. ``We have 90 percent of an airplane that is unaccountable,'' he said, noting that most of it is still under water or buried in mud.

Most of the plane's parts have been found by police officers wading through the area or by pairs of searchers who lash two airboats together, about three feet apart, and reach down between them with their hands, pulling up whatever they find.
Investigators have begun using special radar that can see through the mud, and hope to find the cockpit voice recorder.

To look at the main crater dug by the plane when it crashed, they recently received special diving suits that are designed for use with hazardous materials. But then they found that the airboats from which they have been working are too small to carry all the required diving equipment. The investigators hope to begin the dives on Tuesday morning.
Feith said that investigators had finished reviewing the maintenance records of the plane and that ``the paperwork was in order from what they could see.''

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-VALUJET-NTSB-REPEAT-BLOOM SABRETECH SAYS IT DELIVERED MISLABELED BOX TO VALUJET (REPEAT) (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By Jeff Vinson c.1996 Bloomberg Business News (Repeats story that moved late yesterday; adds comments from Quinn in paragraphs 3-4) Atlanta, May 20 (Bloomberg) -- SabreTech has opened an ``exhaustive investigation'' into why its employees delivered to ValuJet Inc. a box of oxygen generators marked as ``empty,'' said a spokesman for the Miami aircraft repair facility.

TEXT.p: ``We acknowledge that SabreTech delivered to ValuJet boxes containing the canisters with a shipping ticket marked as`empty','' said Dave Reddick, a spokesman for shipper's parent company. ``We're certainly concerned about this.''
