Kenneth P. Quinn, a SabreTech spokesman in Miami, said late yesterday that his company, ``consistent with past practice,'' returned ValuJet materials to the airline for ``appropriate disposal.''
``ValuJet made an independent decision to ship their company materials on board an aircraft, and apparently did not ensure that they were properly labeled, packaged and stored,'' Quinn said.
ValuJet officials said the airline wasn't informed that cargo flight 592 was hazardous.

Hazardous materials experts investigating the May 11 crash of the discount carrier's DC-9 in Florida's Everglades earlier this month found evidence that exploding oxygen canisters in the cargo hold may have caused the accident, which killed 110 people.

The National Transportation Safety Board reported that divers found metal fragments from oxygen canisters that apparently exploded and burned before the plane crashed. Five boxes of oxygen generators were presented for shipment to Atlanta from Miami by non-ValuJet employees, and someone filled out the ticket to read: ``5 boxes, oxy canisters empty,'' ValuJet said in a statement. The shipment was delivered to ValuJet in boxes without the federally required hazardous material labeling or any other indication of the hazardous goods within, ValuJet said. SabreTech removed the expired canisters from three ValuJet MD-80 aircraft, the NTSB said. Two or three months later, a SabreTech official ordered them returned to ValuJet. Consistent with ValuJet's statement, NTSB lead investigator Gregory Feith said the boxes were marked as company material, the shipping manifest said the canisters were ``empty.''

About 119 oxygen canisters were in the cargo hold, more than double the amount originally thought, Feith said. No plastic safety caps were used to cover the firing mechanisms on the canisters, he said. ``We're cooperating fully with the NTSB, the FAA and Department'' to find out why the box was mislabeled, Reddick said.

Sabreliner, a St. Louis-based company that specializes in engine overhaul and structural modification of government and civilian aircraft, purchased SabreTech, formerly known as DynAire, last year, Reddick said. He said this is the first time an incident like this has happened at SabreTech. ``We are very proud of our very good safety record, and we're doing everything possible to check to see that the proper procedures are followed,'' Reddick said. On Sunday, ValuJet President Lewis Jordan ask Americans to wait for the results of the federal probe before abandoning the troubled airline.

``We think it would be a tragedy for the American people who can't afford high fares to not have ValuJet around,'' Jordan on ABC TV's ``This Week with David Brinkley.'' ValuJet, based in Atlanta, cut its number of daily flights in half during a special Federal Aviation Administration safety inspection of its 51 planes. The FAA has launched an ``intensive review'' of the airline, which follows a special 120-day investigation that started last February after a string of safety-related incidents.
In trading today, ValuJet shares closed at 11 1/4, down 1 7/8, the most active issue. ValuJet shares have fallen more than 27 percent since the crash.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-VALUJET-CORRECT-BLOOM VALUJET SHARES RISE AS SABRETECH ADMITS MISLABELING (CORRECT) (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By Adam Levy and Carrick Mollenkamp c.1996 Bloomberg Business News (Corrects to say that SabreTech is an aircraft maintenance company, not a shipping company.)

TEXT.p: Atlanta, May 21 (Bloomberg) -- ValuJet Inc. shares ended a five-day slide after an aircraft maintenance company said it mislabeled as empty a box of oxygen generators that may have caused last week's plane crash that killed 110.
Shares in the no-frills airline rose 1 7/8, or 17 percent, to 13 1/8 in trading of 6.8 million shares, making it the fifth most-active U.S. stock.
Despite the rebound, Valujet shares are still down 27 percent from May 10, the day before Flight 592 crashed in the Florida Everglades.
The maintenance company's admission won't completely repair ValuJet's reputation with travelers, investors and analysts said.

``ValuJet's got to convince the public that its 27-year-old planes are OK to fly,'' said John Cabell, co-manager of the USAA Aggressive Growth Fund, which owns 150,000 shares of the airline's stock. ``There's still a nagging credibility problem.''
Attorneys also said the admission by Miami-based SabreTech, the aircraft maintenance firm, doesn't eliminate ValuJet's legal liability in the crash.
ValuJet bonds traded as high as 85 cents on the dollar today, little changed from yesterday's close of 85.25.
ValuJet also acknowledged today that co-founder Timothy Flynn sold 25 percent of his stake in the airline nine days after the ValuJet crash to satisfy a margin call.

SabreTech, a unit of closely held Sabreliner Corp. of St. Louis, said yesterday that five boxes containing 119 oxygen generators were delivered to Atlanta-based ValuJet without federally required labels identifying them as hazardous.
Investigators found evidence that an explosion of one or more of the canisters in the plane's cargo hold may have triggered the crash.
Showing that the canisters were mislabeled isn't enough to convince consumers that the airline is safe, analysts said.

``That's just one issue out of many that has been raised about ValuJet since the crash,'' said Vivian Lee, an analyst at BT Securities. ``Until there are more definitive answers, it's too soon to guess about the company's future.''

ValuJet has spent most of the year under intense regulatory scrutiny after the airline had five minor accidents, including a fire in one plane. Its planes had 11 serious mechanical problems that disrupted flights in the last two years.

Also, it has been widely reported since the crash that ValuJet has the oldest fleet of any U.S. airline. Avitas Inc., a consulting firm, says ValuJet's planes average 26.4 years old. Kiwi International Airlines has the second-oldest fleet with jets averaging 22.8 years.
The ValuJet DC-9 that crashed was 27 years old.
ValuJet's liability in connection with the crash is likely to be diminished, but not eliminated by SabreTech's admission, attorneys said.

``This won't get ValuJet off the hook, but it may give them a co-defendant,'' said Lee Kreindler of Kreindler A;N;D;AMP; Kreindler in New York, whose firm represents plaintiffs in airline crash cases.

ValuJet was obligated to open the crate of oxygen canisters and inspect at least some to determine whether they were empty, said William Wimsatt, a partner at Los Angeles-based Magana, Cathcart A;N;D;AMP; McCarthy, a law firm specializing in aviation law.
``It certainly could be expected that ValuJet wouldn't rely on what someone told them about a potentially hazardous product that would be put on their airplane,'' Wimsatt said.
ValuJet has $750 million liability insurance to cover the crash.
Oxygen generators, if full, are considered hazardous materials and aren't supposed to be shipped aboard commercial flights, the Federal Aviation Administration has said.

``We acknowledge that SabreTech delivered to ValuJet boxes containing the canisters with a shipping ticket marked as `empty','' Dave Reddick, a spokesman for the maintenance company's parent. ``We're certainly concerned about this.''
Still, SabreTech said it doesn't accept responsibility for the crash.

``ValuJet made an independent decision to ship their company materials on board an aircraft, and apparently did not ensure that they were properly labeled, packaged and stored,'' said Kenneth P. Quinn, a SabreTech spokesman.
Standard A;N;D;AMP; Poor's said it's considering lowering the rating of SabreLiner's bonds.
ValuJet co-founder Timothy Flynn sold 25 percent of his stake in the airline nine days after the ValuJet crash.
Flynn, one of four founders of the Atlanta-based airline and a board member, sold 1.5 million shares yesterday, raising $16.9 million. Flynn still owns 4.5 million shares.
Flynn sold the shares to satisfy a margin call, said Gregg Kenyon, ValuJet spokesman. Kenyon declined to say how much margin debt was owed.
A margin call is a broker's demand for additional cash or securities so that an investor can continue to borrow from the broker to buy securities.
The shares Flynn sold -- worth $52 million in November --would have been worth $19.5 million today, with the stock's rebound.
``Probably because of all the publicity, it will take them a year to grow out of this,'' Lewins said.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-AIRLINE-SHIFT-NYT SMALL, LOW-FARE AIRLINES SHAKEN BY VALUJET CRASH (See also VALUJET-CRASH) (sw) By ADAM BRYANT c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: Mark McDonald has weathered almost every storm imaginable since he started Nations Air last year. The small airline, which has served Boston, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh, was shut down for a week last July by the Federal Aviation Administration for a paperwork violation. A few months earlier, a bank pulled its commitment at the last minute to lend him $1 million. A company that leased him a plane took it back in the middle of the night because of a mix-up.
But his airline could not withstand the impact of the Valujet Airlines crash 11 days ago.

Nations Air is halting scheduled service and laying off a third of its staff to go into the charter business, McDonald said. He was forced to make the decision after he saw reservations drop, and drop some more, after the Valujet crash because of travelers' concerns about fledgling airlines like Valujet and Nations Air.

When a plane crashes, the airline that operates it usually sees cancellations and a drop in bookings for anywhere from a week to a few months. But the Valujet crash on May 11 has raised concerns among travelers who have been flying increasingly on smaller and younger airlines, with names that are less well known than American, United and Delta.

Nations Air may be an extreme example, but some other low-fare, smaller airlines said that bookings had dropped since the Valujet crash, and many more said they were fielding questions from scores of anxious travelers about the safety of their aircraft.

Jet Train, an airline that started serving Orlando, Newark, N.J., and Pittsburgh in January, said that although it has had few cancellations, the number of its daily bookings dropped by 30 percent in the days immediately after the Valujet crash. It has also received hundreds of calls from travelers asking questions about the age of its fleet.
``Certainly we have been impacted,'' said Jim Davis, the airline's president. ``But it appears to be returning to near normal levels.''

Other airlines like Tower Air, Reno Air and Kiwi Airlines said that they had also received calls from passengers with questions about their safety records and fleet age, but that they had seen few cancellations. In fact, Kiwi, whose route network overlaps many Valujet routes, has seen bookings rise by about 5 percent since the crash.

Southwest Airlines, another low-fare airline, said it had seen no drop in bookings, and only sporadic safety-related questions from its customers. Southwest is also better known than many start-ups; it is the eighth-largest airline in the country, has been in business 24 years and has never had a crash.

McDonald, of Nations Air, said he felt blindsided. The day after the Valujet crash, McDonald said his bookings dropped 28 percent. On Monday, they dropped another 6 percent. As the week wore on, they remained at 40 percent below earlier levels.

Nations Air, which has never had an incident or accident, was suddenly losing $100,000 a week with no certainty of when business would bounce back. The airline had been hovering around break even. It laid off 46 employees on Tuesday.

``We are not large enough to stand by and burn off that type of money,'' said McDonald, who decided to start flying charter service because it is a more reliable source of income, though it has less potential for profits and rapid growth.
``There's been an erosion of consumer confidence in the industry and you don't know how long it's going to last,'' he said.

Until the Valujet crash, the public confidence in such airlines appeared to have been high. Airlines were being started at a rate not seen since immediately after the industry was deregulated in 1978. Since 1990, about 50 applications have been filed to start new airlines, the Transportation Department said. It is a trend the Transportation Department has applauded, stating recently that such low-cost airlines saved consumers $6.3 billion a year. The FAA has said that the Valujet crash was the first for a jet airline that started after deregulation.
Valujet has set the pace for the growth of such airlines, expanding to 320 flights since it started in October 1993. It said last Friday that it would cut its schedule in half.
Officials of Valujet, which has been highly profitable, are expected to talk on Wednesday with Wall Street analysts who follow the airline industry about the effects of the crash on its finances.

The airline, an unusually strong performer in an industry where profits have long been thin or nonexistent, has been as popular with investors as it was with travelers, with its stock rising quickly in anticipation of profitable growth.

When the stock market opened on the Monday after the crash, shares in Valujet that had been trading at $17.875 immediately lost a third of their value. They have since rebounded somewhat, closing on Tuesday at $13.125, up $1.875 from Monday's close.

However, one investor who recently sold shares in Valujet was also a founder of the airline. Timothy Flynn, one of four founders, sold 1.5 million hares on Monday. But the airline said that Flynn sold the stock to pay off money that he borrowed for investment purposes. Valujet said that Flynn still owned 4.5 million shares of the airline.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-VALUJET-CRASH-NYT COUPLE RECALLS JET'S FLAWS BEFORE CRASH (sw) By ROBYN MEREDITH c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: ATLANTA A;N;D;MD; Just hours before Valujet Flight 592 crashed into the swampy muck, Pamela Hettinger was sitting on the same DC-9, looking out her window high above the Everglades and imagining a similar fate, because she thought the plane was in trouble.
She and her husband, Wayne Hettinger, were aboard the 27-year-old jet's next-to-last flight.

On May 11, the morning of the crash, the Hettingers boarded Valujet Flight 591 in Atlanta, bound for Miami. After a quiet flight, the plane began its descent. Suddenly, she said, the cabin lights went dark and the public address system failed. ``They had to use a bullhorn to tell people to put their seatbelts back on,'' Mrs. Hettinger said. She remembers looking outside then with visions of a plunge to her death.

Within 10 minutes, Flight 591 had landed safely in Miami. But Mrs. Hettinger, who flies four or five times a year and had flown Valujet before without concern, said that she had tried to persuade her husband to leave the plane with her even before they left Atlanta.

She became concerned, she said, after the airplane returned to the gate twice before taking off. ``I know accidents happen, but I just feel like that plane should have never left the ground,'' she said in an interview on Tuesday. Hettinger echoed her account in a separate interview.

The Hettingers' recollections provide the first detailed public description of the mechanical difficulties aboard the aircraft hours before it crashed. While federal investigators are focusing on the possibility that oxygen generators in the cargo hold caused the crash, they have not ruled out other sources of the fire on board, including wiring. Shortly after the crash, a Federal Aviation Administration rule took effect requiring airlines that fly DC-9's to check them for chafed wires in the cockpit.

Other passengers on the Hettingers' flight could not be reached for comment, and safety officials had few details about Flight 591. A Valujet spokesman, Gregg Kenyon, also refused to discuss the flight, saying, ``We are not able to talk about anything that happened with aircraft 904'' after May 9.

But Gregory Feith, the National Transportation Safety Board's lead investigator for the crash that killed 110 people, gave a brief account of Flight 591 at a press conference in Miami several days after the crash.

Before the jet took off from Atlanta ``there was a problem with the circuit breakers'' for the fuel pumps, Feith said, adding: ``A mechanic came on, thought that he had fixed it, and got off. The problem had not been resolved and he got back on. The problem was resolved and the aircraft departed.''

Mrs. Hettinger recalled watching those events from her seat in the second row of the aircraft in front of its left wing. After the jet pulled back from its gate, she said, its lights went out, the public address system stopped working and, moments later, the engines clicked off. The plane restarted and returned to the gate, she said.
A mechanic boarded and went into the cockpit, then the cabin, Mrs. Hettinger said. After he left, the plane again backed away from the gate, Mrs. Hettinger recalled.
Again, the cabin lights went dark and the public address system failed. Flight 591 returned to its gate, and the mechanic reappeared, stayed 15 minutes and left.
``The third time, we took off,'' Mrs. Hettinger said.
The Hettingers learned after boarding a cruise ship in Miami that the plane they had flown had crashed.
``That is when it made me a little weak-kneed,'' Hettinger said, ``because for the life of me I can't see why they ever left again, with all that going on.''

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-FLA-AIRCRASH-NYT VALUJET TAPE HOLDS WARNING OF FIRE TO THE PILOT (HLW) By MICHAEL WINES c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: WASHINGTON A;N;D;MD; The pilots of Valujet Flight 592 were some six minutes into a routine flight out of Miami when someone apparently burst through the cockpit door to warn of a fire in the passenger cabin, according to investigators' first analysis of the tape from the jet's battered cockpit voice recorder.
``There was also an indication from the cabin that there were problems obtaining oxygen,'' Robert Francis, the vice-chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, said at a briefing on Monday.
Beyond that, Francis said, the first review of the recorder disclosed little about the May 11 crash, which killed all 110 crew members and passengers aboard the DC-9.

Francis refused to speculate on the meanings of any of the cockpit exchanges or to say whether the shortage of oxygen referred to breathable air in the cabin or the functioning of the oxygen masks that are supposed to drop automatically from above passengers' seats in emergencies.
He said that he had not personally listened to the recording but that he had been told that it was extraordinarily difficult to decipher and yielded little else on its first playing.

``At this stage, we have not had the opportunity to do enough work on the tape to say how much help it's going to be,'' he said. ``This is not going to be a matter of hours, but of days.'' The recorder was pulled out of the muck of the Florida Everglades crash site and flown to Washington on Sunday.

At the briefing, the safety board displayed the thick aluminum recorder case, roughly the size of a hard-cover book, that held the flight recorder in the jet's tail section. In the center of the case was a deep puncture, evidence of an immense collision between the recorder and something else as the plane hit the ground and disintegrated.
The penetration of the recorder case, which is meant to withstand the worst of crashes, underscored the speed at which the jet plummeted when it fell 7,500 feet into the swamp.
``It required an enormous amount of force, whatever went into it,'' Francis said. ``We were extremely fortunate that we came out with an intact piece of tape.''

The tape did appear to confirm that crew members first found evidence of a fire in the passenger cabin and not the cockpit. Searchers said on Sunday that they had found a passenger seat frame with melted aluminum that pointed to a cabin-area fire.

But federal investigators have said they suspect the fire began in the jet's forward cargo hold, directly below the cabin. A principal theory is that one or more oxygen generators the jet carried in its forward cargo hold accidentally activated.
That would have produced intense heat and could have started an explosion in any of several aircraft tires that were also stored in the hold.
Francis stressed on Monday, however, that experts had not yet settled on a specific explanation and that they would continue to search for clues at the Everglades crash site.

In particular, he said the searchers would look for any parts that helped control the plane's flight and for a set of circuit breakers controlling the fuel pumps, which mechanics had worked on in Atlanta, the plane's last stop before it flew to Miami.

The disclosure that someone had to alert the pilots to the fire also raises the question, perhaps never to be answered, of whether the crash might have been averted had the DC-9 been equipped with smoke detectors in its cargo hold.

The National Transportation Safety Board had recommended before the accident that cargo areas in passenger aircraft be outfitted with fire-detection systems. But the Federal Aviation Administration, which regulates the industry, has not acted on the safety board's advice.

Despite the damage to the flight recorder, safety officials were hopeful of finding more clues to the crash. The tape ``had obviously been subjected to impact and showed signs of that,'' Bernard Loeb, the director of the board's office of aviation safety, said after Monday's briefing. It also had soaked in the brackish water of the Everglades for two weeks.

Even so, Loeb added, ``The tape was in generally good condition.'' The greatest challenge facing the engineers who are trying to pick scraps of conversation from the tape is not its condition, he said, but the background noise from the jet's cockpit.

Loeb said such noise is common on tapes from cockpit recorders, and varies according to the microphones in use in the cockpit at the time. He said he was optimistic that much of the noise could be removed by electronic filters and other means.
The tape is intended to record continuously, saving the most-recent 30 minutes of data, and Francis said a full half-hour of conversation appeared to be on the recording.

He also said there were ``some indications'' of gaps in the recording similar to large gaps that punctuated the tape of the jet's flight data recorder, which stores basic information about the how the aircraft was piloted.

Julie Beal, the safety board's spokesman, said the cockpit recorder had been flown to Washington Sunday evening in a cooler filled with swamp water to maintain the tape in the state in which it had been found.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-MEMORIAL-OHIO-ART-NYT PILOT SHOT DOWN IN WORLD WAR II IS LAID TO REST IN OHIO (ART ADV: Color photo of Chaplain William Johnson conducting memorial service for Frank Gallion has been sent to NYT photo clients. Non-subscribers can make individual purchase by calling 212-556-4204 or 1927.) (sw) By MICHAEL WINERIP c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: MILLERSBURG, Ohio A;N;D;MD; Flight Officer Frank Gallion was buried here near his home in Amish country on Monday, Memorial Day, more than 52 years after his P-47 Thunderbolt fighter plane was downed by German machine gun fire and crashed into the waters of the Zuider Zee.

The 29-year-old pilot was reported missing on Nov. 3, 1943, his body never found. Then last year the propeller of a Dutch dredging ship hit something, and when a diver went down to investigate, there, in 10 feet of water, was the skeleton of Gallion, almost intact, seated in the cockpit of his plane.

On Monday, at precisely 1 p.m. in a pouring rain, an honor guard from Fort Knox, Ky., placed a container smaller than a shoe box holding Gallion's ashes in the back of a long silver hearse. Then a procession of 20 cars snaked past the Holmes County Courthouse and war memorial, which look exactly as they did when Frank Gallion and his brother, Ottmar, were boys swimming in Saps Run Creek, and on past places that those country boys could never have imagined, like the Wal-Mart and Pizza Hut on State Road 83.

As the procession climbed the last hill before Pleasant Grove Cemetery, Maj. David Deckard, the casualty officer who had organized the ceremony, worried that there would be ``more press and Army than mourners.'' But then his car reached the hill's crest, and there, parked along the road to the cemetery, were cars and pickups, Suburbans and minivans as far as the eye could see, and the major was reminded of the strong pull that World War II still holds for Americans.

Of the more than 16 million Americans who served in the military in World War II, the remains of about 78,700 have never been recovered. Each year 10 to 20, like Gallion, are found by farmers in France or the Netherlands or the South Pacific, by workers for water authorities or highway departments.
``Sometimes they'll recover a B-17 or B-29 and we'll get back 8 or 9 in one aircraft,'' said Harold Campbell, the chief of disposition for Army casualty and memorial affairs operations.

Gallion, a member of the 334th Fighter Squadron, had taken off from England that November day in 1943 to escort American B-17 bombers, part of a 500-plane attack force that passed over the Netherlands on its way to a military base in Wilhelmshaven, Germany.

Two weeks later his wife, Phyllis, received a 17-word cable saying that he was missing in action. Notice that he was mia appeared in the Holmes County Farmer-Hub. In August 1945, his mother placed a headstone for Gallion in Pleasant Grove Cemetery, but his only surviving brother, Ottmar, now 78, said on Monday that for years he had wondered whether Frank had been taken prisoner by the Germans and died in a camp.

As the decades passed, family members would periodically make inquiries to Dutch and American officials, with no luck. In 1990, Phyllis Gallion died. She had never remarried, nor had she had children, but had worked much of her life as a hairdresser. Until her mother-in-law's death in the late 1960s, Phyllis would visit her once a year. After that, the Gallion family lost track of her.

In early 1995, came word of the Dutch dredging company's find about a quarter of a mile into the Zuider Zee, 50 miles north of Amsterdam. Gary Gallion, a 43-year-old nephew, said the Dutch were able to identify the uncle by his dog tags and a serial number on the plane. After a ceremony in the Netherlands attended by family members, the remains were flown to the Army's central identification laboratory in Hawaii.

Several weeks ago, Deckard, the casualty officer, drove the ``artifacts'' recovered from the plane to Gary Gallion's home in this village of 3,200. ``It's not pretty stuff,'' the major told the nephew and other family members as he spread the muddy items on top of the kitchen table. ``But it is the facts of your uncle.''

There were scraps of fabric, buttons, a rusted Zippo lighter, a brass compass, a fishing lure that may have been part of a survival kit, a pant cuff and two boot soles marked size 10-E. ``Frank had thick ankles,'' Ottmar Gallion said.

On Monday, before the funeral, people asked what Frank had been like, and Ottmar, who had earned a living as a laborer and salesman, seemed to have trouble remembering so far back. Mainly he spoke of their hiking trips, their swimming together in the creek and their competitiveness. Ottmar Gallion had spent the war guarding German prisoners in Oklahoma and he was asked, if perhaps, Frank, who had gone to Canada in 1941 to join up early, had been the more adventurous brother.
``Oh, I wouldn't say so,'' he replied. ``I was the only one around here who would dive off the bridge into the river.''

At the graveside service on Monday in the pouring rain there were women and children, Vietnam veterans like Jim Buehler, World War II veterans like Francis Emerick and Ted Anielski, Robert Spahr, a villager, who grew up next door to the Gallions and Gallion's only surviving sister, Clela Joy Davis 88, who lives nearby in the Walnut Creek nursing home.
Family members sat in three rows under a tent facing the box of ashes atop a table.

There were several speakers, including an Army chaplain, the minister from the family's Seventh Day Adventist Church and Rep. Ralph Regula, the area's Congressman. Ottmar Gallion spoke for the family. He said there was relief and closure in finding how his brother died.
``It was a clean kill, he was out of his misery and from then on the thing was in God's hands,'' he said.

Many times in recent weeks, Ottmar Gallion had said he wasn't saddened; it was all so long ago. But by the conclusion of his speech on Monday, his voice was barely audible, and when he sat down, he blew his nose.
At the end there was a 21-gun salute, a bugler blowing taps and then First Lt. William J. Duggan III presented Ottmar Gallion with an American flag.
Afterwards, the whole village was invited to American Legion Post 192 in downtown Millersburg. ``They're going to have a nice little spread,'' Deckard said.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-FAA-CRITIC-KAN INSPECTOR MAKES WAVES WITH IDEAS ON AIRLINE SAFETY (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By DAVID GOLDSTEIN c. 1996 Kansas City Star

TEXT.p: WASHINGTON A;N;D;MD; She's been an organized-crime prosecutor in Kansas City, and she's worked in the Reagan White House. She's had a top post in the Labor Department and been featured as one of ``10 outstanding young working women'' in Glamour magazine.
She can even fly a plane and throw her voice.
Mary Fackler Schiavo has skipped from one high-profile job to another like a stone dancing across a pond.
Except now she has made a ripple, and a big one at that.
When ValuJet Flight 592 crashed into the Florida Everglades on May 11, the issue of Newsweek on the stands that Saturday carried a Schiavo column about airline safety.
``I go out of my way to stay off commuter planes,'' she wrote. ``... I would not fly on marginal airlines (and because of its many mishaps, I also avoided flying ValuJet.)''
But this was more than just a personal essay from a trained pilot and frequent flier.
Schiavo, known as Mary Sterling when she lived in Kansas City, is the inspector general for the Department of Transportation. In her words, she is ``helping to police the country's skies.''
More succinctly, she's been one of the most outspoken bureaucrats about aircraft safety, inspections and the problem of faulty parts installed in planes.

Her role as the Cassandra of the airways has put her on opposite sides of others in federal airline regulation. But if Schiavo was a flash point for criticism before her column and the crash, she's now at the center of the controversy.
Her superiors at the Transportation Department, where the party line is always that the government has complete confidence in the airline industry, blanched at her comments.
David Hinson, head of the Federal Aviation Administration, said Schiavo was ``entitled to her opinion.'' Transportation Secretary Federico Pena has assured the public that ValuJet is safe.
Schiavo's critics in the industry say that, while she is smart and aggressive, she is a media hound who has unnecessarily frightened the traveling public.

``I think the FAA needs to increase and enhance its training and pay attention to things like unapproved parts and other issues she has brought to the forefront,'' said Sarah MacLeod, a lawyer and executive director of the Aeronautical Repair Station Association, which represents companies that repair airline parts. ``I agree with her on a lot of her points. I don't agree with how she is going about her job and overstepping her boundaries, and I don't agree with her grabbing headlines.''

Schiavo could not be reached for comment. She has kept quiet since the days immediately following the ValuJet crash, when she was on national television saying that the low-budget carrier's record was under review.
The 40-year-old prosecutor-turned-political appointee became the Transportation Department's inspector general in 1990 after a swift rise in government and political circles.

She grew up on a farm and attended school in a small town outside of Toledo, Ohio, where she was twirling champion. She also taught herself ventriloquism as a hobby, was flying by the age of 10 and became a certified pilot at 18. She earned degrees from Ohio State, Harvard and New York University.

Schiavo joined the U.S. attorney's office in Kansas City in 1982 at age 27. Missouri Court of Appeals Judge Robert G. Ulrich, the U.S. attorney at the time, remembers that her letter of application and resume stood out among the nearly 400 he received during his eight years as prosecutor.
``It was impressive,'' he said. ``... I suspect the way Mary approaches things, she recognizes and determines a goal; then she goes and gets it.''

Schiavo worked for Ulrich for three years and then joined the federal Organized Crime Strike Force for a year. At time she was married to lawyer Ed Sterling, the chairman of the Jackson County Republican Party.

She left Kansas City to become a White House fellow and a special assistant to then-Attorney General Edwin Meese. She returned to Missouri in 1988 to run President Bush's presidential campaign in the state.
Schiavo aggressively sought Ulrich's post when he left, but she didn't make the final cut of three candidates. The U.S. attorney job eventually went to Jean Paul Bradshaw II.

She worked for the McDowell, Rice A;N;D;AMP; Smith law firm for a while but returned to Washington to work for then-Secretary of Labor Elizabeth Dole as an assistant secretary for labor-management standards.
As inspector general at Transportation, she has been credited by many for pushing the FAA to get tough on the problems of faulty parts and for beefing up the criminal dimension of her office.

Aviation Week A;N;D;AMP; Space Technology magazine praised her this year for winning more than 100 convictions in her investigations. Last week the journal complimented her work on ValuJet but also fired a dart.
``She should stick to what she does best,'' the magazine editorialized, ``finding problems, not creating them.''

She also took criticism after she butted heads with a top FAA official, accusing him of blocking one of her investigations. He was cleared by the Justice Department, but the episode painted her in some quarters as someone who acted outside proper channels and was magnetized by the glare of publicity.

The Clinton White House has shown no indications that it plans to take any action against Schiavo, who was appointed in the Bush administration. Among some on Capitol Hill, however, the mood is that of a hunter who suddenly finds prey in his sights.

Sen. Ted Stevens of Alaska, the Republican chairman of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, which has oversight over the inspector generals, was furious at her comments about the safety of commuter planes.

``That's easily 90 percent of the traffic in Alaska,'' said Mitch Rose, a Stevens aide. ``(Stevens) has never been approached by her or been given that impression. He thought her statements were over-broad.''
Stevens' committee plans to review two years' worth of Schiavo's audits and investigative reports to see whether they bear out her Newsweek comments.
MacLeod said Schiavo and everyone involved in the debate over airline safety needed a dose of reality.
``We have the safest airline system in the world,'' she said, ``but life comes with no guarantees.''

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-FLA-CRASH-NYT DC-9 COCKPIT TAPE CONTAINS NOISE SUPPORTING BLAST THEORY (sw) By MATTHEW L. WALD c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: WASHINGTON A;N;D;MD; The cockpit voice recorder of the Valujet Airlines DC-9 that crashed in the Everglades on May 11 recorded ``a brief unidentified sound'' less than six minutes after takeoff, and almost immediately, the captain ``stated the need to go back to Miami,'' National Transportation Safety Board investigators said on Thursday evening.

The investigators' brief statement does not say what the sound was, and, in fact, refers to it four times on a single page as ``unidentified.'' But a chronology in the statement seems to show that the crew acted properly in response to the noise.

The crash killed all 110 people on board, and investigators found parts of oxygen generators embedded in a fire-damaged tire. Aviation experts said on Thursday evening that a possible source of the sound would be the pop of a spare aircraft tire if it had been heated by a fire in the forward cargo hold. The board has already said that the plane was carrying oxygen generators, which can start fires, and that some of these had been stacked on top of an inflated tire.

The flight data recorder, which has already been analyzed, gives evidence that there might have been an explosion on board. The statement released on Thursday, describing a preliminary analysis of the voice recorder, did not state unequivocally that the sound was related to the crash but gives a partial chronology keyed around that event: The sound occurred about 5 minutes and 47 seconds after takeoff; the captain ``questioned'' the sound; 17 seconds after hearing it, she said the plane, which was still climbing on its way to Atlanta, must return to Miami.

Five seconds later, ``voices were heard from the passenger cabin reporting fire.'' Eleven seconds after that, the co-pilot radioed for clearance to return. The crash occurred about seven minutes later.

The sequence, as described by the investigators, indicates that the crew took prompt action to try to land, which aviation experts say is the most important step pilots can take in the event of a fire. An unresolved question is whether the plane could have landed closer than Miami.

The statement also said ``the aircraft and systems appear normal before the unidentified sound.'' Afterwards, the statement said, there were two apparent interruptions of power to the cockpit voice recorder. The first began 1 minute and 39 seconds after the sound and lasted 1 minute and 17 seconds; the second was just before the end of the tape.

Aviation experts say the reason could be fire damage to the plane's electrical system, or could be the crew, believing that the problem was an electrical fire, turning off various electrical systems. Electrical problems have not been ruled out.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-HAZARD-PULL-COX HISTORY BOX TO GO WITH PBP-HAZARD c. 1996 Cox News Service

TEXT.p: Previous incidents involving the carrying of hazardous air cargo:
NOV. 3, 1973 A;N;D;MD;

Heavy smoke and fumes cause a crash that kills three crewmen and destroys a Pan Am Boeing 707. An improperly packaged container of nitric acid burst into flames in the cargo compartment. The Clipper 160 cargo plane bound from New York's John F. Kennedy Airport to Frankfurt, Germany, crashed during an emergency landing at Boston's Logan Airport. After the crash, the Air Line Pilots Association formally recommended to the Safety Board that ``all hazardous materials be banned from interstate air transportation.''
AUG. 19, 1980 A;N;D;MD;

A cargo compartment fire spreads through a Saudi Arabian Airlines L-1011, killing all 301 people aboard. The pilot was able to successfully land the jet in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. But evacuation attempts failed. Although unable to determine the cause of the fire, the National Transportation Safety Board used the incident to push for better methods for containing fires in cargo holds. The FAA recommended installation of fiberglass ceiling liners in lieu of the standard C-2 Nomex fabric liners used in cargo compartments at the time.
AUG. 10, 1986 A;N;D;MD;

Fire consumes an American Trans Air DC-10 after passenger and crew deplane in Chicago. A jostled oxygen generating canister A;N;D;MD; similar to the ones carried aboard ValuJet Flight 592 A;N;D;MD; set off the fire in the cargo hold.
FEB. 3, 1988 A;N;D;MD;

An American Airlines DC-9 makes an emergency landing in Nashville, forcing 126 passengers and crew to evacuate after chemicals illegally shipped from Austin start a fire in the cargo hold. The floor in the passenger cabin melted and smoke wafted through the cabin. The National Transportation Safety Board called for fire detection and extinguishing equipment in Class D cargo holds. The FAA rejected the recommendation because it would cost more than $350 million to retrofit existing aircraft.
FEB. 1, 1991 A;N;D;MD;

Fire breaks out in the cargo hold of a DC-9 bound from Charlotte to Greensboro, N.C. No one is injured, but an illegal cache of tear gas, volatile liquid dichloromethane, lamp oil, witch hazel and matches are found in the cargo compartment.
AUG. 20, 1993 A;N;D;MD;

A leaking package containing blood tainted with the HIV virus was packed as air freight in Santa Rosa, Calif. Several cargo loaders handled the unmarked package before someone placed it in a clear plastic bag. An inspection revealed the package contained human tissue and blood samples, which laboratory tests revealed were positive for the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), which causes AIDS.
APRIL 6, 1994 A;N;D;MD;

Mercury seeps out of a mail bag during the loading of a McDonnell Douglas DC-9 Super 80 in Houston. The container lacked corrosive and hazmat warning labels. The shipper appeared unaware of proper shipping procedures, claiming he had shipped mercury in the same manner for the past two decades without mishap. Compiled from reports supplied by the National Transportation Safety Board, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Federal Aviation Administration.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-FAA-REGULATE-2TAKES-NYT FAA FACES PROBLEMS IN MONITORING AIRLINE MAINTENANCE PROGRAMS (af) By ADAM BRYANT c. 1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: With the nation's airlines farming out an increasing amount of maintenance work, the Federal Aviation Administration is struggling to monitor an intricate web of contractors that stretches around the world.

Before deregulation of the industry in 1978, airlines did most of their work themselves, making it relatively simple for regulators to examine records and aircraft to insure that procedures were being followed properly.

But now that task is far more complicated than experts predicted even five years ago. United States airlines are trying to save money by hiring companies domestically and overseas for major tasks like overhauling engines, and they are farming out maintenance and critical safety-related work like de-icing to various companies at the many airports they serve.

Federal officials believe that such a misunderstanding may have led to the May 11 crash of a Valujet DC-9 outside Miami. Valujet and its contractor Sabretech, a maintenance company that does work in Miami, are arguing over who was responsible for handling oxygen-generating devices that investigators suspect caused the crash, which killed 110 passengers and crew.

The growing use of outsourcing by both start-up airlines like Valujet and major carriers is not inherently unsafe, experts say, and the FAA has responsibility for authorizing contractors in many foreign countries.
But such relationships do require more supervision. And the FAA has always assigned its front-line inspectors according to an airline's size, not its use of subcontractors.
``The nature of the beast has changed,'' said Daniel M. Kasper, an aviation consultant and a member of a 1993 presidential commission that studied the airline industry.
``While flying remains the safest form of transportation, it raises the question of whether the FAA regulatory model has changed sufficiently to oversee these virtual airlines.''

Valujet could be considered a prime example of a ``virtual airline,'' relying heavily on contractors. Sabretech is one of six companies that Valujet hired to do heavy maintenance, and Valujet has also contracted with more than a dozen other companies, including airlines, to work on its planes at various airports.
Valujet's dispute with Sabretech centers on the oxygen generators, which are small chemical reactors that produce intense heat when activated.

Sabretech, which is an FAA-authorized maintenance company, removed them from Valujet MD-80s because the generators' shelf life had expired and Valujet officials said they told the contractor to dispose of them.

Sabretech said it was given no such order and boxed up the generators, mislabeled them ``Oxy Cannisters, Empty,'' and returned them to Valujet. Valujet then loaded the boxes into the cargo hold of Flight 592.

Internal FAA records show that on several occasions, inspectors were concerned about a lack of oversight by Valujet of its contractors. An inspector found, for instance, that maintenance was not properly documented by one contractor and that Valujet lacked procedures to make sure it was done.

The FAA also found that Valujet did not make sure that companies it hired A;N;D;MD; including other airlines like Northwest and Carnival A;N;D;MD; were properly trained in its procedures. A company that trained Valujet pilots did not send the airline records documenting poor performance of the Valujet employees.
After an engine broke up in a Valujet DC-9 that was about to take off from Atlanta last June, the FAA wrote to Valujet, telling it to develop safeguards against acquiring ``questionable assets.''
The plane was one of nine that Valujet bought from a Turkish airline, which had worked on the faulty engine for a period when its FAA authorization had lapsed.

As part of its closer scrutiny of Valujet after the crash, the FAA said it would conduct new inspections of Valujet's contractors. Valujet has suspended its contract with Sabretech and Valujet officials said they had improved their internal audit system for working with contractors.
Lewis H. Jordan, the airline's president, said the airline had been ``very responsive'' in addressing each of the FAA's concerns.
Other internal reports show that the agency was concerned that its own oversight of Valujet was insufficient.

Its inspection records ``clearly show some weakness in the FAA's surveillance,'' said an internal report released by the agency this month. In addition, the report recommended to top FAA officials that they consider a top-to-bottom check of Valujet, in part because of the ``absence of adequate policies and procedures for the maintenance personnel to follow.''

A separate report described Valujet as an ``unconventional carrier,'' noting that it contracted out all its maintenance to ``geographically diverse low bidders.'' In an interview, Jordan said that cost was not Valujet's only consideration in choosing its contractors.

David R. Hinson, the FAA administrator, said that the widespread use of outsourcing in the industry is ``a relatively young phenomenon'' and creates different challenges of oversight for the agency, compared to when airlines were largely self-contained organizations.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-NY-TERROR-TRIAL-NYT FATAL AIRLINE ATTACK DESCRIBED IN TERROR TRIAL (bl) By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: NEW YORK A;N;D;MD; Prosecutors focused Monday on a deadly midair explosion that Ramzi Yousef is accused of carrying out as a rehearsal for a planned wave of attacks on a dozen American jetliners, a continuation of a terror campaign that the indictment says began with the World Trade Center bombing.

The bomb exploded aboard Philippines Airlines Flight 434, killing one passenger and injuring several others, as the Boeing 747 flew from Cebu in the southern Philippines to Tokyo on Dec. 11, 1994. The pilot, who testified Monday, managed to make an emergency landing in Okinawa after the blast.

Yousef is accused of planting the bomb himself on the first leg of the flight from Manila to Cebu before quietly disembarking. He and the other two defendants are accused of conspiring to replicate that tactic in two days of terror they are said to have planned at airports around Asia to kill several thousand passengers.

But Yousef A;N;D;MD; who has insisted upon conducting his own defense, against the advice of the judge in the case A;N;D;MD; sought to gain some advantage from Monday's testimony, suggesting in his cross-examination of the witnesses that the bomb had been planted by someone else, even one of Philippine Airlines' own maintenance or cleaning workers.

So far, the only witness to place Yousef on the flight from Manila to Cebu has been a Philippine Airlines flight attendant, Maria De La Cruz. She testified Thursday that she had seen him briefly occupy the seat that later exploded. She served him a beverage and snack before he got off in Cebu, she said.

When the trial reconvened Monday morning, the prosecutors, Dietrich L. Snell and Michael J. Garcia, went on to present three witnesses: the jetliner's Filipino captain, a Japanese passenger who was injured in the explosion and a retired Okinawan police officer who supervised the bombing investigation after the aircraft landed at Naha in Okinawa.

Taking the stand, the aircraft's captain, Eduardo Reyes, testified that the sudden explosion had forced his plane, which had nearly 300 passengers on board, to bank sharply to the right. ``It was as if a big rocket exploded right in the room,'' Reyes said. When he took the controls, he had to use force to make a wide turn. ``The plane responded, but very slowly,'' he said.
The captain said he had landed the damaged jumbo jetliner at the Naha airport a half-hour later, after the control tower and another small plane verified that his landing gear was down.

When Yousef cross-examined Reyes, he asked who else, including mechanics and cleaners, had been given access to the plane's interior while it was in Manila and Cebu. He also asked why the flight had departed behind schedule.
``Do you know whether the late arrival of the stairs was deliberate or not?'' Yousef asked.

``No, sir,'' said the captain, who seemed puzzled by the questioning. Yousef asked later whether passengers were required to show passports before boarding. ``That is not my line, sir,'' the pilot said. ``My job is to fly the aircraft.''

The injured passenger, Yukihiko Ususi, said he had been sleeping in the seat behind the passenger who was killed, Haruki Ikegami. When the blast occurred, Ususi said, he thought that the airliner had crashed. Speaking through a Japanese interpreter, Ususi said he had tried to use the oxygen mask dangling above him, ``but then I realized the oxygen mask was burned and was useless.''
Ikegami tried to ask for help and then collapsed, said Ususi, who then discovered that his own legs were ``burned and bloody.'' Ususi said he had looked at Ikegami ``and he looked dead.''

Ususi said he had been hospitalized for 16 days in Okinawa, had surgery twice and spent four more months in his local hospital in Japan. ``My legs occasionally still ache, and also I have a ringing sensation in my ear,'' he said.

In a brief cross-examination of Ususi, Yousef asked whether he was aware of blackmailing and other crimes committed against Japanese businessmen in the Philippines in December 1994. ``I didn't know,'' replied Ususi, looking baffled by the question.

The defendant contends that he was being tortured in a Pakistani prison at the time prosecutors accuse him of being in the Philippines and plotting to blow up 12 American jetliners with his co-defendants, Abdul Hakim Murad and Wali Khan Amin Shah.
The prosecutors say they can prove that Yousef was in the Philippines at that time through Yousef's computer records and fingerprints and other evidence.
Yousef faces a subsequent trial later this year on charges of masterminding the bombing of the World Trade Center in February 1993, an attack that killed six people and injured hundreds.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-WHISTLEBLOWER-COX WHISTLEBLOWER SHIELD: AVIATION WORKERS WANT PROTECTION WHEN THEY REPORT TROUBLE By MACON MOREHOUSE c. 1996 Cox News Service

TEXT.p: ATLANTA A;N;D;MD; Flight attendant Nancy Chagares says when she heard that a ValuJet plane, just deemed unairworthy by a pilot, had taken off with a new crew and passengers, she didn't hesitate to report it to her supervisors.
For her effort, she says, she was forced to resign.
``If you raise questions about anything, by God, they are going to get rid of you,'' she says.
A ValuJet spokesman said the airline investigated Chagares' claims about the incident last New Year's Eve and did not force her out of her job.

But stories like hers have prompted aviation employees to fight for the same protection thousands of other workers have: the freedom to fight back legally if they are punished for blowing the whistle.

A bill pending in Congress would bar airlines and their contractors from discriminating against an employee who reports safety problems. Violations could be reported to the U.S. Department of Labor or, eventually, a federal court.
Supporters say they hope last month's fatal crash of ValuJet Flight 592 helps speed passage of the law. A hearing before a congressional subcommittee could be held as early as July 10.

``On any airline, if there are problems, it's the people working on the planes who will see them,'' said Jill Gallagher, spokeswoman for the Association of Flight Attendants. ``Relying on the workers would be a good thing.''
U.S. Rep. James Clyburn (D-S.C.), who introduced the bill, said the fatal crash of a USAir flight in Charlotte two years ago prompted his concern.
``I take at least four flights a week,'' he said. ``For me to sit there knowing a flight attendant is not on the team making sure I am safe (because of a fear to report problems) is unbelievable.''

ValuJet and Delta, both based in Atlanta, say they do protect employees who report problems and have telephone lines that employees can call anonymously. Both say they encourage employees to talk to their supervisors and do not discipline them for reporting problems.

``It's an open-door policy,'' said ValuJet spokesman Gregg Kenyon. They also may report concerns to the Federal Aviation Administration, but ValuJet prefers that they do not go to the news media, spokeswoman Marcia Scott said.

Valujet flight attendant Anna Wooten said on ABC's ``Nightline'' last month that ``flight attendants are afraid to say anything.'' When the reporter mentioned that she was still working for the airline, she replied, ``Probably won't be after this interview.''
Wooten currently is on maternity leave, Scott said.
Chagares, a former Atlantic Southeast Airlines flight attendant, said her problems began a little more than three weeks after she started working for ValuJet.

She said she was working in the airline's Atlanta operations center Dec. 31 when a pilot came in and told the operations supervisor that his plane needed several days worth of maintenance and he would not fly it.

The pilot was assigned to a different plane, she said, but 15 minutes later ``they boarded up the (first) plane with another crew and they left,'' she said. She said someone asked if that was the same plane that had maintenance problems and the supervisor replied, ``It was the only one they had.''
``I don't know if what was wrong with the airplane was fixed,'' she said. ``If they can do two days' work in 15 minutes, they really are a wonderful airline.''
The next day, she told her supervisor and refused to fly again until she got answers about what happened.

``We took her concerns very seriously,'' ValuJet's Kenyon said. He said the airline investigated but found no records of maintenance problems in the log books. ``We took her concerns very seriously,'' he said. ``We found no discrepancies and nothing wrong with the aircraft.''
He added that Chagares ``was offered various counseling and did not come back.''
Chagares said she was told in early February to start flying or they would assume she didn't want her job anymore.
``Nobody in that company will say anything, nobody,'' she said. ``That's why that whistleblower law is needed so badly.''

While ValuJet's Scott said she was not familiar with the whistleblower legislation, she said, ``Anything that provides the airline and its people with a method of guaranteeing a higher level of safety is great.'' .

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-DRUNK-BOATERS-COX HOUSE VOTES TO KEEP DRUNKEN BOAT, PLANE OPERATORS FROM HIDING BEHIND FEDERAL BANKRUPTCY LAWS By CHRISTI HARLAN c.1996 Cox News Service

TEXT.p: WASHINGTON A;N;D;MD; Seven years ago this month, 22-year-old Deborah Ann Rock died on Lake Austin when she was hit by the bow and propeller of a boat that smashed into the idling boat in which she was sitting.

Rock's parents won a $500,000 award from an Austin, Texas, jury against the pilot of the moving boat, John Greenway. But 3 1/2 years later, the Rocks have yet to collect a penny from Greenway, thanks to the protection of federal bankruptcy law.

That protection should not be available in future cases involving boats and alcohol, the House decided Tuesday. By a voice vote, members of the House closed a loophole in bankruptcy law that shielded drunk pilots of boats and airplanes from liability for accidents that hurt or kill others.

``In the past, watercraft and aircraft operators have had little fear of punishment knowing that this loophole existed,'' said U.S. Rep. Vernon J. Ehlers, R-Mich., the sponsor of the measure. ``With this bill, the federal government will be doing its part to supplement what the states . . . are doing to combat drunk boating and flying.''

Bankruptcy law currently allows debtors to cancel most of their debts, with about a dozen exceptions. Those include federal taxes, student loans and ``any debt for death or personal injury caused by the debtor's operation of a motor vehicle'' while intoxicated by alcohol or drugs.

In at least three cases, including the Rocks' case against Greenway, courts have wrestled with the question of whether boats are ``motor vehicles'' and whether drunk drivers of boats should be shielded from liability.

``I'm just stunned that it's a hard question,'' said Karl O. Bayer Jr. of Austin, the lawyer for two other people who were in the boat in which Rock was killed. ``I didn't even figure it would be a close call.''

But two courts have agreed with Greenway and his lawyers that the 21-foot Supra powerboat he was piloting June 30, 1989, was not a motor vehicle. Those rulings have kept Greenway from having to pay the judgments won by the passengers and pilot of the other boat.

The legislation approved Tuesday will not affect the Rocks' case against Greenway, but the case was one of three cited last November by the House Judiciary Committee when it reported on the need for the legislation changing the bankruptcy law.

The crash occurred on Lake Austin near the Loop 360 bridge as Rock, two other passengers and the pilot sat on an idle 18-foot Maxum powerboat. Greenway's boat hit the Maxum from behind and became airborne, striking and killing Rock and severely injuring another woman passenger.

The wreck happened about an hour before Texas' boating-while-intoxicated law took effect. Greenway, whose blood-alcohol level was between 0.09 and 0.11, was indicted on a misdemeanor charge of criminally negligent homicide and pleaded no contest to the charge in August 1990. He was sentenced to 30 days in jail and fined $1,000.

Greenway, now a lawyer in Austin, sought bankruptcy-court protection shortly after a civil-court jury voted in December 1992 to award $500,000 in damages to Rock's parents and a total of $300,000 to three other people who were on the boat with Rock.

A bankruptcy judge in Austin ruled that Greenway could escape liability for the judgments because a boat is not a motor vehicle as described in bankruptcy law. That ruling was overturned in April 1995 by U.S. District Judge James Nowlin of Austin, who wrote that he could ``see no reason why Congress would have been concerned with drunk driving in one context and not the other.''

Earlier this year, Nowlin's ruling was reversed by the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, which said a boat is not a motor vehicle. The attorneys for Rock's parents, from the Austin firm of Spivey, Grigg, Kelly and Knisely, have asked the U.S. Supreme Court to hear the case.
Greenway, reached at his office, declined to comment.
``There's plenty I'd like to say,'' he said, ``but it's still in court.''

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-NAVY-JOHNSON-ART-500A;N;D;AMP;ADD-NYT LOW-KEY OFFICER IN HIGH-STRESS JOB: ADM. JAY L. JOHNSON (ART ADV: Photo of Adm. Johnson has been sent to NYT photo clients. Non-subscribers can make individual purchase by calling 212-556-4204 or 1927.) (kd) By ERIC SCHMITT c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: WASHINGTON A;N;D;MD; Adm. Jay L. Johnson, one of the fastest-rising stars in the Navy, faces the most daunting challenge of his 28-year career in taking command of a service wracked by tragedy and turmoil.
President Clinton, calling this a ``crucial time'' in the Navy's history, Wednesday tapped Johnson to succeed his mentor, Adm. Jeremy Boorda, who committed suicide three weeks ago.

Colleagues describe Johnson, who became 50 on Wednesday, as a smart, decisive and low-key officer who as the new Chief of Naval Operations would move quickly to reassure a Navy badly shaken by the death of his popular predecessor. Johnson, a 1968 graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy, has been the vice chief of naval operations since April 1.

``Jay is a very steady, solid force who gives the impression of being unflappable,'' said Stanley R. Arthur, a retired admiral who commanded Navy forces in the Persian Gulf war. ``He'll present a soothing image. You won't see a lot of flash and dash from him.''

There is little doubt about the admiral's combat credentials. A fighter pilot with 150 combat missions during the Vietnam War, Johnson won praise as head of the Second Fleet during the U.S. intervention in Haiti in 1994, helping to coordinate the flying of Army helicopters off a Navy aircraft carrier.

A larger question is whether Johnson can overcome a relative lack of experience in the crucible of Washington politicking and in-fighting to turn around the military's most troubled service and win over skeptics in Congress.

Although Boorda did not attend the 1991 Tailhook convention, a gathering of naval aviators in Las Vegas where 83 women were assaulted, he was dogged by its legacy. Cheating and drugs at the prestigious Naval Academy and a series of crashes involving the Navy's fleet of aging F-14 fighter jets combined to create an image of a Navy spinning out of control.
Now these are Johnson's problems to resolve.
``He's got a very tough job ahead of him,'' said Barbara Pope, who worked with Johnson when she was a senior Navy personnel official in the Bush administration.

Senior Pentagon officials expressed hope Wednesday that Johnson, a tall, striking figure and articulate speaker, would by his sheer presence and leadership propel the Navy, and its 422,000 men and women, off the shoals of misfortune.

But in contrast to the effervescent Boorda, who openly promoted his common touch with sailors and his skill as a bureaucratic infighter, Johnson is more self-effacing and is not particularly well known, even within the Navy.
``He's not a big headline grabber,'' said Arthur. ``But people will expect an awful lot out of him. One thing he does need to do is keep visible.''

If the Senate confirms his nomination, Johnson would be one of the youngest men to head the Navy in this century. He would also become the first aviator to assume the Navy's top-ranking job since 1982.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-FAA-VALUJET-TEX FAA CHIEF SAYS AGENCY SHOULD HAVE DONE MORE TO MONITOR VALUJET OPERATIONS (For use by NYTimes News Service clients) By MICHAEL D. TOWLE c.1996 Fort Worth Star-Telegram

TEXT.p: WASHINGTON A;N;D;MD; The government's top regulator of the airline industry said Tuesday that his agency should have done more to monitor maintenance at ValuJet Airlines, which ceased operations after a crash last month in Florida took 110 lives.
``We should have done a better job helping ValuJet manage their infrastructure, especially with respect to maintenance,'' David Hinson, chief of the Federal Aviation Administration, told Congress.

Hinson said in testimony before the House Transportation Committee that the rapid growth of the low-cost, start-up airline appeared to exceed its ability to perform proper maintenance on its aircraft.

``A year ago in April they had about 25 airplanes, and they grew to 50 by February,'' Hinson said. ``In that time frame, we might have done a better of job of saying, `Why don't you slow down? Your systems may not be quite capable of helping you manage your growth.' There are some lessons learned there for us.''

Hinson also told lawmakers that he would be leaving the FAA by the end of the year. The FAA announced last week that it was accepting the retirement of the agency's assistant administrator, Anthony Broderick.

Atlanta-based ValuJet and the FAA have come under intense scrutiny since the May 11 crash of ValuJet Flight 592. Everyone aboard was killed when the McDonnell Douglas DC-9 plunged nose first into the Florida Everglades shortly after takeoff from Miami.
ValuJet halted operations at the request of the FAA, which said it found a series of maintenance problems during an intense post-crash review of the carrier's operations.

Industry and government experts complain that the FAA was lax in overseeing ValuJet and that the airline did not ensure that its maintenance operations kept pace with the rapid expansion of its fleet and routes.

Mary Schiavo, inspector general for the Transportation Department, told lawmakers in the nine-hour hearing that she had complained to the department about poor performance of FAA inspectors and potential problems in the fast-growing airline industry.

``We believe that there is a culture of unaccountability at the FAA,'' Schiavo said. ``Let's look at ValuJet. They conducted 5,000 inspections before the crash. Only after the crash, after the public scrutiny, after the media started digging and after some whistle blowers came forward was there action.''
ValuJet President Lewis Jordan defended his airline.

``Some have suggested that because ValuJet charges lower fares, the safety of the airline is also lower,'' Jordan told lawmakers. ``This is patently false. ValuJet is able to offer low fares because we cut frills. We have not and will never cut corners when it comes to safety.''

But David Stempler, an analyst with AirTrav Advisers, an air travel consulting firm, said the FAA should ground ValuJet permanently, which would keep the carrier's owners and senior management ``from ever operating an airline in the United States again.''
``This would be a fitting penalty,'' Stempler said, ``for a group of high-risk, financial entrepreneurs who have brought us ValuJet, which ... was an accident waiting to happen.''

Hinson told lawmakers that investigators of the National Transportation Safety Board have not found a link between the Florida crash and sloppy maintenance by outside contractors discovered by the FAA in its post-crash review.
But NTSB chairman Jim Hall said the FAA should have learned of the potential dangers of outside maintenance contractors 20 years ago.

He said the NTSB first cautioned the agency on the matter in 1976, when a DC-6 operated by a small regional carrier crashed near Van Nuys, Calif. He said workers for a maintenance contractor had improperly installed a propeller blade on the plane.
Hall added that the government must look carefully again at what he called ``virtual airlines'' A;N;D;MD; carriers that provide transportation but conduct none of their own maintenance or training.
``We will analyze how carriers that outsource these services are ensuring the safety of their operations,'' Hall said.

Sen. William S. Cohen, R-Maine, chairman of a Senate committee that oversees government management, said the FAA told lawmakers a decade ago that it was troubled by poor maintenance standards at start-up carriers.

``Perhaps the biggest single problem our inspector work force has faced is the management of new entrants,'' assistant administrator Broderick told a Senate panel in 1986. ``The proliferation of contract maintenance has been difficult to deal with and has caused a large workload.''
Cohen told the House committee Tuesday: ``Contract maintenance is not a new trend, but an old problem that has gone unaddressed and unsolved.''

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-ELVIS-DEATH-BOS EFFECT OF WINDS WEIGHED IN DEATH OF `FLYING ELVIS' (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By KATE HUNGER c.1996 The Boston Globe

TEXT.p: BOSTON A;N;D;MD; Less than 24 hours after a publicity parachute jump turned tragic, controversy surfaced over the cause A;N;D;MD; whether the jump should have been made in high winds or if the chutists had been dropped at the wrong spot A;N;D;MD; and the pilot pointing to wind shears as a possible explanation.
And the Federal Aviation Administration said it would investigate whether any regulations had been violated in the incident that left one of four Elvis impersonators dead.

Raymond E. Sayles 3d of Las Vegas, one of four parachutists with the Honeymoon in Vegas Skydiving Exhibition Team, died Wednesday at Boston City Hospital of injuries suffered in Tuesday night's jump to mark the grand opening of WaterWorks, an entertainment complex at Marina Bay in nearby Quincy.
Sayles, 41, suffered severe head injuries when he landed on an embankment by the Savin Hill Yacht Club parking lot, a mile short of the chutists' target across Dorchester Bay.

A second chutist, James Bozarth, of Henderson, Nev., was in stable condition at Boston City Hospital last night. The other two A;N;D;MD; Thomas LaRochelle of Brookline, N.H., and George Head of Las Vegas A;N;D;MD; landed unhurt in the water behind the yacht club.

The accident left many wondering Wednesday what went wrong. Some sources suggested the parachutists had been dropped at the wrong spot. And the pilot pointed to winds bounced from Boston skyscrapers as a possible explanation.

Randy Komich, a club member, who helped pull Head from the water, said it was ``definitely too windy'' for the jump and also said he thinks the parachutists were ``badly dropped'' A;N;D;MD; that is, too far from their destination.

Donald Mayer, 49, who piloted the Cessna 182A vintage 1952 aircraft modified for skydiving, said that from his vantage point the jump appeared to be ``excellent.'' Mayer, a parachuter with 1,500 jumps who works for Pepperell Skydiving Center, said there is no way he could have confused the marina locations.

``When you are looking from the air, there is no doubt where you are,'' said Mayer, who recalled seeing lights of the Marina Bay parking lot and people gathering for the exhibition. ``It's pretty precise.''

Richard Feeney, president and owner of a rival group, The Flying Elvi in Las Vegas, said the wind conditions should have stopped the jump. ``The Flying Elvi would never have jumped in those high wind conditions,'' he said.

But Glenn Bangs, director of safety and training with the United States Parachute Association, said weather conditions were ``well within limits.'' He also said licensed divers are not barred from jumping in strong winds A;N;D;MD; no matter how high. ``It appears as if it was safe for them to jump,'' Bangs said, adding that Sayles was the 23d member of the USPA to die in an accident this year.

The National Weather Service said winds were blowing to the southeast at 15 m.p.h. with gusts up to 23 m.p.h. at 9 p.m. A service spokesman said surface wind measurements do not reflect how strong winds thousands of feet up might have been.
Mayer said the plane left suburban Norwood Airport about 8 p.m. and hovered over Dorchester Bay about 8:15 p.m., Mayer said.

He said a wind drift indicator A;N;D;MD; a fluorescent yellow crepe paper 10 inches by 20 feet A;N;D;MD; was dropped from the plane to determine where the plane should position itself for the chutists to make the target A;N;D;MD; the parking lot of Marina Bay.

Mayer said the indicator landed within a mile of the target, making it a good condition for a jump. The plane climbed to 5,000 feet and the chutists prepared to jump, patting each other on the back, wishing each other a safe jump.
``I looked down at that point and their exit point was exactly where it should have been,'' Mayer said. ``I was thinking: `They're going to have an excellent jump.''
Mayer said he did not see the jumpers land because he had to return to Norwood airport and was stunned when he learned of the mishap. He said winds near cities can be unpredictable.

``Windshear could be one of the factors,'' Mayer said. ``If you were in the ocean, you would have a steady wind ... In Boston, the wind bounces off skyscrapers and the smoothness of the wind is disrupted. Even as far as Quincy wind is disrupted. We judge the best we can.''
Wednesday the FAA began its probe. ``They will look at any violation of regulations,'' said FAA spokeswoman Arlene Salac.

Federal aviation regulations prohibit parachuting between sunset and sunrise unless the jumper is equipped with a light that is visible for three miles. The regulations also oversee the packing of parachutes and whether parachutists can jump over densely settled areas or in controlled airspace.
Salac said the jumpers had obtained appropriate permits to jump in the restricted airspace, known as the Terminal Control Area, a 20-mile diameter around Boston's Logan Airport.
``Everything was fine with the waiver,'' Salac said, ``so they will be looking at the chutes.''

Ed Kane, president of Eating Up the Coast, the parent company of WaterWorks, said the jumpers were paid $8,500 and the contract allowed them to call it off if they deemed it dangerous for weather reasons. ``It was their call,'' he said.
Phil Cocco, director of operations for Eating Up the Coast, added: ``We handled every single possible thing we were supposed to. We told them: `Don't jump if you don't want to jump.' ''
Kelly Smith, manager of the Honeymoon group, was unavailable for comment Wednesday.
(Shirley Leung and Matthew Brelis of the Globe staff and Globe Correspondents Moira Downes and Anand Vaishnav contributed to this report.)

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TAYLOR-OBIT-NYT (ATTN: Mass., Ohio, Conn., Calif., N.J.) CHARLES TAYLOR, 101, HELPED DESIGN LINDBERGH'S ENGINE (bl) By DAVID STOUT c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: Charles Fayette Taylor, an engineer who was one of the last living links to the Wright brothers era of aviation and helped to design the engine for the plane that carried Charles A. Lindbergh across the Atlantic, died June 22 at his home in Weston, Mass. He was 101.

Taylor was on the faculty at Massachusetts Institute of Technology from 1926 until his retirement in 1960. His two-volume text, ``The Internal Combustion Engine in Theory and Practice,'' written several decades ago, remains a primary reference for automotive engineers, MIT said in announcing his death.

In the early 1920s, just after graduating from Yale University with a degree in mechanical engineering and while in charge of the Army's Air Service Laboratory in Dayton, Ohio, Taylor was introduced to Orville Wright.

Soon he was working for Wright Aeronautical Corp., where he was in charge of airplane-engine design and development from 1923 to 1926. He was on the team that designed the air-cooled Whirlwind engine for The Spirit of St. Louis, the craft built by Ryan Airlines of San Diego for Lindbergh's New-York-to-Paris flight in 1927.

Knowing full well that his life depended on the engine (and his ability to stay awake for the 33 and a half hours of the flight), Lindbergh fussed over its assembly. According to one account, a mechanic accidentally cracked a cooling fin. Not content to have the single fin replaced, Lindbergh wanted a whole new section of engine.
``Why?'' the mechanic asked.
``Because I don't swim so well,'' Lindbergh replied.

On the trip east before the trans-Atlantic flight, the engine coughed a bit over the Rocky Mountains. More ominously, it was running 1.5 percent below full power on the wet, chilly morning of May 20, 1927, as Lindbergh revved it on a Long Island airfield, mulling whether to take off for Paris.
One last check showed everything in order. Mechanics figured the engine was being momentarily slowed by the elements.
The plane took off and the engine worked just fine, even through 1,000 miles of snow and sleet over the ocean.

As a boy in New York City and in Montclair, N.J., where his family moved when he was 11, Charles Taylor was fascinated by airplanes. His drawings were like blueprints, his mother recalled years later.

In 1912, he entered Yale, receiving a bachelor's degree in philosophy in 1915. In World War I, he was an inspector of aircraft material for the Signal Corps for three months before being put in charge of the Navy's Aeronautical Engine Laboratory in Washington. He returned to Yale after the war and received an engineering degree in 1920.

Taylor joined MIT as an associate professor of aeronautical engineering in 1926. Three years later, he was a full professor and head of aeronautical engineering. In 1933, he was named professor of mechanical engineering and director of the new Sloan Laboratory for Aircraft and Automotive Engines, a post he held until his retirement in 1960.
In 1988, Taylor and his wife, Alice, were honored for creating the Educational Counseling Committee of Boston in the late 1940s and helping more than 2,000 black children attend college.
Just before his 100th birthday, on Sept. 24, 1994, he was asked what it meant to live a century. ``I saw Halley's Comet twice,'' he replied. He had, in 1910 and 1986.
Surviving are his wife, who is 98; a son, Philip, of San Carlos, Calif.; seven grandchildren, and 11 great-grandchildren. Another son, Charles Jr., died three years ago.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-AIR-SAFETY-NYT (Pa., Colo., Va., N.J. ATTN) RUDDER SWINGS MAY HAVE CAUSED CRASHES OF 737S (lb) By MATTHEW L. WALD c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: WASHINGTON A;N;D;MD; Air-safety investigators struggling with two unsolved crashes of Boeing 737s said Tuesday that an incident involving another 737 last month could provide important clues.

In the incident last month, the plane unexpectedly rolled to one side after a movement by the rudder that the pilot did not ask for A;N;D;MD; the same sequence that investigators believe happened in September 1994 to USAir Flight 427, which crashed on its approach to Pittsburgh, killing all 132 aboard.
The same sequence may have also happened in March 1991 to a United Airlines 737 that crashed as it was approaching Colorado Springs, killing all 25 aboard.

Like the two planes that crashed, the aircraft in last month's incident, a 25-year-old Boeing 737 belonging to a small new carrier, Eastwind Airlines, carried a primitive flight-data recorder that did not capture many details of the incident. The plane was bought from USAir and is still maintained by that airline.

Since the Pittsburgh crash, the National Transportation Safety Board has been studying all ``uncommanded roll'' incidents in 737s, in which one of the wings dips unexpectedly. Investigators have looked at more than 50 such incidents, but this is the first since the Pittsburgh crash that they cannot explain.
