Late on June 9, in calm, clear weather as the plane was approaching Richmond, Va., on a flight from the airline's headquarters in Trenton, N.J., the pilot felt what he described as a ``bump'' on the rudder, and then a more substantial swing as the plane rolled to the right.

The captain told the investigators that he ``stood on the opposite rudder pedal'' to try to correct the roll, and extended the ailerons A;N;D;MD; the flight-control panels on the wing surfaces A;N;D;MD; nearly all the way. The plane landed without injury to the 48 passengers and crew of five.

In the Pittsburgh case the flight-data recorder and cockpit voice recorder do not make clear what happened, but engineers say the plane's trajectory could be explained by a sudden swing of the rudder all the way to one side.

Engineers still do not know what could have made the rudder swing that way, but they believe that the problem may be centered on the standby rudder actuator, which is the only part of the rudder assembly on the Eastwind plane that was not replaced as they dealt with a series of problems in May and June.
On new planes, flight-data recorders generally track more than 100 different kinds of data, but the one on the Eastwind plane tracks only 11, as did the Pittsburgh plane.

In a letter to the Federal Aviation Administration, James Hall, the chairman of the safety board, said, ``Under slightly different circumstances, the Eastwind incident could have become a third fatal B-737 upset accident for which there was inadequate flight-data recorder information to determine the cause.''
The letter, sent on Monday and made public Tuesday, noted that the board had asked on Feb. 22, 1995, that such recorders be installed by the end of last year.
The safety board had asked for immediate action on early 737s and improvements over a longer period on other old planes. The FAA combined the two recommendations and drafted a single proposed rule.
In a statement Tuesday afternoon the agency said it agreed with the intent of the safety board's recommendations on flight-data recorders and was still working on a proposal.

Airlines have complained that wiring their planes to capture additional data, like the position of the rudder and the position of the rudder-control pedals in the cockpit, would mean taking them out of revenue-producing service for long periods.
The accidents are particularly troubling because more than 2,400 Boeing 737s are in use.

According to the safety board, the Eastwind plane had three earlier problems with its rudder. Shortly before the June 10 incident, most of the critical parts of the rudder-control system had been replaced, except for a part called the standby rudder actuator.

This is normally used only in back-up mode and is part of the yaw damper, an automatic system that swings the rudder up to 3 degrees in either direction to keep the plane pointed in the direction it is traveling.
The yaw damper may have been ``misrigged,'' Hall's letter said, and could have pushed the rudder up to 4.5 degrees.

Standby rudder actuators have been known to stick if metal parts inside rub together and metal from the softer surface accumulates. But Boeing Co. and others have insisted until now that such a failure cannot cause the rudder to bend by more than 3 degrees.

In this case, apparently because of a maintenance error, instead of having 3 degrees of movement to either side, it was 1.5 degrees to one side and 4.5 to the other. This is the first time investigators have found a mechanism for a swing of more than 3 degrees, but both planes evidently experienced an even larger rudder movement.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWA-CRASH-ART-1STLD-WRITETHRU-NYT TWA 747 EXPLODES IN MID-AIR OFF LONG ISLAND; MORE THAN 200 FEARED LOST (Subs for inserts, rewriting throughout story. Pls note 4th graf clarifying issue of number of people on plane.) (Eds.: The following story is now the lead article on The New York Times front page) (ART ADV: Graphic including locator map, description of plane and list of major fatal airline crashes will be sent as soon as possible to NYT graphics clients. Non-subscribers can make individual purchase by calling 212-556-4204 or 1927.) (sw) By N.R. KLEINFIELD c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: NEW YORK A;N;D;MD; A Trans World Airlines 747 bound for Paris from New York City plunged in a fireball into the waters off Long Island on Wednesday night with more than 200 people aboard.
The Coast Guard said there were no survivors, and officials said there was no immediate indication of what caused the crash.

The plane, Flight 800, went down at around 8:45 p.m., on a partly cloudy night minutes after taking off from John F. Kennedy International Airport. It crashed about 20 miles from the airport and sank into the waters off Moriches Inlet near Center Moriches in Suffolk County on the eastern end of Long Island, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.

The Coast Guard said there were 249 passengers and a crew of 32 aboard the flight, which was scheduled to leave Kennedy at 7 p.m. and was expected to arrive at Charles DeGaulle Airport in Paris at 8:15 on Thursday morning. However, TWA said there were 229 people aboard. The plane had come in from Athens as Flight 881.

Witnesses spoke of a light dropping swiftly from the sky and then either one or two bursts of flame and an enormous black cloud. As the plane spiraled toward the water, they said they saw pieces peel off.

``There were two explosions, bright red up in the air,'' said John Keshal, who lives right along the shore in Center Moriches. ``There was a lot of flames and redness in the air. And a lot of smoke. A lot of smoke.''
He said he didn't actually see anything resembling an airplane, but ``two separate red areas coming out of the sky.''
Even several hours after the crash, debris from the plane could be seen burning in the water as rescue boats surrounded it.

Jackie Marlow, who lives in East Moriches and had been fishing in Moriches Inlet, said, ``There was a great fire, like a fireball. Eventually the plane just spread apart, and there was a loud thump. I felt the tremor when it hit the water.''

Debbie Walsh, who was at a restaurant within view of the crash, said, ``It looked like a ball of fire falling into the water. It was a ball of fire and then the plane trailed down and seemed to break into two pieces.'' She added, ``It was trails of flame going down to the water.''
People on pleasure boats in the general vicinity of the crash reported seeing bodies bobbing in the water alongside fragments of the plane still on fire.
The plunging ball of fire was apparently visible as far away as Dune Road in Westhampton Beach, and people said they could feel the shock wave 10 to 12 miles from the crash.
``We are not finding any survivors,'' Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Steve Sapp was quoted by The Associated Press as saying. ``We are locating lots of bodies out there.''
Coast Guard and Navy planes dropped life rafts in the waters shortly after the crash. The Coaat Guard said that six helicopters, three cutters and a Navy P-3 plane were dispatched to the scene.
On the beaches fronting the inlet, a temporary morgue was set up by rescue officials.

The Federal Aviation Administration would not confirm that there was an explosion, saying only that it lost radar contact with the aircraft at 8:45 p.m. The plane was under the control of the Boston Air Traffic Control Center.

The possibility that there was an explosion aboard the plane raised the obvious possibility that terrorism was involved, and federal law-enforcement officials said they were looking into that possibility. But there are other possible causes for an explosion as well, such as a problem with an engine, and it may be weeks or even months before a final determination is made.
If terrorism was involved, the FBI would have jurisdiction over the investigation into the cause of the blast.

But the officials cautioned that they had no definitive evidence suggesting what caused the downing of the plane, and said that it would probably be many hours before they got a clear fix on what happened. One federal official, however, said, ``It doesn't look good,'' meaning that the circumstances seemed to point to a terrorist act.
The FBI was mobilizing agents on Wednesday night from its New York field office to help identify victims and to work with the FAA to help determine the cause of the crash.

Ira Furman, a former investigator for the National Transportation Safety Board, urged caution about early reports of explosions. ``We have found reports of explosions unreliable,'' he said. ``I can suggest that sometimes an explosion is really connected with a flameout, like a backfire in a car.''

The National Transportation Safety Board said that a team from its New Jersey office was securing the beaches bordering the waters where the crash occurred. An additional team from Washington was expected to arrive at the site on Thursday morning.

The aircraft, a 747 Model 100, is the world's first jumbo jet and was flown for the first time in 1969. The 100 designation makes it one of the older 747 models. It is 232 feet long, with a wingspan of 196 feet. The plane can cruise at 600 miles and hour, with a range of nearly 760 miles.
The aircraft can be configured to carry as many as 516 passengers, although it was unclear how many people the plane that crashed was set up to contain.
The plane had come in from Athens as Flight 881.
The FAA said the plane had climbed to 13,000 feet before it disappeared from the radar screen.
The FBI sent counterterrorism investigators to the scene, which is normally done in instances where there is a possibility of an attack.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWA-PROBE-UPDATE1-BLOOM TWA CRASH CAUSE PROBED; COMPANY RECEIVED NO THREATS (UPDATE1) (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By Greg Groeller c.1996 Bloomberg Business News (Updates with names of crew members, comments from New York congressman and aviation consultant, details on Pratt A;N;D;AMP; Whitney engine.)

TEXT.p: New York, July 18 (Bloomberg) -- U.S. investigators continued to probe what caused a Trans World Airlines Inc. jumbo jet to explode and plummet into the Atlantic Ocean with 228 people aboard last night. There were no reports of survivors. CNN reported that about 100 bodies have been found.
Officials said they haven't ruled out terrorism as a cause of the blast on the Boeing 747-100 jet, which came after TWA heightened security as a precaution ahead of the Olympic Games in Atlanta.

``We have no reason to believe that there was a threat against the aircraft,'' Mark Abels, a TWA spokesman, said at a press conference. He also said the company doesn't believe there were any problems with the aircraft.
Abels said TWA wouldn't release a complete list of passengers until all family members were notified. He said there were 210 passengers on board. The rest were flight attendants and crew.
President Clinton warned Americans not to jump to conclusions about the cause of the crash.
``We do not know what caused this tragedy,'' Clinton said. ``Let's wait until we see the evidence. We will find out what happened.''
Eyewitnesses described a series of explosions before the plane fell.

The navy was sending a crew to retrieve the plane's black boxes, which could be about 100 feet under water, said House Minority Leader Richard Gephardt. The crash site is about 20 miles off New York's Long Island.
New York Representative Michael Forbes, speaking near the crash site, said he was told divers had retrieved one of the two black boxes.
Search teams retrieved passengers' belongings and parts of the engine, wings and a 30-foot piece of the fuselage.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation is leading the investigation into whether the explosion was ``the result of criminal activity,'' James Hall, the chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, told CNN.
Attorney General Janet Reno said the FBI was looking into two suspicious telephone calls made after the crash that may have been related to the TWA crash.

TWA Flight 800, bound for Paris, disappeared from radar screens around 8:40 p.m. local time shortly after taking off from New York's John F. Kennedy Airport. Among the passengers was a party of 16 teenagers from a Pennsylvania high school.
Experts say the maximum survival period in the Atlantic Ocean at 65 degrees Fahrenheit is 12 hours.

Abels, the TWA spokesman, said the plane was delayed about an hour because of confusion over a passenger's luggage and the breakdown of a piece of ground equipment that had to be towed from the runway.
The 25-year-old Boeing aircraft was bound for Paris's Charles de Gaulle Airport. The plane had flown earlier yesterday from Athens, Greece, to New York.
Takis Tassopoulous, the head of Greek aviation security, told CNN that his office had no warnings of terrorist activity in Athens.

TWA released the names of some crew members. These included Capt. Steve Snyder, a TWA pilot since 1964; Richard Campell, flight engineer; and Oliver Krick, recently hired by TWA and on the plane as an observer as part of his flight engineer training.

The crash comes two months after a ValuJet Inc. plane exploded and crashed in the Florida Everglades, killing all 110 people aboard. That plane was a McDonnell Douglas Corp. DC-9. Atlanta-based ValuJet was grounded by the Federal Aviation Administration one month after the crash.

David Stempler, an aviation consultant in Washington, D.C., said the FAA, already under fire for its monitoring of ValuJet, will face tough questions about its safety regulations as a result of the latest crashes.
Passengers will have a ``you better get it right this time'' attitude toward both the airlines and the agency, Stempler said.

A U.S. airliner has never been brought down with a bomb planted in the U.S. A terrorist bomb that blew up a Pan Am flight over Lockerbie, Scotland, in December 1988 originated in Germany, hidden in a cassette player.
The crash comes less than a year after St. Louis-based TWA emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, the airline's second bankruptcy filing in two years.

The carrier has become competitive again by paring costs and pulling out of money-losing routes. The 72-year-old carrier earlier on Wednesday reported an almost fivefold increase in second-quarter net income to $25.3 million, or 46 cents a share.
TWA has had a good safety record, industry analysts say.
The plane that crashed was bought in 1971, a Boeing spokesman said. Boeing produced that model of the world's largest airliner from 1970 through 1986. It holds about 360 passengers in three classes.
``It's too soon to get any hard data on what happened,'' said Boeing spokesman Doug Webb. ``We will cooperate fully with any investigation.''

All Boeing 747-100 planes use Pratt A;N;D;AMP; Whitney JT9D engines, said Mark Sullivan, a spokesman for Pratt A;N;D;AMP; Whitney, which is a unit of United Technologies Corp. Sullivan said the engine, in use since 1970, hasn't experienced any problems ``that would be considered out of the ordinary for airline operations.''
Pratt A;N;D;AMP; Whitney has sent a crash investigator to the site, Sullivan said.
TWA shares fell 1 to 10 1/4 in midafternoon trading of 5.2 million shares, far more than the three-month daily average of 885,700 shares.
Boeing shares rose 1 5/8 to 86 7/8, while United Technologies gained 2 3/4 to 107 3/4.
Brian Jenkins, vice chairman of the international security firm Kroll Associates, said airport security measures have improved significantly in recent years, in the wake of terrorist attacks.
``As the result of extraordinary security measures, commercial aviation, which was once one of the most popular targets of international terrorism, was made a more difficult target,'' he said.

He said attempts to hijack or plant bombs aboard aircraft have decreased. Deaths in crashes, however, have increased markedly this year, according to Flight International magazine, to 609 in the first six months from 206 in the same period last year.
A toll-free number has been set up for family members of people on the flight. The number is (800) 438-9892.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWACRASH-CAUSE-TEX AVIATION EXPERTS POINT TO TERRORISM AS LIKELY CAUSE OF CRASH (For use by NYTimes News Service clients) By MICHAEL D. TOWLE c.1996 Fort Worth Star-Telegram

TEXT.p: WASHINGTON A;N;D;MD; Aviation experts pointed Thursday to a terrorist attack as the most likely cause of the explosion and fiery crash of a TWA jumbo jet into the Atlantic Ocean off New York's Long Island.
But they did not rule out mechanical failure, such as the explosion of one of the four engines on the Boeing 747-100, and President Clinton warned against snap conclusions.
``I want to caution the American people we have no evidence ... that would indicate the cause of the accident,'' Clinton said.

``And I want to remind you that when we had the terrible tragedy in Oklahoma City, a lot of people immediately concluded that this must have been done by some force outside our country, and it appears that that was not the case now.''
But aviation and terrorism experts said eyewitness accounts and information so far available on the crash of TWA Flight 800 point to a bomb as the cause.

``It appears to have been an instantaneous, huge explosion,'' said William Lawrence, a Fort Worth aviation expert and former Marine Corps pilot who investigated aviation accidents for the Navy. ``If I had to bet, I would bet it was a bomb.''
Among the reasons for that conclusion:
Eyewitnesses seem to say unanimously that the Paris-bound plane plunged into the Atlantic in a ball of fire.
The wreckage, judging from pictures available through the media, was in small pieces, a sign of the explosive force of a bomb.
The Boeing 747, despite some high-profile mishaps, is considered one of the world's safest aircraft.
The crash came two days before this evening's opening of the Olympic Games in Atlanta, a factor that might have figured in terrorists' planning if they were indeed behind the crash.

MSNBC, the new interactive news service from Microsoft Corp. and NBC News, reported late Thursday on the World Wide Web that investigators were looking at radar tapes to examine ``possible activity outside the 747 when it went down.''
The tapes may reveal another object, possibly a missile, collided with the plane, the report said.
But Lawrence acknowledged that there could be several possible causes for the crash.

``If an engine did come apart, it may have sent a hot piece through a fuel tank,'' Lawrence said. ``It could also have been carrying some kind of hazardous cargo that would have caused an explosion.''
Oxygen generators carried as cargo aboard a ValuJet DC-9 have been cited as a probable cause of the plane's crash on May 11 in the Florida Everglades. All 110 people on board were killed.
Lawrence said it was unusual for TWA Flight 800 to have disappeared from radar screens with no emergency communications from the crew.
TWA officials said the plane left Kennedy Airport at 7:19 p.m. CDT and disappeared by 7:48 p.m. with ``no non-routine transmissions.''

The crash was reminiscent of the downing of Pan Am Flight 103 on Dec. 21, 1988. The Boeing 747 exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland, less than an hour into its flight from London to New York. No distress signals were received from its crew and witnesses reported seeing fireballs in the sky.

Within hours of the Pan Am crash, investigators suspected a bomb. The plane exploded suddenly at 31,000 feet and an Iranian group claimed responsibility. Federal officials had been cautioned that a Pan Am flight on the Frankfurt-New York route was a target for bombing.
Investigators later found that the bomb was made of plastic explosive hidden in a radio-cassette recorder in a suitcase. That bomb was triggered by a device set for a specific altitude.
Robert Louden, a terrorism expert at the John Jay College in New York, said several signs point to terrorism in the TWA crash, but that so far there is no hard evidence.

He noted that the FBI immediately dispatched members of its explosives unit to New York. The agents should be able to determine if an explosive device was used by looking for residue of explosive material on debris and even on the bodies of victims.
``Because of the possibility of terrorism, you absolutely have to start looking right away,'' Louden said. ``If it does turn out to be that, you haven't lost time or potential evidence.''
But Louden said the crash could have been caused by someone without political motives.

``It could be man-caused, but not terrorist related,'' he said. ``There could be some other motivation for someone wanting to accomplish the same end. There are any number of motivating factors: terrorism, suicide, insurance, and it could have been just one person bent on any of the above.''
Attorney General Janet Reno said two telephone calls from people claiming responsibility were received after the plane went down.

Television station WTSP in Tampa, Fla., received a call at about 2:45 Thursday morning from someone whom station officials said claimed to be a member of a Jihad, or ``holy war.'' The station notified Tampa police and the FBI.
But Louden said it is not unusual for a group, or pranksters, to take credit for a deadly event after the fact.
``Often, it is one group trying to get their name in the ring,'' he said.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWA-OVERHAUL-KAN EXPLOSION OF TWA FLIGHT 800 SPREADS PALL OVER AIRLINE'S OVERHAUL BASE (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By JULIUS A. KARASH c. 1996 Kansas City Star

TEXT.p: KANSAS CITY, Mo. A;N;D;MD; The deadly explosion of TWA Flight 800 spread a pall over the airline's Kansas City overhaul base Thursday.

``We lost a lot of good people on that airplane,'' Roger Tyler, a base mechanic, said as he sat at nearby Allie's Bar A;N;D;AMP; Grill after his work shift ended Thursday afternoon. ``It's heart saddening.''
Federal Aviation Administration records show that the jet that crashed near New York paid what were considered routine visits to the base, the airline's primary site for plane maintenance.
Base workers said they and their colleagues wore Walkman radios much of the work day, listening for word of what ignited the 747 explosion.
The cause of the crash was unknown, and that uncertainty grated on the beefy, bearded Tyler.

``I would hate to think that this was maintenance,'' he said over the muted babblings of a TV talk show. ``As long as I've worked at TWA, I've never seen bad maintenance. Everybody's so conscientious. The training takes years. It's not something you go to night school for.''
Other TWA workers at the bar described the mood at the base as ``pretty somber.''
Steve Lacy, a mechanic who has worked at the base nearly 30 years, was subdued and somewhat stoic about the tragedy.
``I'm sorry for all those people that got killed,'' Lacy said. ``It's just one of those things. It could have been a bomb or anything. You don't know what happened....There's nothing else I can do.''
Kathy Woodward, a bartender and waitress at the Final Approach Pub near the base, said she served fewer TWA employees than normal Thursday.
``The (TWA) people I had today were very down,'' Woodward said amid the bar's vast collection of airline memorabilia. ``They were glued to the TV. People were not themselves.''
Tyler, who overhauls pumps that move fuel from the wings to the engine, said working on aircraft is a high-pressure job, ``probably right below being a doctor.''

``We take people's lives in our hands,'' he said. ``We don't take it lightly. I'll stand behind every pump I ever build. When I go home to sleep tonight, I'll know that isn't what caused that crash.''
Tyler insisted that the crash wouldn't impede TWA's financial recovery after years of losses: ``We're coming back, and everybody knows we're coming back.''

Mechanics and other rank-and-file workers at the base belong to Machinists Local 1650, which is overseen by Machinists District 142. Gary Poos, a District 142 official, said the union is ``fully participating in this investigation.''
Poos said William O'Driscoll, president of District 142, was at the command post in New York.
Poos said the union's ``deepest sympathy goes to the families and friends of those who perished in this tragedy.''

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWA-MISSILE-HNS EXPERTS SKEPTICAL THAT A STINGER MISSILE DOWNED TWA JET (For use by New York Times News Service clients.) By HOLLY YEAGER c.1996 Hearst Newspapers

TEXT.p: WASHINGTON A;N;D;MD; Weapons experts said Friday it's unlikely that a Stinger surface-to-air missile brought down TWA Flight 800.

Paul Beaver, a spokesman for Jane's Information Group Limited, publishers of books on weapons, noted a lack of evidence that any missile was involved in the Wednesday night explosion and crash of the Boeing 747.
Beaver also expressed skepticism that a hand-held U.S.-made Stinger anti-aircraft missile could have downed the jumbo jet.

Some eyewitnesses said they saw a bright light moving toward the jet just before it exploded over the Atlantic Ocean shortly after it had taken off from John F. Kennedy Airport in New York, leading to speculation that a missile may have been responsible. TWA said 230 passengers and crew were killed in the incident.
However, Beaver said several factors make him think the weapon ``couldn't possibly have been used.''
For one thing, the Stinger's maximum altitude is about 12,400 feet, while the TWA jet exploded at an altitude of around 13,700, he noted.

Furthermore, the missile has a maximum range of about 2.8 miles, while the TWA plane was about 10 miles offshore. The missile would have to have been fired from a boat, a still more difficult maneuver.
In addition, Beaver said batteries used in the missiles have only a 10-year life and may have failed by now.
``You need to be an expert to operate it,'' he said. ``You need to smuggle it into the United States or to have obtained it illegally in the United States,'' he added.
Noting that a shoulder-fired Stinger, including its heat-seeking missile and launcher, weighs about 44 pounds and is 60 inches long, Beaver called it ``a conspicuous piece of merchandise.''
Arms control experts have been concerned about an estimated 1,000 Stinger missiles the United States shipped to Afghan rebels in the late 1980s to help them shoot down Soviet helicopters.

After the war, several hundred unused Stingers began spreading to other countries and terrorist groups. A CIA effort with a reported budget of $55 million to buy back the missiles has been largely unsuccessful, instead boosting the black-market price of the $30,000 missiles to more than $100,000, experts say.
William D. Hartung, a specialist in the global arms market at the New School for Social Research, called the spread of the U.S.-made Stingers ``a case of unintended consequences.''

The United States provided the weapons to the anti-communist Afghan mujahedeen ``for one purpose, ejecting the Soviets, but they didn't think about the character of the movement that they were giving it to, which was a right-wing fundamentalist Islamic movement which was involved in training Islamic fighters from all over the world,'' he said.

While that helps explain how the Stingers originally shipped to Afghanistan spread to terrorist groups throughout the world, Hartung said it's ``unbelievable that someone could park themselves on Long Island with a Stinger missile and take out an airliner.''
Natalie J. Goldring, deputy director of the British American Security Information Council, a non-profit research group, also expressed skepticism that a Stinger was responsible.
``I think we've been lucky,'' Goldring said. ``I am one of those people who has been saying for a long time that this is the sort of system that can come back to haunt us.''
Goldring said ``every Stinger that is in another country's hands is a Stinger that can be used against civilian aircraft.''
But she, too, said she thinks it's unlikely that a Stinger was used to down the jumbo jet. ``The more that advanced technology is used in a system, the shorter its shelf life tends to be,'' she said.
While pistols from World War I can still be found in working order, ``advanced portable surface-to-air missiles are a lot more complicated,'' she said.

Terrorism expert Neil Livingstone said it's too early to rule out any explanation for the explosion, but he said a missile appears unlikely. On the other hand, he said, at least a dozen terrorist groups have surface-to-air missiles.

While Pentagon officials have discounted reports that radar showed a small object approaching the plane just before it exploded, Beaver said a missile like the Stinger wouldn't necessarily show up on radar.

John Pike of the Federation of American Scientists said that even if the TWA plane was outside the range of a Stinger, ``that would by no means rule out this thing being done by a surface-to-air missile,'' other than a Stinger, perhaps fired from a boat.
``There are other man-portable missiles ... that have a significantly longer range,'' including the Russian SA-7 Grail anti-aircraft missile, Pike said.
Goldring said the mere speculation that a U.S.-made weapon may have been responsible for the explosion will bring attention to U.S. arms export policy.
``I think we need to think much more carefully about what kinds of weapons we are supplying, especially to unstable and undemocratic regimes,'' she said. ``The risks are just too high.''

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWA-SEARCH-HNS SEAMAN KEEPS THINKING OF STUFFED TWEETIE BIRD FISHED FROM WATER (For use by New York Times News Service clients.) By BENNETT ROTH c.1996 Houston Chronicle

TEXT.p: EAST MORICHES, N.Y. A;N;D;MD; Tom Coonan had been at sea less than two days when his U.S. Coast Guard cutter was forced by rough weather to abandon its search Friday for the remains of TWA Flight 800.
On his way back to port, the 19-year-old seaman kept thinking about the four-foot, stuffed Tweetie Bird he had fished from the water.
``I thought about a little kid sitting near his mom holding that bird,'' he said. ``And then, it's over.''

For Coonan and 10 other crew members of the Coast Guard cutter Point Wells, the past two days have been unsettling. Their vessel, once a patrol boat in Vietnam, was one of the first to arrive off eastern Long Island early Thursday, just hours after the Paris-bound Boeing 747 exploded and plunged into the Atlantic.
``You could smell it in the air. You knew something had happened,'' said Coonan, a Vermont native.
``It was eerie when you know what's out there,'' said Chris Biswurm, 23, another Point Wells crewman. ``We were just out there steaming through this stuff.''

Donald Kreesim, a senior chief petty officer, said he had tried to prepare his young crew for what he knew would be an emotionally difficult task when the Point Wells left port. He even refused to let the crew watch television, fearing it might distract them and make their jobs even harder.
``We had a mission to concentrate on,'' said Kreesim, 40.

Since late Wednesday, the Point Wells and hundreds of other vessels have scoured the Atlantic off Long Island, looking for bodies, plane debris and any possessions of the 230 people who boarded the plane at New York's John F. Kennedy Airport.
Search and rescue efforts were hampered Friday by rain and heavy seas.

Waves as high as six feet forced the Coast Guard to recall some of its smaller boats. Divers, who had been expected to begin their search for debris on the ocean floor, were unable to get into the water.
Officials feared the turbulent water was spreading the debris and moving some of it into deeper water, which would increase the difficulty of retrieving bodies and wreckage.
``The weather is not playing in our favor,'' said Blair Thomas, public affairs officer for the Coast Guard.

On Saturday, the Navy is expected to bring in divers and special equipment that can be lowered in the water to pick up the high-pitched signal from the flight data recorders A;N;D;MD; the so-called black boxes A;N;D;MD; aboard the aircraft.
Meanwhile, residents have been reporting pieces of the wreckage washing ashore.
Ed O'Connell found a charred tray table, the kind normally attached to the rear of airplane seats, near his home about 15 miles from the crash site.
O'Connell, who showed reporters his find, said he figured it was part of the plane when he noticed the wording ``Life Vest under your seat'' etched on the tray bottom.
Meanwhile, those who observed the jumbo jet exploding say they still have vivid memories. Captain Chris Baur of the New York International Guard, was flying his helicopter when the plane went down.
``There was an explosion followed by a bigger explosion followed by a bigger explosion,'' Baur recalled. ``It spiraled down like a corkscrew until it hit the ocean.''
Baur said he became aware of the magnitude of the loss when he sighted as many as 80 bodies in the water.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWA-CRASH-BLOOM FBI HASN'T TAKEN OVER TWA PROBE; CAUSE STILL UNKNOWN (UPDATE1) (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By Greg Groeller c.1996 Bloomberg Business News (Adds comments from National Transportation Safety Board's 9 p.m. press conference in 5th-8th and 13th paragraphs.)

TEXT.p: New York, July 19 (Bloomberg) -- A U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation official said the agency hasn't taken over the probe of Wednesday's crash of a Trans World Airlines Inc. jet that killed 230 people.
However, Jim Kallstrom, an investigator with the FBI's anti-terrorism task force, said the FBI is treating the crash site as a crime scene in case it later determines a crime was committed.

Kallstrom said investigators haven't determined the cause and are considering all possibilities. TWA Flight 800, a Boeing 747, exploded and plunged into the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Long Island, New York, on Wednesday night.
``If it is a terrorist act, we will find the cowards who did this,'' Kallstrom said at a press conference near the crash site.

The FBI hasn't delayed blaming the crash on a terrorist act due to pressure from the White House over the timing of the opening of the Olympic games, Kallstrom said in a second press conference held Friday evening. ``We're not trying to be cute here. We're not prepared to say something until we're sure it's absolutely true,'' he said. ``We're not discounting anything.''
Kallstrom added that it took six days before the December 1988 crash of a Pan Am 747 in Lockerbie, Scotland, was labeled the result of a bomb.
He said the FBI is working with overseas criminal investigation agencies in the probe, which he described as ``massive.''
The crash is the second-worst in the U.S., after a 1979 American Airlines crash in Chicago that killed 273.
The plane went down shortly after taking off from New York's John F. Kennedy Airport bound for Paris's Charles de Gaulle Airport. It had flown earlier from Athens, Greece, to New York.
Earlier today, a spokesman for the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency confirmed it also is investigating the crash, looking for clues that might suggest a foreign connection.
``We've been involved since the tragedy first occurred,'' said Mark Mansfield, a CIA spokesman. He said the CIA always looks at incidents where involvement by a foreign person or group is possible.

At the evening press conference, Robert Francis, chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, said high winds and rough seas had forced divers away from a spot at the crash site where a large piece of the aircraft might be located, according to sonar readings. This evening he said less than 1 percent of the wreckage has been recovered so far.
Earlier, New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani again slammed TWA for taking too long to present victims' families with a list of confirmed fatalities.
``I heard a TWA spokesman say that all the family members had been notified by noon yesterday,'' Giuliani said. ``That's totally false. They hadn't even compiled a list by 4 o'clock.''

Jeff Erickson, TWA's chief executive, responded to a question about the delay by saying that the airline's trauma response team had to be assembled from locations all over the country. He said TWA officials are currently working with family members in New York and Paris.
Erickson also said last night's Flight 800 left fully loaded and that the airline's advance bookings for the summer remain strong.
TWA shares fell 3/4 to close at 9 1/2 on trading of 3.5 million shares, much more than the three-month average of 997,100, but less than half the 7.3 million shares traded Thursday.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-YUGO-BOSNIA-TROOPS-NYT BOSNIA GIs SEE THEMSELVES AS LUCKY AFTER BOMB MISHAP (th) By MIKE O'CONNOR c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: BRCKO, Bosnia-Herzegovina A;N;D;MD; While the Navy investigated why one of its aircraft accidentally dropped a 500-pound bomb on the edge of a U.S. military base near here, soldiers at the base were asking similar questions Sunday and counting themselves lucky that there were no injuries.
Aside, that is, from damage to the nerves of the some 800 people, most attached to an Army cavalry squadron, who were at the base on Saturday afternoon when the bomb struck.
``We thought war was fixing to break out,'' said Pfc. Carter Sanders, who with his partner in a watchtower at the base, Camp McGovern, was probably the closest person to the explosion.
Pfc. John Raile said, ``People's eyes were all wide trying to figure out what happened.''

Some soldiers said they thought that they were under artillery attack. The base commander, Lt. Col. Tony Cucolo, said he thought at first that it might be an attack by a renegade pilot from one of the local Bosnian military forces. Others said they had no idea who was shooting at them or with what.

Soldiers said that for about 30 minutes until the situation was clarified, they dove into bunkers and ran to firing positions around the base, preparing to fire off mortars and getting ready for the next step in what was generally thought to be an attack.

But even the truth was of only limited comfort. Spc. Ronald Orr said he had thought of soldiers killed by alleid fire during the 1991 Persian Gulf war. He said: ``It makes you think, `Here we go again.' ''

Military officials said the bomb fell from a Navy FA-18 jet, also known as a Hornet, in which the pilot was practicing bombing runs near the base so as to be able to protect the troops there in case they came under attack by ground forces.

The drill did not entail dropping a bomb, only practicing coordination between the aircraft and controllers on the ground. But as the jet, which was based on the carrier Enterprise in the Adriatic, flew over the base, the bomb fell, exploding on a remote section of a large mound of dirt that runs around most of the base.
It missed three large freight containers holding ammunition by about 200 feet.

About half of the bomb's weight was the metal casing, so 250 pounds of explosive shook the ground, sending concussion waves against the soldiers and 250 pounds of metal fragments through part of the base. An Army spokesman said, however, that there was almost no damage from either the explosion or shrapnel.
There have been no fatalities as a result of hostile action among the 16,500 American peacekeepers in Bosnia since they began arriving in December.
The base, just southwest of Brcko, is in a particularly tense area of Bosnia, in the three-mile wide strip of land that separates Bosnian government and Bosnia Serb territory.

There has been fairly constant friction between the Muslim and Serbian authorities here. Last week, three war-damaged houses that were being rebuilt by their Muslim owners on the Serbian side were dynamited, presumably by Serbs who did not want the Muslims to return.

Four nights ago, base officers said, three men tried to sneak into the base, prompting a search around the base and the shooting off of illumination shells. Although the officers said the intruders probably were only looking for something to steal, the incident raised anxieties here.

Sgt. Peter Walker said that on Saturday, while he was trying to figure out who was behind the explosion, he thought of last month's bomb attack on the American base in Saudi Arabia and last week's crash of the TWA airliner off Long Island.
As he watched the smoke rise from what he described as a very impressive explosion, Walker said he thought: ``If something like that hits real near us, we're dead. There's no question.''

The base is built around a large group of buildings from an abandoned farm cooperative. The nearest civilian houses are more than a mile away in the Bosnia Serb side of the dividing line. But these too are abandoned for the most part. The owners are Muslims who were expelled during the war, and the homes are too badly damaged to be habitable.

But some of the owners are repairing their homes. Sunday, while the American soldiers were still shaken, Hamdija Mujic leaned against the bumper of his burned car, which remains in the ruins of the garage where it was sitting two years ago when an artillery barrage destroyed his house.
``Yeah, we heard the explosion,'' Mujic said, ``but we didn't think much of it. It was just one bomb. The Americans should relax.''

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWA-CRASH-2NDLD-WRITETHRU-920A;N;D;AMP;ADD(2TAKES)-NYT (Inserts new 5th thru 9th grafs concerning conflicts over number of bodies found and recovered; small editing changes throughout story) CRASH INQUIRY FAILS TO FIND EVIDENCE OF EXPLOSIVE(ART ADV: Map of debris found by Coast Guard has been sent to NYT graphics clients. Non-subscribers can make individual purchase by calling 212-556-4204 or 1927.) (sw) By MATTHEW PURDY c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: NEW YORK A;N;D;MD; Investigators examining the small amount of wreckage recovered so far from the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 said on Tuesday that they had not yet found any concrete evidence that the plane was destroyed by an explosive device.

Speaking to reporters on Tuesday evening, President Clinton said investigators were making progress, but he added: ``We must not draw conclusions until we're sure the conclusion is supported by the facts. And I cannot say that I've learned anything today which enables me to give you a definite conclusion about the cause of the accident.''

Law enforcement officials on Long Island continued to maintain that circumstantial evidence suggested that the 747 jetliner crashed because of an act of either political terrorism or sabotage. And they said they expected to have a clearer sense of what caused the plane to explode last Wednesday night when they begin recovering large sections of the wreckage, possibly as early as Wednesday.

Gov. George Pataki said the first priority was to recover the ``dozens and dozens'' of bodies that divers had found trapped in large sections of the fuselage resting on the bottom of the ocean. He estimated that the divers had found 60 to 100 bodies, which could account for most of the 122 bodies that have not been recovered.
Despite Pataki's announcement, there were conflicting statements from other officials on Tuesday night.
Robert Francis, the vice-chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, said there were no bodies in the wreckage that had not been recovered.
But despite Francis' comments, a federal official in East Moriches, on Long Island, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, confirmed that there were dozens of bodies still on the ocean floor.

And early on Wednesday, James Kallstrom, assistant FBI director for the New York office, said: ``Given the fact that a portion of the fuselage has been discovered, and that the search team has apparently located a large debris field in the same area, we have every hope and expectation of finding and recovering a significant number of victims soon.''
The accounts angered family members staying at the Ramada Plaza Hotel at Kennedy International Airport, who told reporters late on Tuesday night that they were frustrated by the conflicting accounts.
So far, the remains of 108 of the 230 people on board the New York to Paris flight have been recovered, and 77 bodies have been identified.

At the crash site off the coast of Suffolk County on Long Island, recovery workers brought up three more bodies on Tuesday and continued sonar mapping of the ocean floor in preparation for the enormous task of disentangling bodies from the wreckage, bringing them to the surface and then raising the pieces of the airplane.
``Raising the remains, identifying the bodies is a top priority,'' Pataki said. ``We believe there will be dozens and dozens of bodies that will be identified and returned to their families.''

The governor said the second task would be to recover the large pieces of the plane, which he said would help solve the mystery of what made the airplane explode at an altitude of 13,700 feet shortly after it took off for Paris.

Law enforcement officials, who from the beginning suspected that the plane had been destroyed by an explosive device, said on Tuesday that further tests for traces of explosives from a piece of the airplane's wing had not yet produced any evidence of such traces. On Monday, when law enforcement agents on Long Island tested a residue found on the underside of the wing segment, they first found traces of an explosive, but in a later test with different equipment, no traces were detected.

On Tuesdayy, when the residue was tested with more sophisticated equipment at the FBI laboratory in Quantico, Va., once again no explosive traces were found on this or any other piece of wreckage that had been retrieved.
``Right now,'' a senior law enforcement official said, ``we just don't have enough pieces of metal to make a judgment about the cause of the crash. Not today and maybe not tomorrow.''

Even as the crash inquiry remains classified as an accident investigation, the FBI is investigating various criminal theories. And Zachary Carter, the U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of New York, has assigned prosecutors and investigators, led by Valerie Caproni, head of the criminal division, to monitor the case.
Kallstrom, said on Tuesday that the FBI had already conducted 1,300 interviews on the crash. ``We're looking at everybody that touched that aircraft,'' he said.
Kallstrom said that two working criminal theories were that the plane was destroyed by a bomb or a missile and that ``there's circumstantial evidence pointing in those directions.''

Kenneth Bacon, the Defense Department's chief spokesman, cast some doubt on the possibility of a missile. He said that satellite photographs and radar data offered no evidence of a missile strike on the plane. He said that apart from the accounts of eyewitnesses who described a streak of light near the 747 before the explosion, there was ``precious else'' to suggest that a missile had hit the plane.

But he told reporters that the Defense Department and other federal agencies had left open the possibility of a missile, possibly fired from a boat. ``Could it have been fired from the water?'' he said. ``That is the question that they're looking into.''

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-NJ-SMALL-PLANE-CRASH-NYT (ATTN: N.J., Del., N.Y.) SMALL PLANE CRASHES INTO ATLANTIC; NO SURVIVORS FOUND (bl) c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: A small single-engine plane crashed into the Atlantic Ocean about eight miles off New Jersey on Wednesday. The Coast Guard reported finding aircraft debris and a fuel slick, but no bodies or survivors.

The plane, which can carry four people, was seen hitting the water shortly after 11 a.m. by a fisherman, who radioed the Coast Guard, according to Petty Officer Jeff Fenn, a spokesman for the base at Governors Island in New York Harbor.

By midafternoon, several vessels and a helicopter were combing the area about eight miles east of Sea Bright, N.J., and seven miles south of the Ambrose Light, the Coast Guard said. The area is 55 miles from the site off Long Island where a TWA 747 crashed one week earlier.
Searchers found the plane's landing gear, seat cushions and other debris, Petty Officer Fenn said. He said the water is about 125 feet deep in the crash area and that much of the wreckage had sunk.

The Coast Guard said the craft had taken off from Allaire Airport in Monmouth County, N.J. The Federal Aviation Administration said the plane was registered to Delaware Environmental Development Service of Wilmington. There was no listing for the company in Wilmington.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWA-CRASH-ATHENS-500A;N;D;AMP;ADD-NYT (ATTN: N.Y., Greece) SECURITY IN ATHENS BETTER THAN AT JFK, EXPERTS SAYS (lh) By PAM BELLUCK c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: Immediately after the crash of TWA Flight 800 on July 17, speculation focused on the possibility that the plane had been sabotaged at its previous stop before New York, the airport in Athens, Greece.

The airport has had a reputation for lax security since 1985, when terrorists hijacked TWA Flight 847 departing from Athens and tortured and killed a U.S. Navy diver on board. In March, the Federal Aviation Administration issued a travel warning for the airport, but lifted it in May after a new training program for airport police began.

Airline and airport staffs based in Athens and New York, along with aviation security experts, say that Hellenikon International Airport in Athens has more security precautions in effect than Kennedy International Airport. In fact, these experts say, European airports have gone much further toward combating the threat of explosives on airplanes than airports in the United States.

``Our focus has been anti-hijacking, as opposed to anti-sabotage,'' said Billie Vincent, a former director of security with the FAA and now a private airline security consultant. ``The threat changed, but we did not change our focus.''

For example, before the plane left Athens on the morning of July 17 as Flight 881 to New York, a security firm that is a subsidiary of TWA searched for bombs, contraband or suspicious items in hidden parts of the aircraft, like the panels that line the luggage compartment and the crevices underneath the toilet or other bathroom fixtures.

Such a security sweep was not done when the plane landed at Kennedy Airport or before it took off for Paris. Other airlines, including United, Avianca and Air Jamaica, which stop along several known drug smuggling routes, hire private security companies to conduct such sweeps before their planes take off from Kennedy. Many of the companies also monitor the people who clean the airplane when it is on the ground, to make sure they do not plant drugs on the aircraft. TWA, which does not travel to countries that are on prominent drug routes, does not.
Takis Tassopoulos, director of the Aviation Security Division in Athens, said Greek police dog units inspect each flight leaving for New York.

Also in Athens, hand luggage is X-rayed twice, when passengers enter the terminal and just before they get on the plane, reducing the possibility that someone could place an explosive device in a passenger's carry-on luggage. At Kennedy Airport, hand luggage is X-rayed only upon entering the terminal, which is supposed to be sealed off from anyone who is not a passenger or an employee.
Air cargo is also more strictly scrutinized in Athens, said a representative of a U.S. air carrier there who insisted on anonymity.

``We secure all our cargo,'' said the official, who said most American carriers in Greece have their own cargo X-ray machines. ``I can't tell you we X-ray everything. But there are systems in place so everything is secured. Cargo is often manually searched.''

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWA-CRASH-EVIDENCE-2TAKES-NYT INVESTIGATORS SEE `EERIE SIMILARITIES' WITH OTHER AIRLINERS THAT BLEW UP (With TWA-CRASH) (sw) By DON VAN NATTA JR. c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: NEW YORK A;N;D;MD; When an explosion ripped through a French airliner flying over the Sahara in 1989, the blast severed the DC-10's front end from the rest of the plane, which stayed aloft for about 20 seconds before plunging into the ground. The black boxes showed that everything on board was normal until a jarring, split-second noise was followed by silence.
Two days later, investigators said the crash was caused by a bomb.

When Pan Am Flight 103 blew up over Lockerbie, Scotland, in December 1988, the nose of the aircraft broke away from the rest of the plane, scattering debris over 80 square miles of Scottish countryside. The black boxes showed everything on board was normal, until a split-second noise, followed by silence.
Within three days, investigators said the probable cause was a bomb.

In both cases, investigators based their pronouncements that the airplanes were destroyed by bombs not on forensic evidence found in a laboratory, but instead on early examinations of wreckage and the circumstances of the crashes.

In some ways, the circumstances surrounding the explosion of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 on July 17 are strikingly similar to the bombings of the other two. An explosion caused Flight 800's front end to break away from the rest of the Boeing 747, which continued to fly for about 20 seconds before becoming engulfed by a fireball. Flight 800's black boxes show that everything on board was normal until a split-second sound was followed by silence.

Yet two weeks after Flight 800 exploded off the coast of Long Island, federal officials have not determined the cause of the crash, or even publicly declared their strong, private suspicions that a bomb, possibly hidden in the forward cargo hold, destroyed the aircraft. The investigators on Long Island also have something the investigators of the other two bombings did not have: dozens of eyewitness accounts that the plane exploded in midair.

Investigators explain their caution by saying they do not want to leap to conclusions that might later be proved wrong. Several officials in Washington said that some White House officials appeared eager to respond aggressively to the crash with condemnations of terrorism. But, the officials said, Justice Department officials did not want to exaggerate the threat of terrorism, and were wary of offering conclusions without clear-cut evidence.

In addition, some officials said, the wariness goes beyond the TWA flight itself. They said federal security officials, preoccupied by terror concerns at the Olympics, have wanted to avoid declaring the crash a terrorist act because of fears that such a determination would provoke domestic and foreign extremists.

At each daily briefing, James Kallstrom, the assistant director of the FBI in New York, says, ``The investigation is continuing,'' and he refuses to say a bomb is the most likely cause of the explosion. Officials said they would not declare the crash to be a result of a bomb until they had found traces of bomb materials on wreckage from the crash.

On both the Lockerbie jet and the French airliner, a bomb was hidden in a piece of luggage stored in the front cargo hold. The force of the blast caused the front of both planes to split off in midair.
Because Flight 800 broke apart in a similar way, investigators have privately speculated that the front cargo hold was the most likely place a bomb was hidden.
``There are so many similarities, it's almost eerie,'' said one federal official, who insisted on anonymity. ``It would be a major surprise if this turned out to be some mechanical failure.''

In the 14 days since the crash of the TWA jet, a powerful dynamic has settled over the inquiry. Federal investigators refuse to say publicly what they overwhelmingly agree on in private: a powerful explosive destroyed the plane.

Investigators are always reluctant to declare the official cause of an airplane crash until there is conclusive physical evidence. In the investigations of the downings of Union de Transports Ariens Flight 772, the one that crashed in Africa, and Pan Am Flight 103, investigators had the distinct advantage of recovering airplane wreckage over land. Some pieces clearly showed characteristics consistent with an explosive.

But Flight 800 investigators have had to retrieve pieces of potential evidence from the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean, 120 feet below the surface, which has made the hunt for conclusive evidence that much more difficult.

Those same challenges faced officials more than a decade ago when they investigated the crash of an Air-India 747, which was bombed off the coast of Ireland in June 1985. The wreckage settled 6,700 feet below the surface of the Irish Sea, and it took more than six months before officials declared it to be a bomb.
(MORE)
nn

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWA-SHIPS-ART-BOS (ART ADV.: A graphic has been sent to NYTNS clients. Non-subscribers can make individual purchases by calling 212-556-4204 or -1927.) RECOVERY VESSELS: VARIED HISTORY AND FUNCTIONS (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By DAVID L. CHANDLER c.1996 The Boston Globe

TEXT.p: The Navy ships Grasp and Grapple were built to rescue or tow ships or submarines in distress and to salvage sunken vessels, but their work this week on the recovery of TWA Flight 800 is not the first time they have been used to retrieve aircraft A;N;D;MD; or even spacecraft.
Less than two months after it was commissioned, the Grasp, the older of the two vessels, was used in 1986 to pick up pieces of the space shuttle Challenger from the sea floor off Florida.

The Grapple, commissioned a year later, was once used to recover two F-14 jets that had crashed in 190 feet of water, although a Navy spokesman declined to specify where or when this operation took place. More conventionally, it has towed decommissioned nuclear submarines to their final ports, it has towed three minesweepers to the Persian Gulf before the Gulf War, and it helped with harbor cleanup in the aftermath of Hurricane Hugo.

The two ships working on the TWA effort off Long Island are the most advanced salvage ships in the world, and they are outfitted with the latest in equipment for surveying the sea floor, supporting teams of divers and raising debris, the Navy says.

For the TWA salvage, the ships' most important equipment are Remotely Operated Vehicles, or ROVs A;N;D;MD; small unpiloted submersibles, connected by cables to the ship. The submirsibles carry cameras, sonar and laser equipment, and claws to grab and retrieve objects. They are controlled from the ship by operators who watch television screens displaying the ROVs' sea floor view. They are capable of diving to 7,200 feet, although the TWA operation is in relatively shallow water, only 100 to 120 feet deep.

Much of the technology they employ is relatively new. In particular, the advent of the Global Positioning System satellites should make it much easier for divers to locate precisely specific targets that have been identified with the side-scan sonar used to map the area. The system can pinpoint a location to within a few feet.

The robotic submersibles also carry advanced scanning systems that use a narrow beam of laser light to locate objects on the sea floor. A small moving mirror reflects the laser beam back and forth across the bottom, as a light receptor builds up an image of the debris field. The image is created one line at a time as the submirsible is towed along, much as a computer's flatbed scanner translates an image into digital data one line at a time.
This is the first time the laser scanner has been used in an actual salvage operation, said a Navy spokesman, Lt. j.g. Joe Walker.

But even with the best of equipment, the skill of the operator can make a big difference, said James Bellingham, director of the underwater vehicle laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. For one thing, in the murky environment of the sea floor, it can be very difficult to get a sense of the scale of objects located by the sonar or laser devices.

To illustrate, Bellingham cited a research project he worked on in New Hampshire's Lake Winnipesaukee. A submersible found an object the researchers thought was a coffee cup. Pulled to the surface, it was found to be a chamber pot. ``We couldn't gauge what the size was by looking at the video,'' he said.

Locating pieces of the aircraft on the ocean floor is difficult enough; recovering them is even trickier, Bellingham said. ``It's a tough thing to do, and very much depends on surface conditions,'' he said.

There are three basic ways to recover objects: with a ``lifting bag,'' a canvas bag that is placed around the object and filled with air to cause it to rise to the surface; using an ROV to grasp the object in its claws and carry it up; or attaching cables to it and hoisting it directly to the ship.
The ROV is by far the gentlest and the least likely to cause further damage to the object, said Navy spokesman Walker.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWA-CRASH-MEGADATA-ART-2NDTAKE-NYT BOHEMIA, N.Y.: agency's concern.

TEXT.p: Yet, in the case of the TWA crash, Megadata's records proved invaluable to federal officials.

After Keller's phone call, safety board investigators and FBI agents went to Megadata's office to view charts and determine what other aircraft were in position to see the final moments of Flight 800.

Eyewitness reports are considered by aviation experts to be extremely unreliable, and the Megadata information helped establish whether the other pilots were in positions to see what they claimed to see.

Based on FAA radar scans that emanated from Riverhead, Megadata's charts indicated that two aircraft A;N;D;MD; an Army Black Hawk helicopter and an Air National Guard C-130 cargo plane A;N;D;MD; were indeed in position to have observed the fireball.

FAA radar systems of the type used in Riverhead send out pulses of energy that are reflected off metal objects in the sky, making blips on a screen. The systems also send out electronic queries, asking the identity and altitude of planes with on-board transponders A;N;D;MD; special radios that can respond to the FAA queries by emitting electronic identification codes one one-millionth of a second later.

Subtracting that microsecond and dividing by the speed of light, the FAA knows the range, or how far away the plane is. By keeping track of precisely where the circular-scan radar beam is pointed when it asks the question, the FAA knows the direction, or bearing, of the aircraft.
Megadata's system simply eavesdrops. The main components are a receive-only antenna, about 5 feet high, which can be miles from the nearest airport, and a work station to process the data.

Although the company is searching for more customers, the reason some buyers have been willing to pay $250,000 or so for a Megadata system can be traced to the tight FAA strictures on air-to-ground communications.

When a plane is below 10,000 feet a ``sterile cockpit'' must be maintained with no work or conversation not directly related to flying the plane. That includes a ban on talk by crew members to dispatchers at their airlines.

For incoming flights, the radio blackout can leave airline ground crews in the dark about precisely whether a plane will arrive in time to let passengers make connecting flights or whether controllers have put the plane into a low-altitude holding pattern.

And even if radio contact were permitted, when several dozen of an airline's planes are to land within minutes of one another, calling them all would be too time-consuming, according to Capt. William B. Cotton, United's manager of air traffic and flight systems.
United has become Megadata's largest client, using the systems in Chicago, Denver, San Francisco, Los Angeles and at Dulles International near Washington.

``It's a very, very clever invention,'' Cotton said. With the click of a mouse, he said, United's dispatchers can view all planes aloft in the vicinity, or simply all United planes, or focus on a single aircraft. The system gives ground crews an estimated time of arrival that is more accurate than pilots or dispatchers have been able to provide, Cotton said.

If a plane is going to be late, United uses the system to decide, for example, whether to hold other planes on the ground to let passengers make their connections. If its plane is in a holding pattern above 10,000 feet, the airline can also tell its pilot how long the wait is likely to be to help decide whether to divert to another airport A;N;D;MD; information that the FAA generally does not provide, Cotton said.
Airport managers use Megadata's information mostly to enforce noise-abatement ordinances.
``We get complaints all the time,'' said Ron Wilson, a spokesman for San Francisco International Airport, which has used the Megadata system to resolve hundreds of complaints in the last few years.
``People say: `I saw a 747 come over my house at 500 feet. I know it was 500 feet because I could see the pilots. I could read the numbers. I could see the wheels.' ''

Using the Megadata work station, Wilson said airport officials could enter the location and the time into the work station and quickly determine the facts. ``We can tell them, it wasn't 500 feet A;N;D;MD; it was 3,500 feet,'' he said.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWA-CRASH-392A;N;D;AMP;ADD-NYT INVESTIGATORS: TWA EXPLOSION DIDN'T ORIGINATE NEAR COCKPIT (With TWA-CRASH-FAMILY) (kd) By DON VAN NATTA Jr. c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: NEW YORK A;N;D;MD; After picking apart some of the wadded remains of the cockpit of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, investigators concluded Tuesday that the catastrophic explosion that destroyed the Boeing 747 most likely did not originate inside the cockpit or in the electronics bay beneath it.

They were partly persuaded by a surprising discovery found in the ton of wreckage that had been the jet's cockpit: The circles of glass that cover many of the cockpit dials, and even a light bulb above a staircase that led to the plane's upper deck, had somehow survived the crash intact.

``You have this mass of wreckage and yet things from that area are relatively the way they were before the accident,'' said Robert T. Francis, vice chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board. ``There is no indication at this point of anything in that area that would give cause for concern in terms of something having initiated there.''

A senior investigator who looked at the cockpit wreckage Tuesday said that one of the plane's altimeters A;N;D;MD; instruments that show the plane's altitude A;N;D;MD; was frozen with a reading of 13,100 feet. Altimeters are mechanically driven instruments that do not depend on electricity to work, so the finding suggests that the mechanics continued working for several seconds after the initial explosion, at about 13,700 feet.

Federal investigators continued their search for the cause of the crash Tuesday, the 20th day since Flight 800 exploded in midair off Long Island and plunged into the Atlantic Ocean, killing all 230 people on board. On the seas and on the shore, investigators said they made a modest amount of progress, though they still have not determined if the plane crash was caused by a bomb, a missile attack or a mechanical malfunction.

At the former Grumman hangar in Calverton, investigators on Tuesday began piecing together the fractured parts of the airplane. They also pulled about one-third of the cockpit wreckage off the one-ton ball of metal, essentially unwrapping it.

James K. Kallstrom, the assistant director of the FBI's New York office, said he had sent many agents who had been working in Suffolk County back to their home offices, mostly in New York City. Criminal investigators are anxious for the cause to be determined, he said, adding: ``We are in a bit of a waiting pattern.''

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWA-CRASH-BOS TWA PROBERS SEE LITTLE CHANCE OF MORE BODIES RECOVERED (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By FRED KAPLAN c.1996 The Boston Globe

TEXT.p: SMITHTOWN, N.Y. A;N;D;MD; Investigators said Wednesday that they have given up hope of finding the remaining 35 victims from the wreckage of TWA Flight 800.

In the three weeks since the crash, divers have brought up 195 of the 230 passengers and crew who were aboard the jumbo jet on July 17. But as Navy salvage ships continue to bring up large pieces of wreckage from the plane, it is becoming less likely that many more bodies remain hidden.

Robert Francis, vice chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, said finding victims remains the top priority. But ``there's just not the kind of wreckage out there anymore where we'd expect to find bodies,'' he said.
He said that families have been told and that they are ``pretty understanding.''
In another development, the Federal Aviation Administration is expected to announce Tjirdau that it will requiring testing of fuel pumps on 747s for electrical resistance.

There are 14 pumps on the jumbo jet's wings, and low resistance indicates they could develop arcing that might lead to a fuel leak and a possible fire. In May 1995, a fire related to a fuel pump leak broke out in the wheelwell of a Japan Airlines plane. It was extinguished before the plane took off.
The TWA jet experienced a power loss and its cockpit-voice and flight data recorders ended abruptly, which investigators say would not have happened in the case of an engine failure or explosion.

In the past few days, as fewer and fewer victims have been found, investigators have shifted their attention to recovering pieces of the plane that could be crucial to solving the mystery of what caused the 747 to explode in midair on July 17.

The salvage ship USS Grasp pulled up a 75-foot-long section of the plane's right wing Wednesday, with a chunk of the fuselage attached to it. Francis said he saw burn marks on the wing, but he warned against drawing conclusions from that, noting that the ocean's surface was on fire when the plane crashed and the wing could have been burned when it hit the water.

Technicians onboard the Grasp were working on cutting the wing in two, so that it would fit onto the tugboat bringing pieces of the wreckage back to the Grumman aircraft hangar on Long Island, where they are being analyzed.

Investigators are also now interested in bringing up the plane's engines as quickily as possible. Two of the four engines A;N;D;MD; and a piece of the third A;N;D;MD; have been found by sonar detectors.

Francis said the engines are key evidence, mainly because they might show where the explosion came from A;N;D;MD; a missile from outside the plane or a bomb from within, and, if the latter, where in the plane.
He said a ``rub strip'' is inside the engine, surrounding its fan blades. When the blades rotate, the strip keeps them from damaging the engine's shell.

``In an accident, you can sometimes tell from the rub strip what kind of forces have come to bear on the aircraft,'' Francis said. ``You can end up with the fan clipping part of the rub strip. An engineer can figure out where that force came from.''
James Kallstrom, the FBI assistant director involved in the investigation, said, ``We're very pleased with the speed of the recovery of parts of the aircraft.''

When asked if it might be a few weeks or more before they figure out what caused the explosion, he replied: ``It could very well be. I would hope it won't be that long ... Whether it's a week or two weeks or four days, I don't know.''

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-DEM-PLANE-CRASH-ART-1STLD-500A;N;D;AMP;ADD-NYT (SUBS to add names of victims in last graf.) AIR FORCE PLANES CRASH KILLS MEMBERS OF CLINTON SUPPORT STAFF (ART ADV: Map has been sent to NYT graphic clients. Non-subscribers can make individual purchase by calling 212-556-4204 or 1927.) (kd) By TIM WEINER c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: WASHINGTON A;N;D;MD; A military plane carrying a Secret Service agent and an Air Force crew of eight crashed into a mountain minutes after taking off from President Clinton's Wyoming retreat late Saturday night, killing everyone on board, officials said.

The C-130 aircraft was carrying the Secret Service agent and an automobile used by security officers in presidential motorcades. It was bound from Jackson Hole, Wyo., where Clinton spent his holiday, to New York City, where he was to attend a 50th birthday party Sunday night.

The plane took off from the Jackson Hole airport at about 10:45 p.m. Saturday night, according to state and local officials in Wyoming and an Air Force spokesman in Texas, where the crew of the plane was based.

About three minutes later, after flying about 15 miles southeast and reaching an altitude of about 10,000 feet, the C-130 slammed into the side of Sheep Mountain, known locally as Sleeping Indian. It exploded in a fireball visible in Teton Village, a resort town 20 miles away. The crash site was about 1,000 feet below the 11,300-foot summit.

A party of 28 searchers set out for the remote site on foot and on horseback a few hours later. But the impact of the explosion, with the plane hitting the mountain above the timberline at 200 miles an hour or more with about 18 tons of fuel on board, was so severe that they found little more than smouldering fragments.

The C-130 has generally been considered an unusually safe aircraft A;N;D;MD; a slow, fat, reliable workhorse, nicknamed the Hercules, and is used mostly to haul people and equipment around the world. But this crash was the third fatal one involving a C-130 in the past 15 months.

Four weeks ago, a C-130 flown by the Belgian Air Force crashed in the Netherlands, killing 32 people, most of them members of a Dutch military orchestra. And in May 1995, a C-130 carrying six Air Force reservists went down in southern Idaho after an engine caught fire, killing all aboard.
Saturday night's crash was also the third time in the past 16 months that an Air Force plane has carried U.S. government officials to their death.

In April 1995, an Air Force C-21, a military version of a Learjet executive aircraft, crashed in Alabama and killed Clark G. Fiester, an assistant Air Force secretary. A year later, two Air Force pilots trying to land their military Boeing 737 at Dubrovnik, Croatia, flew straight into the highest peak for miles around, killing all 35 people aboard, including Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown.

A study of military aircraft mishaps published six months ago by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, found that 73 percent of the most severe accidents in 1994 and 1995 were caused by human error, mistakes by pilots or, more rarely, ground crews or air traffic controllers.

At the White House, shortly before departing for New York, Clinton said the deaths of the Secret Service agent and the Air Force crew members were ``especially painful to us because they worked for me and did an invaluable service, and I am very sad about it.'' The president and his family had left Wyoming for Washington a few hours before the crash on Saturday.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-BIZTRAVEL-COLUMN-BOS (f and t coding) LOGAN AIRPORT BEEFING UP SECURITY (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By JERRY ACKERMAN c.1996 The Boston Globe

TEXT.p: Boston's Logan Airport expects by the end of next week to have two explosives-detection units ready to roll out at a moment's notice to sniff out dangerous objects in luggage and cargo compartments, or even at check-in gates.

Each weighing about 45 pounds, the units are made by Boston-area companies, Ion Track Instruments Inc. of Wilmington and Thermedics Inc. of Woburn. Airport security director Joseph Lawless said that along with Logan's five trained bomb-sniffing dogs, the units will provide another level of assurance for a flying public deeply worried about in-flight safety.

Three out of four corporate travel managers polled by the National Business Travel Association last month, after the crash of TWA Flight 800, said they would be willing to pay a premium on airline tickets to improve airport security.

Respondents to the poll also chided the government and airlines for failing to take security seriously enough. Many of those who opposed paying more said they were concerned that government would only waste the money.

Lawless said Logan is still working out whether to lease or buy the explosives-detection devices. Ion Track's version lists for more than $50,000, and Thermedics' for over $150,000. The two designs also function differently, he said, but having both will provide a testing ground for their effectiveness.
Other security procedures put into force after Flight 800 went down already are complicating the lives of passengers who book trips ``electronically,'' without traditional tickets.

Electronic ticketing eliminates paperwork and boosts airline profit margins. Passengers get a confirmation number when they reserve their flights. At the gate, they get a boarding pass by repeating their number and showing a photo identification card.

The system didn't work, though, when airports, including Logan, tightened up who can get to the gates. Lawless said Logan took this step because its higher number of overseas travelers could make the airport more vulnerable to terrorism.
Now, airlines that don't issue paper tickets must send agents to meet their passengers at the metal detectors. With passenger lists in hand, they check in each person individually. --- A;N;D;QC;

JetTrain, the start-up low-fare airline that was going to fly from Boston to Newark beginning this month, has shifted gears and now will fly a triangular route between Boston, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh, starting in mid-September. JetTrain has been flying from Pittsburgh to Orlando, Fla., for the past year. Airline spokesman Carmine Cardillo said the latest change is aimed at filling the void left when two other low-cost carriers, ValuJet and Nation's Air, ended Boston-Philadelphia service. --- A;N;D;QC;

Wednesday is the launch date for Korean Air's new Boston-Seoul service, three days a week via New York with a stop to refuel in Anchorage. The first plane lands at Logan at 9 p.m. A ceremonial ribbon-cutting is scheduled at the British Airways gates at 10. Korean Air says this is the first same-plane service ever from Boston to Asia. Massport says it's going to hold a New England Lobster Festival in Seoul in October to promote this region as a tourist and business destination. --- A;N;D;QC;

About those antlers you might want to bring home as a trophy from your hunting trip: TWA has revised its entire fee schedule for unusual baggage since details, compiled by Best Fares magazine, ran in this column. TWA has lifted its ban on antlers and now accepts them at the discretion of airport agents. Also, skis, golf clubs and fishing gear are now checked without charge versus the fees of $45 to $75 that were previously posted. Surfboards still cost $50 extra, as do bicycles, pet kennels and scuba gear.
But, according to Best Fares researcher Elaine Hewlett, cyclists can ship their wheels free now on United Airlines A;N;D;MD; although United now says it charges $50 for scuba equipment. --- A;N;D;QC;

Two national luxury hotel chains, Fairmont and Loew's, are offering a luxury upgrade on American Airlines flights and 1,000 frequent flier points on American if the room booking is charged to a Visa card. You have to ask for this deal when you reserve ... USAir has authorized its pilots to disconnect the seat-back phone system in the event of an emergency. Pilots last week got a memo declaring that the airline ``prefers to furnish press releases for in-flight anomalies instead of having this information reported live via telephone from the aircraft.'' A USAir spokesman later said that language ``has been rescinded'' but defended the policy.
