(Jerry Ackerman is a member of the Globe staff. He can be reached by mail at The Boston Globe, Box 2378, Boston, MA 02107-2378, or by e-mail at ackerman(AT)globe.com)

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-C-130-CRASH-CLINTON-PLANE-NYTSF CLINTON'S C-130 CRASH HAS A CHILLING MESSAGE (To publish this ``separate buy'' article, it must be purchased the rate is not prohibitive from one of these New York Times Syndicate sales representatives: (--U.S., Canada and the Pacific: CONNIE WHITE in Kansas City at 1-800-444-0267 or 816-822-8448, or fax her at 816-822-1444. (--Europe and Asia: KARL HORWITZ in Paris at 47-42-17-11; fax, 47-42-80-44 or 47-42-18-81; telex, 282-942. (--Latin America: PAUL FINCH in Los Angeles, 310-996-0075; fax, 310-996-0089. (PLEASE NOTE: This article has been transmitted twice into the ``k'' commentary and ``a'' general news files. By TOM WICKER (Distributed by New York Times Special Features)

TEXT.p: The crash of an Air Force C-130 carrying equipment for use by Bill Clinton is fair if gruesome warning that some day an American president may be killed in an air crash.

The Clinton family had departed Jackson Hole, Wyo., in another plane only hours before the C-130 slammed into a mountainside shortly after takeoff. All nine persons aboard, including a Secret Service agent, were killed.
The death of Commerce Secretary Ron Brown in April in a somewhat similar plane crash in Croatia offered the same warning.
The destruction of TWA Flight 800 off Long Island this summer, perhaps by a bomb or even a missile, adds the chilling possibility of terrorist assault.
All these incidents, plus others A;N;D;MD; three fatal C-130 crashes have occurred in 15 months A;N;D;MD; should suggest at least two common sense developments.

A;N;D;MD; 1) As do many husbands and wives and some top business executives, presidents and vice presidents should follow the practice of never flying together. Candidates for those offices should take the same precaution, even if it hinders their ability to campaign together.

A;N;D;MD; 2) The historic custom of presidential nominees choosing their vice presidential running mates without regard to their experience or ability to take over the presidency, if necessary, must no longer be accepted.

Bob Dole, the recent Republican president nominee, appears to have pondered his choice carefully and named a qualified man in Jack Kemp, the former congressman and Cabinet member. So did Clinton, when he chose Sen. Al Gore in 1992.

As recently as 1988, however, George Bush made an apparently quixotic choice in J. Danforth Quayle In 1952 Richard Nixon was chosen by Republican leaders A;N;D;MD; not by the nominee, Dwight Eisenhower A;N;D;MD; less for his presidential qualifications than for his anti-Communist fame and acceptability to the party's ``old guard.''

A constitutional amendment is not necessary to improve the chances that a qualified vice presidential nominee will be chosen. And, anyway, such an amendment probably would be hard to write and impossible to enforce. What is really needed is for American voters to turn their backs on a presidential nominee who makes a blatantly political or otherwise unsuitable choice for vice president.
Or perhaps presidential nominees should run alone and, if elected, use provisions of the 22nd Amendment to nominate someone for vice president.

That person then would have to undergo extensive congressional investigation and confirmation A;N;D;MD; as did Nelson Rockefeller, when he was nominated for vice president by Gerald Ford in 1974. Ford had been chosen by President Nixon when the sitting vice president, Spiro T. Agnew, had been forced to resign.

Proponents of air travel will protest, no doubt accurately, that it is safer than any form of ground transportation. That statistical argument overlooks the fact that an air crash is far more likely to be fatal to all involved than are other forms of accident.
And presidents now travel almost exclusively by air A;N;D;MD; including helicopters for short hauls.

It will be argued, too, that no aircraft could be more carefully maintained or skillfully operated than those used by a president. Thousands of commercial passengers can testify to being held up in scheduled takeoffs or landings because right-of-way was being cleared for Air Force One.
If safe air travel can be guaranteed, it certainly is for the occupant of the White House.

Still, no amount of precaution or skill can preclude the unexpected or predict the unpredictable. And if terrorism is a threat, as TWA 800 investigators may conclude, what juicier target could there be than a plane carrying a president and his entourage?

When I was The New York Times White House correspondent during the Kennedy administration, a small group of us termed ourselves ``White House regulars'' A;N;D;MD; meaning we went on every presidential trip, no matter how insignificant or unlikely to produce news. We did so to keep a ``death watch'' on the president A;N;D;MD; though none of us really believed, until Nov. 22, 1963, that it was necessary.

President Kennedy, of course, was murdered on the ground. That does not alter the rising odds that some day or some night, somewhere in an unaccountable world, sometime in the uncharted future, a high-flying president will be brought to earth by chance, or by malevolent design.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWA-CRASH-PROBE-7THTAKE-NYT NEW YORK: the machine.

TEXT.p: The Egis machine sniffs vapors of invisible particles. It can detect C4, a plastic explosive made by the U.S. military, Semtex, an explosive manufactured in Eastern Europe, and Detasheet, a plastic compound that comes in quarter-inch thick sheets and that contains PETN.
A 10-pound vacuum sniffs a sample of air, which is then transferred to a 4-feet-by-2-feet metal box. The machine's computer spits out a chemical profile.
Certain federal agents, calling the FBI's laboratory in Washington a ``black hole,'' remained convinced that the bureau was hiding its positive lab confirmations.

``There was one problem after another with this investigation, from weather to lab results,'' a federal investigator said. ``People became incredibly frustrated. Then, with information sacred and everybody wishing for the smoking gun, people got paranoid. It was like separate cells were formed. Certain people would only speak with certain other people.''

While secrets were preserved, there were relaxations of the wariness. For instance, two federal agents, after staring at a fragment of aircraft, asked a safety board expert nearby for help. He, in turn, had to consult with a Boeing engineer. In a moment, the manufacturer's representative identified the part.
But some investigators began to suspect that with millions of dollars at stake, industry representatives were reading into the wreckage what they wanted to see.
One industry expert was sure he had seen ``shock waves'' in the fuselage, a clear indication of a bomb. Law enforcement authorities said it was unclear what the damage was, and what meaning it held.

And according to a federal official, the people representing the engine's manufacturer, Pratt A;N;D;AMP; Whitney, did not hide their relief when the four engines had been brought to shore, opened and declared a non-factor.
``There are camps, divided camps,'' one investigator said.
The competing conclusions only fueled the news coverage of the investigation, and thus the public's sense of what was true, what was coming.

``The most frustrating thing is all the people that are talking to the news media, giving different versions and having different agendas,'' Kallstrom said. Later, he added, ``I have a problem with anyone rooting for anything. And if they are rooting for anything that's unique to their sphere of influence or their domain, they're part of the problem, not part of the solution.''

There was no solution to the disabling sadness. Investigators, wearing surgical masks against the odors, created cardboard boxes for each victim. Into each went every piece of personal belonging that could be linked to an individual A;N;D;MD; wedding rings, wallets, a coloring book.
Then there were the personal belongings and the clothing that did not have obvious owners A;N;D;MD; ``orphaned'' bits, the agents called them.
``You just have to find a way to keep sorting through it all,'' said an investigator who had worked on a handful of airline bombing investigations.
``Pick through the debris, run your eyes and hands over what appears interesting, test it, test it again. You wait for that jewel. Of course, it's a sick jewel, in a way.''
THE PROCESS: An Epic Exercise Of Elimination
Despite the initial chaos and the ensuing divisions of opinion and operational style, a unifying thread came to course through the investigation. The thread was frustration.

The investigation, after all, had become one large, detailed map of dead ends. Results from the forensics lab were inconclusive. Theories of structural malfunction, from probability's outer fringes, were undone by hard data. The ocean stubbornly refused to give up solid leads.
The entire investigation, then, became an epic exercise in elimination. Knocking down theories A;N;D;MD; in their entirety or in their speculative detail A;N;D;MD; became the most satisfying work.
The momentum for erasing a mechanical failure as the cause of the crash gathered early and never really relented.

The aircraft had recently been through some of the most rigorous examinations the industry requires. The black boxes revealed only sudden silence after a split-second sound spoke volumes to investigators, downgrading malfunction's standing as a theory.

Within days of their discovery, a second major site of debris, the front of the plane, was located. The inference was inescapable: The plane had split A;N;D;MD; just as Pan Am 103 had over Lockerbie, Scotland.
A third debris field sprinkled with luggage and tiny scraps of metal underscored the suspicion for everyone that the malfunction theory was fantasy.
The engines proved fine four weeks into the inquiry; the fuel tank, the last, best hope for theorists of mechanical failure, did not appear to have exploded as the initiating incident.

The safety investigators privately conceded they had no known way of explaining through mechanical failure what had occurred. Even the mantra of their methodology A;N;D;MD; the history of aviation accidents is a history of things that never happened before A;N;D;MD; was recited without enthusiasm.

The belief that a bomb destroyed the airplane was always strongest. But even it suffered under the waves of negation: The cockpit, briefly thought to be the location of the explosion, was found mangled, but with parts of it, such as glass instrument dials, tellingly intact. It was thus ruled out as the site of the blast.

Four weeks into the investigation, the front cargo bins, the location of choice for numerous previous bombers, came up empty of evidence. The bomb experts, not budging from their instinctive conclusion that a bomb had done the damage, said, in the words of one agent, ``No one could have imagined that 60 percent of the plane would be up and at least some absolute proof of a bomb not have been found.''
The longshot theories, then, survived.
Kallstrom, the central processor of all theories (including the absurd E-mail tips of extra-terrestrials), had a particular fascination with the idea that a missile had struck the aircraft.
``I gave up being surprised at anything a long time ago,'' Kallstrom said early on.
(MORE)

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWA-CRASH-TERRORISTS-525A;N;D;AMP;ADD-NYT (ATTN: N.Y., Va., Fla., R.I., Hawaii, Brazil, Iran., Israel, Japan, Libya, Germany, U.K., Egypt, Lebanon, Italy, Greece, Germany) AUTHORITIES EYE TERRORISTS WHO TARGET PLANES (lh) By DOUGLAS FRANTZ c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: NEW YORK A;N;D;MD; In June, a few weeks before the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 off Long Island, leaders of several Middle Eastern terrorist organizations backed by the Iranian government met in Teheran, Iran, to plan terrorist acts, intelligence officials said Friday.

Among them was the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, an organization that has been linked to airplane bombings in the past, according to the officials. And its leader, Ahmed Jabril, came to the meeting to ask for permission to carry out terrorist attacks against American interests, one intelligence official said.

The organizations that attended the meeting, and the session itself, are among a number of avenues that federal investigators are following in their inquiry into the crash of the TWA jet, according to the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Although the FBI has not declared that the plane crashed as the result of a criminal act, the FBI crime lab has found traces of PETN, a component of plastic explosives, on a piece of wreckage from the cabin of the plane. Investigators noted that PETN was a component of bombs used in past terrorist bombings of airplanes.

The intelligence officials cautioned that they had no evidence linking the June meeting in Teheran to the crash on July 17. They note that Iran is not known to have targeted Americans in recent years and that the time span between the meeting and the crash may have been too short to execute a complex operation.

But a senior federal investigator working on the TWA case said investigators were interested in learning more about the meeting. At the same time, though, investigators say they are examining many other individuals and organizations in their inquiry.

If Flight 800 is proved to have been brought down by a bomb, as most investigators strongly believe, it remains possible that no foreign terrorists were involved. The crash could have been the result of a domestic criminal act. Still, if the TWA crash is eventually blamed on a terrorist attack, the investigators said Jabril and the others who were in Teheran would be high on a short list of suspects.

Other terrorist groups identified as present at the Teheran meeting included leaders of the Lebanese-based Hezbollah, which has been linked to the 1983 bomb blast in Beirut that killed 241 U.S. Marines, and the Egyptian branch of Islamic Jihad, which is loyal to Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman. He was convicted of plotting to blow up the United Nations, and his followers were convicted of the bomb attack on the World Trade Center.

In recent years, a small number of terrorist organizations have demonstrated the capability of bombing an airplane. While investigators have not ruled out the possibility of a previously unknown group, investigators say evidence amassed about the bombs and methods used in previous attacks may yield important clues in the investigation of Flight 800.

``If it was a bomb, determining the kind of bomb and the way it got on the plane will narrow down the universe of suspects,'' said Vincent Cannistraro, a private security consultant and former chief of counterterrorism at the Central Intelligence Agency.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWA-CRASH-PROBE-8THTAKE-NYT NEW YORK: early on.

TEXT.p: To some experts in terrorism and airline security, the notion that a missile had blown the aircraft out of the sky was far-fetched, and several expressed amazement at the ``shelf life of the missile theory.'' The plane was out of range, they said.

But others, Kallstrom included, had a resilient fealty to the rocket theory. He and others could not ignore the dozens of eyewitness accounts testifying to a streaking light intersecting with the aircraft. The details matched in many ways.
In addition, the notion that Stinger missiles from Afghanistan might have made their way into the United States was a longstanding assumption within law enforcement circles.

The presence on the crash scene of officials with the National Security Agency and the Defense Intelligence Agency reinforced in some minds that there might have been some intercepted intelligence regarding a missile attack.

And so the viability of the missile theory A;N;D;MD; which seemed to carry a dread greater than a bomb A;N;D;MD; rose and sank daily, in the minds of Kallstrom and other investigators. Yet, Kallstrom, early on, refused to acknowledge publicly how seriously investigators had taken the possibility of a missile attack.
``I don't want to scare people,'' he said in front of his agents.

Investigators ran down reports of stolen boats on Long Island, and senior investigators three days into the investigation broke down the likelihood of the three causes this way: 45 percent missile, 45 percent bomb, 10 percent malfunction.

Kallstrom ordered his agents to research the Mistral, a French-made missile that could be launched from a tripod and that would have had the range capability. Other experts offered the possibility that a small-engine Cessna might have been equipped to fire a Sidewinder missile.

The missile theory did not go away. Agents spent chunks of their days rereading the eyewitness interviews. A kind of missile cult emerged within the ranks of the agents. The group was never more enthusiastic than when one of the first preliminary positive results registered at the hangar in Calverton showed evidence of PETN, a component found in some missiles.

Meanwhile, the Department of Defense, asked to provide investigators with a full accounting of military activity that might have been going on in the area of the crash, launched such a diligent inquiry that it took days to come up with complete information, according to Kallstrom and Pentagon officials.

Public records showed that the Navy had issued a warning to mariners that it might be conducting ``firing tests'' in a section of the sea roughly 80 nautical miles northeast of the crash scene. The Navy also had an aircraft near the crash site. It briefly helped recover information.

By late July, Kallstrom had doubts about the missile theory, but he never completely let go. And despite the Pentagon's assurances, he refused to rule out a ``friendly fire'' mishap, saying only that ``it's not in the crosshairs of my radar.''

Then, two weeks ago, came the most dramatic moment, which took place in a cramped third-floor laboratory in the J. Edgar Hoover Building in Washington. The endless frustration was snapped. The string of inconclusive results had ended: A positive finding for the explosives was confirmed with the most sophisticated detection machinery in the world.

The revelation of the finding A;N;D;MD; which investigators insist does not rule out a missile A;N;D;MD; sharpened the details of the remaining hunt: find the blast site, and with it the metal wreckage that could be brought before the cameras.

Study the ``sick jewel'' for its signatures that could produce suspects: what contained the bomb, the exact type of explosive used, any available fragment of the detonating device. Microscopic clues had produced breakthroughs for investigators in the Pan Am 103 bombing, a tiny sliver of a Toshiba stereo sending agents to North Africa.
``It doesn't get us all the way where we need to be,'' a senior investigator said of the lab finding.
But if the mystery had not been completely solved, Francis and others believed something strongly. A wonder had been worked.

Yes, it might take a full dredging of the ocean floor before the right hunk of plane was recovered. Yes, things could have gone more smoothly. Yes, the safety board investigators would spend the coming months examining everything and one day recommending a range of thoughts on industry policies on aircraft construction, perhaps even on how the safety board and the FBI might conduct a similar, subsequent investigation.

``What an incredible feat is being accomplished,'' Francis said of the entire effort. ``People say Jacques Cousteau does this all the time, Jacques Cousteau makes it look easy. Well, he's working off Bimini where you can see 94 miles through the water, and he's picking up shellfish, not jagged pieces of aluminum.''
``There is no McDonald's of air safety investigation,'' he said.

DOC.PREAMBLE: PM-HIJACK-COX HIJACKED SUDANESE AIRLINER LANDS IN BRITAIN By LOUIS J. SALOME c.1996 Cox News Service

TEXT.p: STANSTED, England A;N;D;MD; Police negotiated today with several hijackers believed to be Iraqis who seized a Sudan Airways plane with 199 people aboard and demanded that it be flown to Britain.

After nearly five hours of negotiations, 160 passengers, most of them women and children, were allowed to leave the plane. But the other 26 passengers along with 13 crew remained on board along with ``six or seven'' hijackers claiming to be carrying grenades and explosives, police said.
Police said the hijackers were accompanied by their families and had asked to see a member of the Iraqi Community Association in London, an organization that helps Iraqis seeking aslyum.

Essex County police said the passengers were mostly Sudanese, but included Syrians, Saudis, Jordanians and Palestinians. None of the released passengers were mistreated, although three were sick and had been taken to a hospital, police said. Their illnesses were unrelated to the ordeal.
Police were questioning the released hostages at a nearby terminal as negotations with the hijackers, conducted by radio, continued.
``Everyone seems calm and collected. My understanding is that no one has been hurt,'' said Essex police spokeswoman Kim White said.
Sudan Airways Flight 150 was hijacked Monday evening about 25 minutes after it left the Sudanese capital of Khartoum heading for Amman, Jordan.

The Airbus 310 jetliner landed at Larnaca International Airport in Cyprus to refuel before being forced on to London. Cyprus aviation officials quoted one hijacker as saying he wanted political asylum in Britain.

The plane arrived at Stansted, London's third airport 30 miles to the northeast, at 4:30 a.m. today (11:30 p.m., Eastern time, Monday). Armed and masked Essex police officers surrounded the aircraft as it stood in an isolated spot on the tarmac two miles from the terminal.

In hijack situations, British authorities usually direct planes to Stansted, which is especially prepared for such events and is located in a rural area, rather than to the busier Heathrow or Gatwick airports.
It has been 14 years since a hijacked airplane has landed in Britain.
About a dozen police, fire and rescue vehicles were arrayed far from the plane in case of an accident or if the negotiations turned sour.
Police said the hijackers were releasing the passengers in groups of 10 or so at a time and that they hoped more would be freed.
It was the second hijacking this year involving a Sudanese airliner.

On March 24, a Sudan Airways Airbus A320 plane carrying 40 passengers and crew on an internal flight was hijacked to Asmara, the Eritrean capital, where the two Sudanese hijackers surrendered and sought political asylum.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-NORWAY-CRASH-ART-NYT MORE THAN 140 FEARED DEAD IN RUSSIAN AIRLINER CRASH IN ARCTIC (ART ADV: Graphic map is being sent to NYT graphics clients. Non-subscribers can make individual purchase by calling 212-556-4204 or 1927.) (bl) c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: OSLO, Norway A;N;D;MD; A Russian jetliner carrying more than 140 people A;N;D;MD; mostly coal miners and their families A;N;D;MD; crashed into a mountain Thursday on the remote Arctic island of Spitsbergen in Norwegian territory. There appeared to be no survivors, Norwegian authorities said.

The three-engine Tupolev Tu-154 owned by Vnukovo Airlines was nearing the end of a flight from Moscow when it went off course amid low clouds and struck Opera Mountain, a 3,000-foot peak six miles east of Svalbard Airport at Longyearbyen, the island's main settlement.

The passengers were described as Russians and Ukrainians, most of them workers for the Trust Arktik Ugol mining company. They were a relief force for an equal number of miners and family members who had been waiting at the airport to take the same jet back to Moscow.

Russia's ambassador to Norway, Yuri Fokine, said that up to 20 children were aboard the jet, but Norwegian authorities in touch with the airline maintained that the passenger list comprised 125 adults and 4 children, in addition to either 12 or 14 crew members.

Flight controllers reported losing radio contact with the jet at 10:15 a.m. At 12:06 p.m. a Norwegian search party in two helicopters and a light plane found most of the wreckage on a snowy plateau, officials said. The rear section of the jet had tumbled down a cliff, causing a small avalanche.

Five rescue workers who landed at the scene determined that there were no survivors, then left three and a half hours later because of thickening fog, Norway's Rescue Coordination Center said. It said the temperature was in the high 30s.
Fokine praised the rescue effort in an interview with Norwegian television and added, ``There was no sign of life when the helicopters arrived.''
A Norwegian minister, Jan Hoifoedt, informed the group waiting at the airport of the crash.
``The tears flowed,'' Hoifoedt told a radio interviewer. ``Many had friends, work acquaintances and even some family members aboard. It is a huge tragedy for so small a community.''

Spitsbergen is the largest island in the Svalbard archipelago, about 350 miles north of the Norwegian mainland. A 1920 treaty gave Norway ownership of the archipelago, but the Soviet Union acquired mining rights in 1935.

Of Svalbard's population of 2,500, almost two-thirds are citizens of former Soviet republics. They operate two mines A;N;D;MD; in Pyramiden and Barentsburg A;N;D;MD; extracting some 600,000 tons of coal a year, about twice the output of Norwegian mines.

Investigators from Oslo and Moscow are not expected to reach the crash site until Friday morning, when removal of the bodies is to begin. The Norwegian government was also sending criminal investigators, though officials said there was no immediate sign of foul play.

Early this evening a Norwegian helicopter crew managed to lift two prefabricated cabins onto the plateau near the wreckage. From there, two or three sentries were to make sure the site is not disturbed during the night.
``There are about 2,000 polar bears on this island,'' said Rune B. Hansen, the acting governor. ``We haven't seen any around here lately but they are unpredictable and can suddenly be anywhere.''
Though the number of air fatalities in the former Soviet Union has declined in the last two years, it remains alarmingly high compared to what it was during the Soviet era.

When the Soviet airline Aeroflot was broken up five years ago, many new air companies were created. Vnukovo Airlines is one of dozens of these so-called ``babyflots,'' which have been plagued by lack of cash and poor maintenance. Many if not most of the aircraft in the Russian fleets are long past retirement age.
An official at Vnukova Airlines in Moscow refused to comment Thursday night on the crash.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-VALUJET-NYT VALUJET GETS PERMISSION TO FLY AGAIN (bl) By ADAM BRYANT c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: The Federal Aviation Administration said Thursday that Valujet Airlines, grounded for more than two months after a deadly crash in the Everglades, could start flying again under greater agency scrutiny.

The approval, one of two hurdles the airlines must clear before resuming service, comes 10 weeks after the agency ordered a halt to its operations because of systemic safety problems uncovered after the crash on May 11 of a Valujet DC-9 that killed all 110 people aboard.

Valujet also received tentative approval Thursday to resume flights from the Department of Transportation, which evaluates the competence and safety record of an airline's managers as well as the carrier's economic health.
With the department's decision, a seven-day comment period begins during which the agency will receive any objections to letting Valujet resume service.

It will review the objections, give Valujet a chance to respond and then make its final determination. If Valujet clears this second hurdle with no objections, it could be back in the air as soon as next Thursday.
Transportation officials, however, are likely to hear again about Valujet from the Association of Flight Attendants, a union representing flight attendants at the airline.

The union has repeatedly complained to the transportation department in recent weeks that Valujet's senior officers are not fit to run a safe airline in large measure because of the lapses found at Valujet.

The department said Thursday that it had taken into account the union's recent objections in making its tentative decision. A lawyer representing the union, Robert S. Clayman, said Thursday that the union planned to file more complaints.

``What the DOT has suggested today is that the men in charge of the airline were in no way responsible for all of the safety violations that caused their shutdown,'' Mr. Clayman said in an interview. ``We thought it was one strike and you're out, not trial and error.''

John V. Coleman, director of aviation analysis at the department, said in a conference call with reporters that the two top officers of Valujet A;N;D;MD; Robert Priddy, chairman, and Lewis H. Jordan, president A;N;D;MD; had good safety records over their long airline careers. ``Nothing in their background suggests that they have been noncompliant with federal regulations of any kind,'' he said.

The aviation agency said Thursday that Valujet had been approved to resume service with nine aircraft, and could quickly add up to six more. Valujet had 51 aircraft in its fleet when the airline was shut down June 17. The safety lapses that led to Valujet's grounding were not directly linked to the cause of the crash.

Since the grounding of Valujet, the airline had met the agency's requirements for resuming service, including revising its maintenance program and procedures, revising its organizational structure and adding new maintenance and management personnel, and retraining pilots and maintenance workers, the FAA said Thursday. The airline also will initially fly only one type of DC-9.
The FAA also said it would raise the number of inspectors assigned to Valujet to seven from three, and closely scrutinize its plans to expand once it resumes flying.
Valujet executives said Thursday that they hoped to resume service to Atlanta and four as yet unnamed cities in about two weeks.
The FAA appears to have changed its approach to speaking publicly about the safety of Valujet. Immediately after the May 11 crash, top FAA and DOT officials declared Valujet a safe airline.

When asked Thursday whether the FAA now considered Valujet safe, Bill White, deputy director of flight standards at the FAA, responded only by saying that Valujet was in compliance with safety regulations.
``It's up to Valujet to maintain the safe operation of the aircraft,'' he said.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-HELICOPTER-REPORT-BOS OVERSIGHT FAULTED IN POLICE HELICOPTER CRASH REPORT (For use by New York Times News Service clients) By THOMAS C. PALMER JR. c.1996 The Boston Globe

TEXT.p: BOSTON A;N;D;MD; A;N;D;UR; A;N;D;LR; Top State Police officials were warned of management problems within the air wing even before the February 1995 helicopter crash that killed two troopers and two civilians, according to a report issued Friday.

The final administrative report of the State Police on the crash repeats the October 1995 findings of the National Transportation Safety Board on the two contributing causes of the crash A;N;D;MD; State Police management's failure to provide adequate oversight of the air wing, and fuel contamination from an poorly maintained facility in Framingham.

But the report adds explicitly that a third cause of the aircraft's crash into a Memorial Drive boathouse in Cambridge was ``failure of the pilot to execute a proper autorotation,'' a safety procedure designed to allow an emergency landing after engine failure.

The crash of the American Eurocopter ASTAR craft killed two state police troopers and pilots, James Mattaliano and Paul Perry, and two civilian employees of ATA;N;D;AMP;T who were also aboard, Arthur Howell and Michael McCarthy.
Friday's report chronicled two instances in which warnings were sent to State Police management pointing to problems in its aviation wing.

In one case, a civilian manager at Norwood Airport reported observing ``a lack of training activity'' among the police unit and reported complaints about ``training practices and professionalism'' within the air wing.
That manager, who is unnamed but is employed by a company that is a defendant in a lawsuit resulting from the accident, met with top State Police officials in 1993 to express his concerns.

Although he recalls telling the officials, including Secretary of Public Safety Kathleen O'Toole that ``pilots no longer seemed to practice autorotations when returning from a mission as had been past practice,'' neither O'Toole nor two state police majors who attended the meeting recalled that specific warning.

In addition to that manager's warning, in March 1994 Sgt. Richard Welby, an air-wing pilot, wrote a report containing his belief that officers were not being adequately trained in emergency procedures. All pilots later received training, though a recommendation for advanced training had been denied because of a lack of funding.

The report issued Friday said Welby's concerns were communicated to Col. Charles Henderson, but Henderson ``does not recall receiving the document.'' Henderson has since retired as head of the State Police after being pressured to leave, in part because of the fatal crash.
One State Police lieutenant said that, although the wing met technical training requirements, ``he did not feel that formal training was up to the standards one would expect.''

O'Toole issued a statement Friday, saying, ``My thoughts and prayers go out to the families of the crash victims as they once again relive the tragedy that befell us all. Although nothing can be done to return those lost I am pleased with the comprehensive nature of this report.''
The report reviews significant changes that have been made since the crash, and others that are planned.

So far, aviation consultants have been hired to reorganize the air wing, the Department of State Police is seeking additional money to replace aircraft and ground facilities, more training has been required of air-wing managers, and the Framingham fuel facility has been permanently closed.

The report ruled out any acts of sabotage, but it said that among police management there was ``organizational confusion resulting from a lack of designated responsibility'' for taking care of the fuel facility.
Water contamination in the fuel found in the system of the wrecked helicopter ranged from 2.5 to nine times the allowable limit.
``We have learned from this tragedy,'' says the report, signed by Reed V. Hillman, State Police superintendent.

DOC.PREAMBLE: BC-TWA-CRASH-NYT ROUGH SEAS PARALYZE SEARCH FOR PLANE WRECKAGE (sw) By ANDREW C. REVKIN c.1996 N.Y. Times News Service

TEXT.p: SMITHTOWN, N.Y. A;N;D;MD; On the 50th day after the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, senior investigators said that persistent rough seas off the coast of Long Island had paralyzed efforts to collect the remaining wreckage of the shattered jumbo jet.

The only activity by divers in the past seven days was one six-hour mission completed early on Thursday morning, Robert Francis, the vice chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, said. The divers, from the Navy ship Grapple, were able to reach the last remaining large field of debris, but rising seas on the surface and storm-stirred silt on the bottom reduced visibility to almost zero and limited them to one haul of only a dozen small pieces of wreckage, Francis said.

Even those pieces remained on the stern of the ship as seas grew rougher on Thursday, leaving investigators ashore with no new flow of potential clues to the cause of the explosion that split the jet on July 17, killing all 230 people aboard.

With one hurricane recently departed and another one stirring the Atlantic anew, conditions were so bad on Thursday morning, Francis said, that a wave knocked him into the water as it swept the Navy speedboat carrying him and several other investigators to the Grapple.
``Fortunately, the admiral was kind enough to come back and get me,'' Francis said of Rear Adm. Edward Kristensen, the pilot of the speedboat and the Navy officer in charge of the salvage effort.

Even though more than two-thirds of the aircraft had been recovered as of a week ago, and much of that debris has been closely scrutinized, criminal and transportation investigators say they still lack sufficient evidence to show that the explosion was caused by a bomb or missile rather than a mechanical failure.

In a new sign that investigators still lacked many of the pieces shed by the airplane in the earliest moments of its disintegration, Francis said that as soon as weather permitted a sonar sweep of the bottom would be extended west and south of the areas that had already been searched.

The decision to backtrack another half mile along the ill-fated plane's path from Kennedy International Airport was made after a new analysis of the last radar traces of pieces falling from the airplane, Kristensen said.

Despite the lack of new wreckage pulled from the ocean, Francis said, investigative teams at a complex of hangars in Calverton, were still busy working with what they already had. He said new pieces were added on Thursday to a growing reconstruction of the cabin between the wings.

But some of the most coveted pieces of wreckage were still missing, he said, including many parts of the center fuel tank, which sat under a group of seats that many investigators say were the likely center of the explosion.

On Thursday, Francis confirmed previous reports that two seats at the right end of row 23 had large holes ripped in their metal backs. ``They may turn out to be significant,'' he said, but he cautioned that ``there are a lot of ways things can get holes in them after an airplane accident.''
